story:
Short Summary

The Betrothal is the story of many mothers in Uganda and other developing countries who lose their children due to preventable causes. Often, it is because public officials steal funds meant for their treatment or vaccination. In the play, the playwright, Joshua Mmali, dramatizes one such case, using a village woman in Uganda and her baby on the one hand, and a young gentleman who works in the Ministry of Health on the other. After stealing a lot of money in underhand deals that involve his bosses, this public official is intent on marrying his beautiful girlfriend whose mother, coincidentally, is the village woman mentioned earlier.

Why this play is important

The drama highlights health issues that people have to grapple with everyday in developing countries. It is a play that addresses an issue that is very close to my heart, and that is why I am inspired to see its success. When I lost my father, Dr. Joseph Sepiriya Nyanzi on the 8th of August 2014, it was on his way from Masaka to Kampala- a two-hour drive to hospital. Had there been a health centre well equipped for bypass surgery in Masaka, my father would still be alive.

The playwright seeks to raise awareness about the dangers of corruption in Uganda, in Africa, and in any society that might be impacted by such dangers.

The Betrothal illustrates these negative impacts in a way that seeks to appeal both to the audience’s conscience and to their human emotions, hoping to positively impact their attitudes.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $15,000 to support the premiering of The Betrothal  between August and November 2016 at the Uganda National Cultural Centre (The National Theatre). The play will hold two stage productions in Kampala, Uganda, before going on tour to other East African capitals.

We have designed for you 6 attractive perks...

We are a crew team of four(4) and a cast team of seven(6). The money will be used to finance rehearsals for six (6)weeks, buy props, and sets decorations, as well as facilitate actors and team members

The Impact

The Betrothal emphasizes accountability that ensures that individuals and families around the world, and especially in developing countries, access public services from their governments so that they are able to live their full lives with dignity and respect.

Risks & Challenges

  • In casting for this play, the playwright, Joshua Mmali and Director, Angela Emurwon, have made serious considerations about gender diversity and inclusiveness. It is a play where, in the absence of a strong political will to fight corruption, women take the lead role in fighting the graft that leaves them without the basic necessities like medicines for their children. To continue its revolutionary stance, it is also the very first Ugandan play to cast an LGBTQ person, in a highly homophobic society.
  • We are a very small crew sharing responsibilities by taking on more than one role  to cut production costs. The Director, Angela Emurwon, and myself as a producer, have worked on various productions requiring various skills. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign to bring social injustices to the realm of public debate. You will be highlighting and exercising your authority to seek justice.

story:
Short Summary

New play BREATHE tackles the thorny issue of mental health amongst millenials trying to make their way in life.

BREATHE pans across the struggles of four housemates living in London trying to successfully accomplish their dreams. Personal secrets, fears and dreams emerge as their lives intertwine, revealing the importance of human connection and friendship in the face of anxiety and depression. Will they choose security or transform their fears into fuel to conquer their dreams? 

At the heart of our play lies the idea of bringing the medium of theatre and film together through the fusion of video projections and social media’s overshadowing presence. BREATHE is designed to engage in a dialogue with the viewer, provoking introspection and stimulating imaginations through the use of visual projections.

We believe that the topic of mental illness is particularly relevant in the current period of time in which the UK and several regional councils have reported high rate of low mental wellbeing among their citizens. The play aims to open the question to mental illness to everyone and open up these ‘labels’ as anxiety and depression to a wider public and allow an open discussion without the need to judge or discriminate.

 

Who are we?

Lucrezia Pollice
Lucrezia Pollice is a freelance Theatre & Film Director and Producer based in London.
Lucrezia after training as an actor at the most famous drama school in Italy Paolo Grassi Academy and RADA foundation course at CSVPA, she graduated with a First Honours Degree from the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, in Drama, Applied Theatre and Education - focusing her degree on Directing, Producing and Playwrighting.
Lucrezia has been recently produced and directed the critically acclaimed short documentary IDENTITY which premiered at the United Nations WTPFilm Festival at the BFI Southbank. She will soon be producing and directing a documentary short film for Westminster Council.

 

Aretusa Campagnolo

Aretusa has a passion for the performing arts and is especially interested in interdisciplinary and independent theatre projects. She has a background in performing arts and festival organisation as well as marketing and communications.
Aretusa worked as an assistant producer for MDA Contemporary Dance Company and as an executive producer for RedWedge Srl film production company based in Rome. She moved to the uk to undertake a Master’s degree in Culture, Policy and Management at City University of London, where she graduated in October 2017.
Prior to moving into assisting in producing Metal Rabbit Productions in autumn 2017, she intered as a Company Administrator for circus company Gandini Juggling.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to be able to afford to put our time and creativity into this production we need to raise £1100 which will cover our marketing expenses, rehearsal space, venue costs and most importantly paying our creative cast members and designers. 

Any donation and even small contribution will make a huge difference to the quality of our experience with this piece, as we will be able to concentrate our energies on the overall production quality. 

 

The Impact

BREATHE explores the subject of anxiety, friendship and resilience. The story will highlight conversations about pressures, fears and societal expectations that young generations face on a daily basis. Partially autobiographical, the show also aims to investigate the connection between mental illness and its social effect on the daily life. We are in the process of partnering with local charities and councils who raise awareness about mental wellbeing and psychological support.

We want our audiences to feel empowered when they see this show.

We want them to see their own story and personal experience reflected on stage.

We hope through this play to promote hope and a positive representation of seeking for psychological help through rough times, a new non-capitalist perspective on what success is, and most importantly a desire to get up from the theatre and go towards one’s dreams with full strength.

 

Risks & Challenges

There a lot of risks and expenses behind a production.

Our biggest challenge therefore will be to fill the auditorium of the Lion and Unicorn Theatre with plenty of people. However with the right marketing strategy and the support we have already started gathering from creating collaborative work, we are positive about our potential audiences.

Without these funds the project will go on, but as a shadow of itself. We all know how to make do but we want to do better. And we can with your help. Any support is deeply appreciated.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. The more people that know about this campaign, the greater opportunities we have to reach this goal! Please share and spread the word about this project:

COME AND SEE THE SHOW

TWEET ABOUT IT

LET YOUR FRIENDS AND FRIENDS OF YOURS KNOW ABOUT IT

LET YOUR FAMILY KNOW ABOUT IT

CONTACT US WITH AN EMAIL AND SAY HI. WE LOVE HEARING FROM PEOPLE.

story:
I am Jenny Colebourne, I was born in London, England within the sound of Bow Bells which makes me a true cockney, a true Londoner. I seem to have inherited, from my father’s side a great sensitivity towards sound and music and a deep love of dance. I was also born with great sensitivity, an ability to dream and a spiritual  connection. I don’t know where this came from but I am grateful for it. I own Illium Center of Light in Athens, Greece, a healing Center where I teach Pilates, Yoga and Reiki. 
In this moment, we are going through a difficult moment in Greece, which means that I can t afford the cost of an educational seminar in Patras, Greece about Skeletical System BMC in 21-31 August 2017. The cost is 100 euros per day (total of 1000 euros) 
I would be greatful if you could help me to realize this dream... Thank you
(http://www.dancarte.gr/index.php?option=com_con...) 

my websites are : www.illium.gr  & http://jenn...

story:
WAR Trilogy Synopsis

At some point in the future, the United States is engaged in a violent war with another country. Political tensions between the two countries have escalated over the past few years, resulting in the most dire and bloody conflict in recent American history: Operation Janus. A Soldier, part of the United States Army Reserve, receives orders to deploy to the war, forcing him to leave behind his newlywed wife. Devastated by the news, but also realizing that the deployment was imminent, the Soldier leaves with the understanding that he might not come back. 

WAR is a story told through dance and cinematography about love, trauma, guilt, grief, and acceptance in the face of extreme conflict. 

WAR Principal Cast

The Soldier (Rowan Quinain)
The Soldier, a member of the United States Army Reserve, is a young man enjoying a good life with the Love of his life, his newlywed wife. He works a great full-time civilian job while simultaneously advancing his military career on the side. As a reservist, he has never been deployed and has grown comfortable with his civilian life. However, everything changes when one day, he receives orders to report to active duty in Operation Janus, the most dire and bloody conflict in recent American history. Uncertain of his future, the Soldier is faced with the prospect of leaving behind his Love, as well as the imminent burdens of war and its consequences should he return. Whether or not he returns from his deployment, the Soldier's life is destined to change forever.

The Love (Liz Galvan)
The Love is a young woman newly married to the love of her life, the Soldier. With a great job and a wonderful husband, the Love is blissful and lives life with intense fulfillment every single day. Her idyllic is turned completely upside down when her Soldier receives orders to deploy overseas to Operation Janus, a violent conflict borne from mounting tensions between the antagonizing country and the United States. She is heartbroken and fearful of being separated from her Soldier, knowing that there is a chance he might never return. However, she recognizes that he made a commitment to serve his country, and by making a commitment to the Soldier, the Love also made a commitment to let him go should he be called to duty. Through this trial, she learns to find acceptance in the circumstances that befall her, and that near or far, her love will always be with the Soldier, and vice versa.

The Girl (Amy Shin)
A mysterious figure haunting the Soldier's dreams, the Girl is an enigma that only the Soldier is able to see. He is unsure of who she is, but knows that this Girl changed the course of his life forever. The Soldier gets the feeling that this Girl played a role in his service in Operation Janus, but for one reason or another, he cannot remember who she is. The significance of her existence is a mystery that the Soldier is hesitant to solve, but as her memory starts to consume him he has no choice but to face both his past and the Girl, in more ways than one.

WAR Project Background

My name is Specialist Rowan Quinain. I have been a dancer in the Chicago urban dance community for about six years now, and just recently also completed Initial Entry Training for the United States Army as a Corrections/Detentions Specialist. In December of last year, I returned home to Chicago as an Army Reservist and plan to continue pursuing civilian employment, education, and of course, my passion for dance.

The WAR Dance Trilogy is a project I have been conceptualizing since June of 2017. During this time, I was set to soon leave Chicago to complete my military training. As one of the first members, if not the first member, of the Chicago urban dance community to join the military and continue my dance career on the side, I wanted to take advantage of this unique position and tell stories to the community that have never been told before.

For a while now, I have recognized that my purpose as a dancer is to convey emotion and to tell stories. At its core, dance is a highly passionate form of art. Passion is also intertwined with suffering, and I have always sought to convey both positive and negative emotions through dance, to tell stories of my own trials and tribulations without fear of reprimand or embarrassment. Through WAR, however, I hope to tell the story of soldiers everywhere that may be suffering from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Traumatic Brain Injury as a result of their service in war. The characters in this trilogy are intentionally left nameless, as they could be absolutely anyone. Although this story is fictional, the message behind it is very much non-fictional, and there are many veterans that seek to benefit from an art project like this existing in the world.

What We Need & What You Get

I am seeking to raise at least $3,000 for this project.

  • Filmography ($1,000/33%) - A bulk of the funds raised from this campaign will go towards filmography provided by the amazing Viet Phan from New Pixel Films. I have a very close working and personal relationship with Viet; he has almost exclusively shot my concept videos in the past and I am 100% confident he would be perfect to help bring this project to fruition. This portion of funds will cover all aspects of the filming process to include filming, lighting, editing, consulting, and more.
  • Cast/Crew Pay ($500/17%) - I will be asking a lot of my cast members in terms of emotion through dance and acting and I am sure to challenge their boundaries and comfort as artists. Because of the artistic value of the work I am seeking to produce, I want to make sure my cast members are properly compensated for their contribution to my project. Additionally, any additional funds will go towards compensating additional crew members (yet to be determined) to potentially include a makeup artist, a sound designer, and more. In addition to financial compensation, I also would like to provide simple sustenance for my cast and crew on each day of production, whether it be for filming or editing.
  • Costumes/Props ($500/17%) - For the most part, many costumes in this video series will be provided either by me or another cast/crew member. However, there is a possibility I will need to purchase additional costumes for other scenes. There will also be a need to purchase additional military gear for scenes depicting the Soldier in action, which will consume a majority of the funds for this section.
  • Premiere Event ($600/20%) - After the videos have been produced, I want to use a portion of the funds raised from this campaign to host a premiere event to screen the trilogy. This event will be catered and will feature opening performances from the Chicago community to include dance, spoken word, music, and more. I will also have a booth set up for Mission22, a nonprofit organization with three programs to benefit veterans and veteran families who are suffering or have lost a loved one due to PTSD.
  • Mission22 Contribution ($400/13%) - Finally, the last portion of funds from this campaign will be donated to Mission22, mentioned above. M22 was founded based on the fact that over 20 veterans take their own lives every single day due to the effects of Post Traumatic Stress and Traumatic Brain Injury. M22 has three major programs to help combat this: Awareness, the War at Home Memorial, and Veteran Treatment Programs. M22 represents the perfect bridge between military life and art and I could not choose a better beneficiary for this project. In addition to funds raised here on IndieGogo, all proceeds and donations raised at the WAR Premiere Event will be added to my contribution to M22. You can find out more about M22 here: http://www.mission22.com/ 

The Impact

Through WAR, I hope to bridge the gap between my experiences as a new soldier and as a dancer. In order to maintain maximum authenticity and respect, I will be meeting with several members of the Armed Forces, both current members and veterans, in order to paint a genuine picture of wartime and its effects for myself. I will also be consulting with these people regarding creative/story choices I am making in the WAR Dance Trilogy to make sure each story beat is purposeful, respectful, and impactful.

As mentioned previously, a portion of the proceeds from this campaign and the eventual release event will go towards benefiting Mission22. I believe M22's programs are the embodiment of what I am trying to accomplish with this project, and I think that with our combined efforts, we can make real strides in the war against veteran suicide and PTSD. My hope is to make even the smallest stride towards reducing the number of veteran suicides and to help the effort to fight PTSD and raise awareness about issues that are not heavily discussed today, especially not in the Chicago dance community. If this project can help save just one life, then I've accomplished my goal.

Risks & Challenges

Choreography Process - I have been choreographing for several years now and have taught various classes in the Chicagoland area, Minnesota, and California. While I am a capable choreographer, I am by no means an expert nor would I consider myself "fast" at choreographing. I can foresee the largest roadblock to this project would be the creative process itself and challenging myself to create the most impactful choreography that I can. While I have no doubt in my mind I can get it done, it is moreso an issue of how fast I can get it done, which is why I have left ample time in my production timeline for choreography itself. However, my cast members have assured me that should I need any assistance whatsoever, I can lean on them for creative advice and collaboration, so I don't see this as a pressing issue in terms of production.

Authenticity - I recognize that I myself do not have experience in the subject matter discussed in WAR. As stated previously, I am a new member of the Armed Forces and do not have any combat experience under my belt. One of my utmost concerns is the need for authenticity and respectful storytelling in the execution of this project, which is why I have already mentioned that I will be consulting with fellow soldiers, veterans, and ambassadors from Mission22, the non-profit that I seek to help benefit through this project. No story beat will be executed without being vetted or advised upon by people that have real experience in this matter, as this trilogy will be nothing without respect for the demographic it seeks to help.

Deployment - Finally, the ideas and story behind this project were all based on my very real fear of getting deployed. My reserve unit is currently "ready for deployment," which means I could get the call at any moment to leave within 30 days. This call could happen next week, next month, or not at all. While I am afraid, I am ready to fulfill my commitment as an Army Soldier and am currently steeling myself for the possibility of leaving home again soon. Should a deployment happen within the timeline of this production, all production will understandably cease until I return from my deployment. I ask for your understanding in this worst case scenario, as if it happens, there is nothing I can do to continue production while I am deployed. However, I am determined to bring this project to fruition no matter what happens, so production will continue as soon as I return home.

Production Timeline (Tentative)

Below I have mapped out a rough timeline for the production of WAR. This timeline is subject to change and hopefully expedited!

February

  • Finalize pre-production details
  • Produce teaching/filming schedules
  • Meet with ambassadors from Mission 22 as well as other Armed Forces members/veterans for interviews
  • Begin preliminary choreography

March

  • Continue choreography
  • Research filming locations/reserve locations, if necessary
  • Recruit extras/supporting cast

April

  • Finish choreography
  • Begin teaching to cast members

May

  • Film WAR
  • Begin planning Premiere Event

June

  • Finish filming WAR
  • Post-production and prepare for release
  • Premiere Event

July

  • Wide release of WAR on YouTube

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute to my campaign today, please share this page on your social media outlets! If you know anyone that has served in the Armed Forces no matter what branch of the military they were/are in, please consider sharing this campaign and its message to them as well. Thank you!

In December of last year, I returned home to Chicago as an Army Reservist and plan to continue pursuing civilian employment, education, and of course, my passion for dance.
The WAR Dance Trilogy is a project I have been conceptualizing since June of 2017. During this time, I was set to soon leave Chicago to complete my military training. As one of the first members, if not the first member, of the Chicago urban dance community to join the military and continue my dance career on the side, I wanted to take advantage of this unique position and tell stories to the community that have never been told before.
For a while now, I have recognized that my purpose as a dancer is to convey emotion and to tell stories. At its core, dance is a highly passionate form of art. Passion is also intertwined with suffering, and I have always sought to convey both positive and negative emotions through dance, to tell stories of my own trials and tribulations without fear of reprimand or embarrassment. Through WAR, however, I hope to tell the story of soldiers everywhere that may be suffering from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Traumatic Brain Injury as a result of their service in war. The characters in this trilogy are intentionally left nameless, as they could be absolutely anyone. Although this story is fictional, the message behind it is very much non-fictional, and there are many veterans that seek to benefit from an art project like this existing in the world.

What We Need & What You Get
I am seeking to raise at least $3,000 for this project.


Filmography ($1,000/33%) - A bulk of the funds raised from this campaign will go towards filmography provided by the amazing Viet Phan from New Pixel Films. I have a very close working and personal relationship with Viet; he has almost exclusively shot my concept videos in the past and I am 100% confident he would be perfect to help bring this project to fruition. This portion of funds will cover all aspects of the filming process to include filming, lighting, editing, consulting, and more.

Cast/Crew Pay ($500/17%) - I will be asking a lot of my cast members in terms of emotion through dance and acting and I am sure to challenge their boundaries and comfort as artists. Because of the artistic value of the work I am seeking to produce, I want to make sure my cast members are properly compensated for their contribution to my project. Additionally, any additional funds will go towards compensating additional crew members (yet to be determined) to potentially include a makeup artist, a sound designer, and more. In addition to financial compensation, I also would like to provide simple sustenance for my cast and crew on each day of production, whether it be for filming or editing.

Costumes/Props ($500/17%) - For the most part, many costumes in this video series will be provided either by me or another cast/crew member. However, there is a possibility I will need to purchase additional costumes for other scenes. There will also be a need to purchase additional military gear for scenes depicting the Soldier in action, which will consume a majority of the funds for this section.

Premiere Event ($600/20%) - After the videos have been produced, I want to use a portion of the funds raised from this campaign to host a premiere event to screen the trilogy. This event will be catered and will feature opening performances from the Chicago community to include dance, spoken word, music, and more. I will also have a booth set up for Mission22, a nonprofit organization with three programs to benefit veterans and veteran families who are suffering or have lost a loved one due to PTSD.

Mission22 Contribution ($400/13%) - Finally, the last portion of funds from this campaign will be donated to Mission22, mentioned above. M22 was founded based on the fact that over 20 veterans take their own lives every single day due to the effects of Post Traumatic Stress and Traumatic Brain Injury. M22 has three major programs to help combat this: Awareness, the War at Home Memorial, and Veteran Treatment Programs. M22 represents the perfect bridge between military life and art and I could not choose a better beneficiary for this project. In addition to funds raised here on IndieGogo, all proceeds and donations raised at the WAR Premiere Event will be added to my contribution to M22. You can find out more about M22 here: http://www.mission22.com/ 


The Impact
Through WAR, I hope to bridge the gap between my experiences as a new soldier and as a dancer. In order to maintain maximum authenticity and respect, I will be meeting with several members of the Armed Forces, both current members and veterans, in order to paint a genuine picture of wartime and its effects for myself. I will also be consulting with these people regarding creative/story choices I am making in the WAR Dance Trilogy to make sure each story beat is purposeful, respectful, and impactful.
As mentioned previously, a portion of the proceeds from this campaign and the eventual release event will go towards benefiting Mission22. I believe M22's programs are the embodiment of what I am trying to accomplish with this project, and I think that with our combined efforts, we can make real strides in the war against veteran suicide and PTSD. My hope is to make even the smallest stride towards reducing the number of veteran suicides and to help the effort to fight PTSD and raise awareness about issues that are not heavily discussed today, especially not in the Chicago dance community. If this project can help save just one life, then I've accomplished my goal.

Risks & Challenges
Choreography Process - I have been choreographing for several years now and have taught various classes in the Chicagoland area, Minnesota, and California. While I am a capable choreographer, I am by no means an expert nor would I consider myself "fast" at choreographing. I can foresee the largest roadblock to this project would be the creative process itself and challenging myself to create the most impactful choreography that I can. While I have no doubt in my mind I can get it done, it is moreso an issue of how fast I can get it done, which is why I have left ample time in my production timeline for choreography itself. However, my cast members have assured me that should I need any assistance whatsoever, I can lean on them for creative advice and collaboration, so I don't see this as a pressing issue in terms of production.
Authenticity - I recognize that I myself do not have experience in the subject matter discussed in WAR. As stated previously, I am a new member of the Armed Forces and do not have any combat experience under my belt. One of my utmost concerns is the need for authenticity and respectful storytelling in the execution of this project, which is why I have already mentioned that I will be consulting with fellow soldiers, veterans, and ambassadors from Mission22, the non-profit that I seek to help benefit through this project. No story beat will be executed without being vetted or advised upon by people that have real experience in this matter, as this trilogy will be nothing without respect for the demographic it seeks to help.
Deployment - Finally, the ideas and story behind this project were all based on my very real fear of getting deployed. My reserve unit is currently "ready for deployment," which means I could get the call at any moment to leave within 30 days. This call could happen next week, next month, or not at all. While I am afraid, I am ready to fulfill my commitment as an Army Soldier and am currently steeling myself for the possibility of leaving home again soon. Should a deployment happen within the timeline of this production, all production will understandably cease until I return from my deployment. I ask for your understanding in this worst case scenario, as if it happens, there is nothing I can do to continue production while I am deployed. However, I am determined to bring this project to fruition no matter what happens, so production will continue as soon as I return home.
Production Timeline (Tentative)
Below I have mapped out a rough timeline for the production of WAR. This timeline is subject to change and hopefully expedited!
February

Finalize pre-production details
Produce teaching/filming schedules
Meet with ambassadors from Mission 22 as well as other Armed Forces members/veterans for interviews
Begin preliminary choreography

March

Continue choreography
Research filming locations/reserve locations, if necessary
Recruit extras/supporting cast

April

Finish choreography
Begin teaching to cast members

May

Film WAR

Begin planning Premiere Event

June

Finish filming WAR

Post-production and prepare for release
Premiere Event

July
Wide release of WAR on YouTube

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you cannot contribute to my campaign today, please share this page on your social media outlets! If you know anyone that has served in the Armed Forces no matter what branch of the military they were/are in, please consider sharing this campaign and its message to them as well. Thank you!

story:
About the Show

You're invited to the last sh*t show of the year, to revel in the deaths, divorces, deception and the miserable isolation of life. We've all been through some stuff and thrown some parties, and it just seems fitting to go out with a bang. There will be drugs. 

What We Need

Here's the breakdown of what we need in order to make this production as successful as possible:

  • We're looking to raise about $1,200 for our production of An Incomplete List... Your contribution will support basic needs such as props, set materials, costume materials, and payment for our actors and production team. 
  • Even if we don't make our goal, your contribution will still support our production, as any funds not received in donations will be coming out of the artists' personal finances. Thank you in advance for your kind donation!

The Impact

In the past, An Incomplete List... was produced as part of the 2017 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. We produced this production on a $0 budget! All expenses were paid out of the pockets of the young artists making the art. After completing a successful sold-out run, Dante and the original cast and creative team have been DETERMINED to continue the play's journey, reaching new artistic heights and new enthusiastic audiences. Your contribution would assist us in doing so, by increasing our production value and our audience reach without decreasing the money in our own pockets. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us by making a donation, don't sweat it! You can still help us by sharing this campaign with your friends and loved ones, and by seeing the show! (Because the show will  go on). Tickets for our show will be available soon at an affordable $8!! For more information on the show itself, check out our Facebook Event Page. For more information about Bloomsburg Theatre Ensemble, you can go to bte.org 

 

 

Cast and Creative Team

Dante Green, Marlee Gordon, Daniel Jones, Patrick Campbell, Alyssa Batsakis, Terran Scott, Max Van Kooy, Phenon Murphy, Matthew Donzella, Genevieve Farbe, Rebecca Thomas, Lyell Hintz, Hannah Sandler, and Sophia Grosshauser. 

About the Playwright

Dante Green was born and raised in the small town of Bloomsburg, PA. His passion for art first sparked in the Alvina Krause Theatre with Bloomsburg Theatre Ensemble, working as a community actor from elementary to high school. His experience includes straight play, proscenium theater, performing in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, The Miracle Worker and several other classics, as well as original community works, entitled The Landlover! A Pirate Musical, Lil’ Red’s Extreme Freestylin’ Fairytales, and many more. Now, Dante is continuing his education in Philadelphia, where his artistic endeavors focus on writing, composing, devising, and collaborating. He studies Directing, Playwriting, and Production with a concentration in Musical Theatre Writing at The University of The Arts, and plans to attend the Headlong Performance Institute this semester to further train in performance. At UArts, Dante has gained experience in the new musical field, working with upcoming composers such as Cesar Alvarez and Michael R. Jackson on their respective shows The Elementary Spacetime Show, and White Girl in Danger. Dante is thrilled to be making his return to his hometown theatre, bringing his beloved and multi-talented friends and collaborators with him in a production that cannot be missed.

story:
Our Campaign

The Sunday Art Club (TSAC) is a two-part platform we launched in the summer of 2020, comprising a monthly live event showcasing multidisciplinary art from diverse artists.

Artist-led, we passionately believe in advocating for grassroots artists and connecting them with audiences craving a place to discover and enjoy new artists, art and performances.

In the months since TSAC began we’ve programmed an array of brilliant performances ranging from musicians, such as Jordana Mba & Kaia Vieira, to Spoken Word Poet Marta Luné, and Performance Artist Kollier Din-Bangura. We also launched a ‘Platform Talks’ series in August 2020, a spotlight style interview segment that hit the ground running with veteran artists Dollie Henry & Paul Jenkins, founders of Body of People Jazz Theatre Company.        
 These are but a few talented artists out of the 52 that we’ve platformed so far, (some established in their own right), who deserve to have their work and voices amplified. Our mission is to connect them with audiences who also have a yearning for real grassroots art.

Our event garnered the interest of local and national publications, such as The Upcoming and BBC radio, links below: 

The Upcoming - The Future of Inclusive Theatre

Islington Gazette - Sunday Art Club

Broadway World - Outdoor Festival The Sunday Art Club

TheSundayArtClub.com

TSAC is a two-part platform, the first part is an Event scheduled for the last Sunday of every month and centred around:  

  • Intimate performances.
  • A platform showcasing both undiscovered and established talent.
  • A curated experience of real grassroots art.
  • A scratch space for artists of all disciplines to explore new work in front of a live audience.
  • Live interviews with veteran artists and change makers in the arts industry.

The second part is a digital platform that we’ve begun building which aims to be: 

  • A digital hub for grassroots culture globally allowing us to expand our reach beyond the U.K.
  • A collection of works, performances & interviews available online, anytime or location.
  • A finger-on-the-pulse community arts space accessible 365 days a year. 

See our Concept productions below for a look at the artists and stories we've featured so far.

Music Sessions - Roxana & Jorma - Carnal Hell

Visual Art Series - Katja Larsson

Theatre Series - Macbeth: BEIRUT

What We Need & What You Get

In order to preserve our quality and our pledge to showcasing the best undiscovered and emerging talent, we need the funds to organise production, and grow the platform's reach through targeted marketing whilst paying artists fairly.

We have set our initial goal at £2,500 because we are keen to iterate rapidly in this time of great need for the arts and most importantly, grassroots representation. Reaching this goal would allow us to invest in targeted marketing, basic production costs (transportation and Covid-19 PPE) and reserve cash for artist expenses. 

However, in order to become the force for change we aspire to represent, our stretch goals are the desired target.

For example, the Budget Breakdown below details the costs to produce a Digital performance.

Pay at the U.K. National Living Wage is what we can achieve throughout 2021 if we reach our Stretch Goal of £12,500; producing both live/digital performances each month. 

The Breakdown below is calculated at industry rates arts (Equity & BECTU) and is reflective of an artist/creative's cost of living, frequency of work opportunities, and requires more funding.

Reaching our Stretch Goals of £25,000 and beyond will allow us to implement a comprehensive strategy (hiring qualified professionals in roles such as marketing) preparing the platform for 2022.

The Stretch Goals at £7,500, £12,500, £25,000 and £40,000 reflect the true costs involved in establishing a live/digital art event that punches above its weight and produces content comparable to that of industry giants.

Reaching these Stretch Goals will allow us to attract additional sponsorship and a more sustainable funding structure that enables The Sunday Art Club to become an event of excellence. A successfully funded campaign will give us 6 months to build upon the successes of 2020 and implement the best strategy to achieve a thriving platform in 2022.  

You, our amazing backers can fund this endeavour by making a one-off contribution or collecting a Perk. Some perks will give you discounted access to TSAC when we re-open this summer and others will grant you behind the scenes participation and even an Executive Producer role. Perk to Consider: Summer Live Event Pass.

International backers are encouraged to see TSAC as a global platform that could be producing live events internationally as early as 2022. Even with our work focused in London and the U.K. at present, it's very important that we connect with international artists through our digital platform and showcase a wide range of stories. Perk to Consider: Summer Live-Stream Pass.

We vow to keep The Sunday Art Club Artist-led and will always be answerable to the artists and audiences that support us, ensuring that the individual is heard and championed.

What will TSAC's Impact be?

We launched TSAC in the summer of 2020 just as the first Covid-19 national lockdown in the U.K. eased and are proud to say that both July and August editions sold out. We programmed more than 30 performances involving over 50 artists. Our September edition saw great ticket sales (our first attempt at monetising the event) before being cut short by new Covid-19 safety measures.

On a local level, TSAC will be a hub for artists and community to come together and celebrate grassroots art, reconnecting audiences' relationship to art and expanding representation across the many art forms.

On an international and global level, artists will be given a platform to reach a much larger audience, particularly audiences who are actively seeking to engage with performers sidelined from mainstream performance.

Whilst success means different things to different people, we want to mandate our success in the championing of grassroots artists and the providing of appropriate support. Beyond this, we absolutely want to be a force for change straddling both the commercial world of live entertainment and the artistic fringe environment that often produces the best artistic voices.

The Sunday Art Club will be our way of democratizing art and connecting diverse stories with diverse audiences.

Join the movement.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest and most immediate hurdle is Covid-19 and the lasting effects that prohibit the entertainment industry from holding large events.

Drawing on the expertise of Khaos Artistic Director James Scotland who has worked as an Actor/Director/ Producer in theatre (West End, Fringe) and film for over a decade, our team will focus on the quality of performance and representation of diverse artists, ensuring that both can be delivered to audiences within Covid-19 guidelines as they change and keep everyone safe.

In-line with established theatres and online streaming services, Creative Director Marwa Ayari will connect and grow our audience nationally and internationally through our digital platform making TSAC a secure investment in the face of Covid-19 and a vital force in Covid recovery for the freelancers most affected within the arts industry.

We don't run the risk of losing funds to Covid-19 as any work that needs to be created in isolation and or with strict Covid-19 guidelines can be adhered to, allowing us to place equal focus on the development of our online platform. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you are able to financially contribute or not, it will make the world of difference to this campaign if you share it far and wide. Especially internationally where we want to connect with diverse artists and audiences.

You can also connect with us through social media, engage with our material and give us feedback.

Instagram: the.sunday.art.club  | Facebook: the.sunday.art.club | Twitter: the.sunday.art.club   

Instagram: KhaosEurope  | Facebook: KhaosEurope | Twitter: KhaosEurope

Instagram: outsidethe_zone  | Facebook: Outsidethezone

story:
Who We Are

The Cuckoo's Theater Project is a non-profit theater company producing works in the Rogers Park neighborhood of Chicago. We are currently in the midst of our 5th season, but we need your help to continue. TCTP is encountered countless roadblocks to get to this anniversary season, and only with your support will we be able to continue. By donating today, you will ensure that TCTP can follow through with our 5th season (see season productions below) as well as renovate our venue at 7077 N Ashland Avenue. This is a pivotal time for The Cuckoo's Theater Project. We could not be where we are today without support from our patrons and donors, but we are now asking for your generous support in our time of need.

 

Mission Statement: 

The Cuckoo's Theater Project produces works that expose the discomforts of human nature. By navigating the struggle as a community, we seek to find light within the darkness in hopes of creating a brighter future. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this campaign is to do two things:

1. Ensure we can successfully finish the remaining two shows in our season.

2. Make the first venue of our building into a quality, licensed, and rentable space not only for TCTP but for other storefront theaters and the Rogers Park community.  

 

We have two shows left in our 5th season: Missed Opportunities by Jillian Leff and Calorie Counters by Molly Wagner. Both of these shows are world premieres.

We need your help to make these amazing shows happen. By donating, you can also receive complimentary tickets and other perks to see your contribution in effect. 

 

"The Nest" is the nickname for the Cuckoo's building at 7077 N Ashland Avenue. The building was purchased in 2016 by our managing director and donated to TCTP. The building was originally home to the Rogers Park Women's Center and later converted into a church. The first floor of the building will house a primary 50-seat performance space (which can be used both traditionally and in the round), a small rehearsal space, a dance studio, a set construction room, and offices. The second floor will be a large 100-seat performance space, costume and prop storage (for rentals), and individual studio spaces. 

Our initial goal is for the downstairs venue to become a usable space. Many of the key elements are already existing, but paint, a light-grid, and dressing room renovations are currently needed in order to finish this project. With the first space done, TCTP will finally have a home. But equally important: a large number of small performing arts organizations will have a local, affordable place to present their own art. We want this space to be a legacy for The Cuckoo's Theater Project, but also be an important part of the Rogers Park arts scene for the countless organizations that are based here. 

 

The Impact

Your contribution to TCTP will not only preserve Rogers Park arts, but will also stabilize many other artists and arts organizations in the area. Below, we've listed some of the most important reasons for you to donate today:

  • TCTP staff and company have a proven track record of the drive and motivation that it takes to run a non-profit theater company. We started with little knowledge, little money, and only a few people. We have since become a company with a strong, knowledgeable staff and a dedicated core of company members who have fallen in love with the company and what we do. 
  • The Nest was always going to be a challenge from the start. Of course, the gift of this building was amazing, but we've lacked the resources and backing to complete the project. However, we are incredibly close to finishing the first space: by searching for donations of seating, building our own in-the-round stage, and volunteering time to clean and organize. 
  • We have always had a dedication to our community. Having been born and bred in Rogers Park, we struggled with the fact that there were little-to-no affordable venue options in the neighborhood. We want The Nest to be a place for the whole community to gather and to foster creativity in every way. 
  • Season 5 is about identity. TCTP is now beginning to have their own identity and share with Chicago. By continuing our season, we are learning more about ourselves and showing our audience how to learn more about themselves and each other. 

 

Risks & Challenges

In order to fully produce the world premiere of Calorie Counters, we are reaching out to our friends, fellow artists, and supportive network to raise the funds we need to realize our full artistic vision. We are creating this campaign to help us offset the costs of producing a show, and your generous donation will allow us to pay our performers and designers that will allow us to fully fund this production. Additional proceeds will go towards our ongoing renovations to our home, The Nest

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, there are other ways to help! 

  • Please share this campaign on social media and with your friends and family directly. You can make a big impact by just helping us get the word out and encouraging others to participate! 
  • If you are a designer, stage manager, or other theatre artist and would like to donate your time in either producing Missed Opportunities or Calorie Counters or if you are interested in volunteering to help with building renovations please contact Artistic Director, Marc James, via email (mjames@thecuckoostheaterproject.com). 

Thank you for supporting The Cuckoo's Theater Project on our journey.
story_txt:
Who We Are
The Cuckoo's Theater Project is a non-profit theater company producing works in the Rogers Park neighborhood of Chicago. We are currently in the midst of our 5th season, but we need your help to continue. TCTP is encountered countless roadblocks to get to this anniversary season, and only with your support will we be able to continue. By donating today, you will ensure that TCTP can follow through with our 5th season (see season productions below) as well as renovate our venue at 7077 N Ashland Avenue. This is a pivotal time for The Cuckoo's Theater Project. We could not be where we are today without support from our patrons and donors, but we are now asking for your generous support in our time of need.
 
Mission Statement: 
The Cuckoo's Theater Project produces works that expose the discomforts of human nature. By navigating the struggle as a community, we seek to find light within the darkness in hopes of creating a brighter future. 
 

What We Need & What You Get
The goal of this campaign is to do two things:
1. Ensure we can successfully finish the remaining two shows in our season.
2. Make the first venue of our building into a quality, licensed, and rentable space not only for TCTP but for other storefront theaters and the Rogers Park community.  
 
We have two shows left in our 5th season: Missed Opportunities by Jillian Leff and Calorie Counters by Molly Wagner. Both of these shows are world premieres.
We need your help to make these amazing shows happen. By donating, you can also receive complimentary tickets and other perks to see your contribution in effect. 
 
"The Nest" is the nickname for the Cuckoo's building at 7077 N Ashland Avenue. The building was purchased in 2016 by our managing director and donated to TCTP. The building was originally home to the Rogers Park Women's Center and later converted into a church. The first floor of the building will house a primary 50-seat performance space (which can be used both traditionally and in the round), a small rehearsal space, a dance studio, a set construction room, and offices. The second floor will be a large 100-seat performance space, costume and prop storage (for rentals), and individual studio spaces. 
Our initial goal is for the downstairs venue to become a usable space. Many of the key elements are already existing, but paint, a light-grid, and dressing room renovations are currently needed in order to finish this project. With the first space done, TCTP will finally have a home. But equally important: a large number of small performing arts organizations will have a local, affordable place to present their own art. We want this space to be a legacy for The Cuckoo's Theater Project, but also be an important part of the Rogers Park arts scene for the countless organizations that are based here. 
 
The Impact

Your contribution to TCTP will not only preserve Rogers Park arts, but will also stabilize many other artists and arts organizations in the area. Below, we've listed some of the most important reasons for you to donate today:

TCTP staff and company have a proven track record of the drive and motivation that it takes to run a non-profit theater company. We started with little knowledge, little money, and only a few people. We have since become a company with a strong, knowledgeable staff and a dedicated core of company members who have fallen in love with the company and what we do. 
The Nest was always going to be a challenge from the start. Of course, the gift of this building was amazing, but we've lacked the resources and backing to complete the project. However, we are incredibly close to finishing the first space: by searching for donations of seating, building our own in-the-round stage, and volunteering time to clean and organize. 
We have always had a dedication to our community. Having been born and bred in Rogers Park, we struggled with the fact that there were little-to-no affordable venue options in the neighborhood. We want The Nest to be a place for the whole community to gather and to foster creativity in every way. 
Season 5 is about identity. TCTP is now beginning to have their own identity and share with Chicago. By continuing our season, we are learning more about ourselves and showing our audience how to learn more about themselves and each other. 

 

Risks & Challenges
In order to fully produce the world premiere of Calorie Counters, we are reaching out to our friends, fellow artists, and supportive network to raise the funds we need to realize our full artistic vision. We are creating this campaign to help us offset the costs of producing a show, and your generous donation will allow us to pay our performers and designers that will allow us to fully fund this production. Additional proceeds will go towards our ongoing renovations to our home, The Nest
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute financially, there are other ways to help! 

Please share this campaign on social media and with your friends and family directly. You can make a big impact by just helping us get the word out and encouraging others to participate! 
If you are a designer, stage manager, or other theatre artist and would like to donate your time in either producing Missed Opportunities or Calorie Counters or if you are interested in volunteering to help with building renovations please contact Artistic Director, Marc James, via email (mjames@thecuckoostheaterproject.com). 

Thank you for supporting The Cuckoo's Theater Project on our journey.

story:
Welcome to How To Save The World!

In How To Save The World, you will be immersed into an epic theatre experience, as you witness Keira, an idealistic yet troubled drama student, strive to establish herself as a professional playwright by winning the London Student Drama Festival. However, the lengths that she and her cast of closest friends must go to in order to achieve artistic excellence will irrevocably change how they see the world, and themselves. Prepare for a journey like no other!

Here is the ticket link for our event: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/redgates-presents-...

Check out this feature on MyTheatreMates: https://mytheatremates.com/howtosavetheworld-ne...

And check out our Facebook Event page!: https://www.facebook.com/events/2457746194245692/

Thank you so much for coming onto this page. Your simple click has already made a world of difference! Who knows, there might be a reward waiting for you at the bottom of this page...

Yep, that's me. 

My name is Patrick Bayele. I am an actor, writer, director, and I am about to graduate with a First-Class degree in Film Studies and Comparative Literature from Queen Mary University Of London. Having been raised by three parents - my mother, father, and VHS system - I have loved and revelled in visual storytelling before I uttered my first words (at the age of 5). A video of Terminator 2, bought by my mother from Asda (I remember trying to pronounce the name Schwarzenegger on the cassette case to no avail), was the straw that broke the camel's back. I no longer wanted to watch the screen; I wanted to be in the screen. I turned to local performing arts in my area - acting, singing and dance - and it only took a matter of sessions, and the role of Leroy in Bugsy Malone, to seal my future and my passion in storytelling. I have never looked back. 

...And here we are.

16 years later, and currently 22 years old - mature, grizzled, and with an unrivalled sense of humour - I am now part of Identity Agency Group, the same agency as John Boyega and Letitia Wright, and the National Youth Theatre of Great Britain, a charity which has nurtured hundreds of influential artists. Since 2015, I have performed at Shaftesbury Theatre, Wilton's Music Hall, The Royal Court and the Criterion Theatre in anniversary specials, educational workshops and world premieres. Many, many industry professionals such as Paul Roseby OBE, Femi Oguns MBE, Lynette Linton, Juliet Knight and Sita Thomas, have commended me for my commitment, rigour, professionalism, undying focus and my invincible vibe. 

Function, directed by Lynette Linton (currently the Artistic Director at the Bush Theatre), written by Sophie Ellerby, performed at the Criterion Theatre - what a show!

How To Save The World is the culmination of everything I have learned ever since I began performing all those moons ago, and this show marks our entry into the realm of excellence. I have written several pieces for Theatre, TV, Film, and I frequently collaborate with Redgates Theatre - run by Callum Tilling, our guardian angel for this production - in helping to direct the critically-acclaimed Gateways showcases. I established my artistic company - Pat On The Back Productions - in 2017, after having staged No Good, the third play that I have written, acted in and directed. How To Save The World is my fifth self-written play - and by far my most ambitious. 

Being personally invited to meet the cast of Black Panther - I look so goofy!

Moscow theatre raves with the gang - for the win!

However, it was my six-week acting term at the Moscow Art Theatre School in 2018 which changed me irrevocably, as an artist and as a person. Having been immersed in such a distinct culture, I learned that there is no rulebook for telling stories.

This adaptation of The Seagull, directed by Yuriy Butusov, burnt the rulebook right in front of me.

As a person who has endured adversity, loss and heartbreak, I felt that The Seagull by Anton Chekhov - a personal favourite, and a play which solidified the prestige of the Moscow Art Theatre School at the turn of the 20th century - was the perfect vehicle to tell a modern day story about 21st century humanity. Our intention with the play is to find something beautiful amidst the haze of our reality; we want things to change for the better, once and for all - all of us do. But in order to save the world, we must become who we are destined to be. This is a story of what it means to be human.

Looking out over the Baltic Sea in Peterhof, St. Petersburg - the future is out there.

We are a cast of Queen Mary students, with the majority of us having studied drama. What's funny is that we often experience overlaps with our lives and the lives of the characters, and this brings us closer to the story at hand, and brings us even closer together as a cast. We all collaborate through the theatre committee, but this is a story which I felt had to be taken outside of Queen Mary, so it could be showcased on a much wider scale. We have been working tirelessly to honour this story as much as possible, and we show no signs of stopping until we strike that set on the 31st, or perhaps even after this date! Help us in our journey by donating to our project, so you and I, through a story about actors - those people who are brilliant at playing other people, but never themselves - can; illustrate a new way of building identities, foster unconditional love amongst our diverse, divided communities, and usher in a dawn of a new theatre. How To Save The World is not only an adaptation of a masterpiece - it is a play that marks the beginning of a world of infinite possibilities through self-discovery, authentic passion, and a genuine belief in an ideal world. By contributing, you will aid us in eradicating a world so devoid of hope, that the only cry of resilience we can muster is 'that is the way it is', and you will bring us closer towards the great beyond of our generation.

It starts now - help us save the world.

Our excellent cast, from left to right: Archie Brown, Beatrice Olivier, Shavariya Padayachee, Patrick Bayele, Alfie Noble, Maria Messias Mendes, Rosie Hodgson and James Garnham. 

What We Need & What You Get

Redgates and Pat On The Back - partners in crime!

As the project has progressed, our total expenditure stands at an estimate of £9680. Whilst this was initially larger, it has been due to the good will of our associates and collaborators who have offered additional services or provided their assistance with little to no charge that the overall cost has decreased. Their contribution is invaluable to us, and will always be remembered.  

A substantial amount of capital has been amassed personally over the years, and this capital will be used to pay cast members and collaborating practitioners. With this page, we are asking for £1500 to help cover what reaches outside of our own pockets. However, as we have applied for further funding from other sources, we are launching this indiegogo not only to meet the demands of the production, but also to involve you, our audience, in its creation, so we can all truly develop a universal story and mould an everlasting cultural staple for everyone. Through this page, we aim to cover the cost of certain expenditures, those being:

  • The cost of making our play accessible (hiring extra chairs, props and platforms) (£1000).
  • Paying the salaries of technicians (£350).
  • Acquiring props (£150).

Studio 9294 - great, right?

We need your help to make this show the best it can be. We do not want to make a loss, cut elements from the show, compromise the longevity of the show, or reduce the salaries of our team. We really need your help to ensure that this production is as professional as it can be, and that it maximises its full potential in curating the careers of our young, emerging talent, whilst gaining longevity through national and international tours. Even though we are new to the realm of professional theatre-making, we are confident that our voice and our story is compelling. Your contributions ensure that this show goes up as seamlessly and gracefully as possible. This aids us in planning our next step with the play through collaborating with professional theatre-makers and donors. This is your show as much as it is ours, and your contributions assure that this play embarks on a successful future through tours, research and development, and international recognition.

Firstly, we'll be giving back to our audience through our Post-Show Q+A hosted by Terri Paddock on the 31st of July, the former editor of What'sOnStage, and the founder of MyTheatreMates, an excellent forum for independent theatre and journalism. You will be enriched, informed, enlightened and entertained as we; explore what the play means, reveal and share different insights into the story, discuss the challenges we had to face in its creation, articulate our intention in telling this story, chinwag over the play's future, and just have a laugh in general! 

Outside of this Q+A, donors will be rewarded not only with our utmost and sincere gratitude, but also with landmark materials from the play's production process. We have three tiers: Awesome Donors, Premium Donors and Badass Donors! Our Badass tier will be uploaded as the show approaches...

Premium donors who contribute £50 or more will receive: 

  • Deluxe copies of the script - Copies of our technical scripts in all the different draft versions, with amendments and notes, all signed by every member of our cast - they'll be worth a pretty penny in the future! This also includes Blessed They Be Damned, the very play which Keira, the protagonist, writes for the London Student Drama Festival, the competition she is driven to win throughout the story. That's all we'll say on that; we really have gone the extra mile to make this story as brilliant as possible!
  • Blueprints of the play - Have you wondered how actors become their characters? Have you ever been curious about what goes on in rehearsal rooms? How on earth did we create How To Save The World? This blueprint will give you all the answers and so, so much more. These USB blueprints contain around 30 hours of improvisations and thought-tracking exercises that enabled us to create these characters. Our script was written out of improvised scenes and exercises, and these blueprints grant you unrivalled access to our process. You can witness how the script and the characters have been brought to life over the past 5 months, day by day. These blueprints even contain footage of scenes that took place before the events of the play - a whole new play in its own right! They also contain the moodboards, concepts, documents and all the promotional materials we have developed - even the stuff we didn't decide to use! It's the closest thing we can do to giving you our brains.

 

Badass donors who contribute £100 or more will receive: 

  • Luxury packages - You will receive free tickets to our show and other shows, paid-for dining, and an invite to our private post-show party. Let us bring you into the world of London youth theatre with a toast to celebrate your arrival!
  • Involvement in our next show - If you donate £200, you will have an active say in what show we stage next. Whether you're acting, producing, writing, composing, directing - you can become one of us, right here, right now. Join us on the frontline in the war for a greater reality and have your visions come to life. We were born to create - you'll never look back!

Look at how badass we are - contribute £200 to join the squad!!!

If we don't reach our all-or-nothing target, all the funds will be sent back to you. In such a situation, it'll take us a good few months to recover from losses, and this may stall or hinder the progression of the play. However, our cast is determined to ensure that any funding that can be secured is sought for. Your contributions will ensure that we avoid making any major losses, and will prevent us from having compromise on professionalism, accessibility and quality. 

Anything you can contribute will put our show in a better position for development in the future, and will ensure that this play lives on. If you help us reach our goal, your donations will ensure that our play will be an emblem of true artistic quality, and you will be at the centre of a creative revolution. This is it - the time is now!

The Impact

I feel like this play has been in production subconsciously for almost a decade, as the sudden loss of my oldest brother, Anthony, in 2012, shattered my outlook on life. Ever since then, I have been re-building myself, nurturing my true identity through mourning and life experience. Now, this play has become more real than I even anticipated, and nothing, absolutely nothing, will come in the way of bringing this story to life, not only for myself, or for all of us, but for Anthony Bayele. This play is made for you, and could change everything. This play was meant to happen - and we want nothing more than for you to be apart of it.  Our project is valuable because it encompasses so many identities, experiences, issues, plights and human behaviours, that it connects all of us through the little things that all of us share. There are so many discoveries to be made in this play, so many personal revelations to be unearthed, it truly is a story for our times. You will experience an uncompromisingly and profoundly real, harrowing and tender tale, whilst also slapping your knee over laugh-out-loud, hilarious dialogue which you simply cannot make up. Our play is a play like no other. All of this drama is connected with choreography, movement and lighting, which all coalesce to make an awe-inspiring, unforgettable experience, leaving you yearning to pursue your greatest passions, whatever they may be. 

 My brother - who I dedicate this play to.

You will be inspired to; tap into your vocation; discard your inner-critic, your fears of judgement, and your need to compare yourself to others; and locate your true self and carve your destiny out of growth, learning, faith and compassion. The play will make you see things differently, and most importantly, you will see yourself differently. You are in the play as much as we are, and we are pushing the boundaries of storytelling in order to immerse you in this poetic world as fully as possible, so you can leave the auditorium with a clearer vision of your ideal self, driven to make the world a better place. If you buy a ticket or donate, you will be contributing towards a play that gives us the grace to be who we are. This play is about all of us - and those who contribute in any way will be contributing to the growth of a new generation, a generation built on equality, acceptance, love, passion, art, and most importantly, hope. 

Risks & Challenges

This play has become a challenge unto life itself, in more ways than we could foresee. We are all graduates who work in paid jobs, have far-branching expertise in different theatre fields and are familiar with theatre producing (many Queen Mary Students perform at Edinburgh Fringe regularly - we are a community of experienced and devoted artists). However, we are new to many crucial aspects of this industry - the nitty-gritty of producing, marketing the play, acquiring funding - we really are learning as we go along. Every mistake we have made has provided us with a lesson in ensuring excellence and avoiding absolute chaos (hahaha, absolute chaos, mate!). The main challenge we face, with two weeks until we go up, is selling out our venue through ardent promotion, and also hitting this £1500 landmark in such a short space of time. I'll be honest - I haven't given ourselves much time. But as someone who thrives off impulse, and is hellbent on bringing artistic visions to life, we brought this play together in the moment, because we simply couldn't wait to bring you and so many more people together on such a beautiful, momentous occasion.

We are all acquainted with industry professionals who can pull us out of any mud we find ourselves stuck in. While we are very much in the position to negotiate fees or make last minute adjustments, we have an ideal version of the show is in our hands, and with some extra funding, we can grip onto our intentions and execute our show how it is meant to be executed. If we do not hit our target we'll recover our losses through working, correspond with our associates to evaluate our strategies, and go back to the drawing board for our next production - but who knows what opportunities may vanish before us if we have no choice but to compromise? We don't want such a situation to arise - please, help us ensure that the play becomes a true success, for the benefit of us all. This is a not-for-profit project - I don't want a single penny to myself. All I want is for Pat On The Back Productions and Redgates Theatre to continue making great art for the greater good - your contribution will assure that this simple wish is granted. This art is for all of us, and this page is a way of bringing us together to heal our world through storytelling, one step and one day at a time. No more divides between artists and audiences - let's all come together to create truly astounding work, made by all of us, for all of us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I'm a firm believer that nothing is impossible - its just that some things are very, very, very difficult. However, we genuinely believe that if we try our utmost, we may hit or perhaps even exceed our target before August the 1st. If you have read this far, you are an absolute legend, and please contact me personally to gain a discount code for our show! (on Twitter or Facebook) - a cheeky little reward for your intrigue! It's the least I could do for you taking interest in our journey. But if you cannot make the days for whatever reason, your contribution, or even by sharing the post onto your social media circles, talking about the play with your nearest and dearest, or using the indiegogo share tools to get the word out, will bring us one step closer to a new horizon of an ideal humanity. Theatre is the 'sacred arena of the imagination', as Simon Callow once said; and our show is a dream-like poem, it is our imagination unchained; it is our most beautiful ideas on stage. Art to me is proof that we are alive, so let's make our dreams come true for once! What else are dreams for other than to realise what's possible?

This play is a passion project, it is a brave adaptation, it is my highs and lows; this play means everything to me, and we can all be in this together. Join us as we venture into the great unknown; things will never be the same when we reach that brighter future.

 As Anthony Bayele would chant in our house frequently: 'Let's Get It!'

This is only the beginning. Take care, my friends. 

Yours truly,

Patrick Bayele.

Thank you - from the Bayeles. I wish I was smiling properly in this photo! Ahh well :).
