qui s’appelle « L’amour tout nu » (http://suggerebonheur.com/les-podcasts/lamour-tout-nu/)
En 2015, je retrouve le feu de la scène pour vous
présenter le meilleur de mon univers créatif.
Témoignages



Il faut beaucoup de talent pour écrire un projet comme le tien et beaucoup d'audace       pour le financer comme tu le fais. J'aime rencontrer les gens qui ont du talent et les gens qui ont de l'audace. L'audace...c'est,à mon humble avis ,ce qui manque le plus à la           plupart des Québécois. Tu sais peut-être que mon compatriote Richard Desjardins(et     oui je suis originaire de l'Abitibi-Témiscamingue moi aussi) a financé son premier CD de cette façon. Je te souhaite autant de chance et de succès qu'il en a eu par la suite.                                     Jacques Michel


Allô la belle femme Lucie! wow! tu es géniale, tu vas au bout de tes projets, je t'admire tu sais!! Ce sera un plaisir, mais je vais y aller tout simplement avec mon cœur d'amour et à chaque fois que je vais toucher à ton projet il se gonflera de Lumière/Amour... alors lâches-toi lousse ma Lucie envoi la sauce !  xxxGuylaine Gamache 
Le titre est plein de belles émotions.
                                                       Jasmin Racicot
C'est génial, j'aime ça. Parlons-en de l'Amour de
toutes les sortes d'amour!! et surtout aimons!! Merci de ta confiance et que je
t'aime toi!!!
                                                                                                      Suzelle Tardis
Wow, bravo Lucie ! C'est inspirant !  XX
                                                              Valérie Dion
C’est super ! Ça accroche et la curiosité est là. Lâche
pas ton beau travail!
                                                                                       Andréanne Garneau-Vallée
Très belle initiative, je suis vraiment fière de toi! Tu peux compter sur mon soutient ! 
                                                                                                                      Annie Fortier
Démarche
artistique
En tant que philosophe de l'amour et artiste ma
mission est de répandre l'amour. Quoi de mieux que l'humour pour y parvenir ?
Et la scène est le lieu privilégié pour offrir l'amour à l'humanité. C'est ce
qui m'a incité à commencer à utiliser mes mots et mes émotions en 2011. C'est à
ce moment-là que j'ai commencé à écrire et à parler d'amour avec mes mots sur
scène. Parler d'amour a souvent été fait de façon romantique ou en montrant que
c'est dans le couple qu'il se réalise seulement. Je veux montrer qu'il est
partout autour de soi et en soi; qu'il est multiple et pas exclusif au couple. Je
veux manifester l'amour comme souffle de vie, et également comme motivation à
connaître l'autre à aimer l'autre comme soi-même.
Ma démarche philosophique se poursuit donc sur la
scène, avec humour et discernement. Être sur scène avec mes mots, et
accompagnée de ces comédiennes, me permet de dire, de vivre avec le public, mes
réflexions philosophiques sur l'amour. Mon art manifeste la vie et l'amour dans
des mots et des scènes à profondeur humaine.
Mon art est celui du monde tel que je le vois,
c'est-à-dire plein d'amour.
Résumé
de la pièce de théâtre "Femmoi l’Amour"
FEMMOI l’AMOUR est un spectacle de théâtre sur
l’amour, pour faire voir et pour faire aimer l’amour. L’amour commence par
soi-même. S’aimer comme on est, avec toutes nos oppositions, nos paradoxes.
Le spectacle partira d’un souper de filles. 9 filles
qui se réunissent une fois par mois pour se parler de leurs amours, de leur
vie, de leurs doutes et de leurs bons et moins bons coups. Puis, à partir de ce
souper, nous pourrons vivre la vie et l’amour du point de vue ou de la
perspective de chacune des filles. À travers ces sketchs nous vivrons l’amour
sous de multiples jours.
Nous appellerons les filles à partir du trait de
caractère qui leur correspond le plus : Paradoxale, Belle, Audacieuse,
Harmonie, Fifine, Ti-Coun, Prof, Grandiose et L’Étrange. 
Cette pièce s’adresse aux femmes et aux hommes
également; quel mari, chum, ami, père, frère, oncle, grand-père n’a pas rêvé de
savoir, de voir ce qui se passe dans un souper de filles ? Voilà votre chance !
Alors que les femmes s’y reconnaîtront, vous, messieurs, pourrez en apprendre
davantage sur les dames, un atout de plus pour des relations agréables au
quotidien..
Votre contribution, votre argent servira à produire une pièce de théâtre qui se donne comme mission de répandre l'amour dans le monde. Grâce à vous, l'amour pourra se manifester dans le coeur et dans le corps de tous. Car l'amour triomphe de tout !

BUDGET

2
000 $   Écriture ; coach et temps
12
250 $   Scénographie: metteure en scène, décors (conceptions, plan et fabrication), écriture des chansons, composition de la musique, enregistrement de la musique 
10 000$   Captation et postproduction vidéo dans la
pièce et vidéo et photos                      de la pièce (Cinéaste : filmer, monter/ Photographe ; prendre les photos, les arranger)
5
000$  Outils de promotion : billets, posters, cartes postales promotionnelles, programmes etc..

29 250$  TOTAL

Échéancier : Octobre 2015 à mars 2016
1er  Avril 2016
Christine Pageault concevra, avec Lucie Riffon, les costumes et elle les fabriquera : valeur $1000.00
P.S. Si nous amassons plus que notre objectif, nous l'investirons également dans la pièce.
La contrepartie la plus élevée, mais la meilleure et qui se nomme LA PRÉSENCE vous fera connaître toute l'équipe en personne. Qui sait, peut-être vous ferez-vous de nouvelles amies pour la vie.
Passez le mot ! Car vous contribuerez ainsi à la production d'une pièce qui parle d'amour et qui fera en sorte que chacun recevra sa dose d'amour !
De plus, vous pouvez toujours contribuer en faisant des activités de financement de votre côté. Dites-le moi et j'y serai c'est certain.

story:
Short Summary

As I said above, I have been an actor ever since I can remember.  I have performed in community theaters in Riverside and Chino, California and Missoula, Montana, as well as performing at Oxnard College in California.  I have been part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival since it started in 2010 as a member of the press, and have written hundreds of reviews of shows.  http://www.lamusiccritic.com/indie_voice_blog

Now it's my turn.  I have a great story to tell, and I need your help to bring it to the Hollywood Fringe Festival.  I have been so inspired attending and reviewing your stories, that I feel compelled to tell my own.

If you can help me, it will allow me to tell my story, as well as make me a better journalist because I will truly understand what it's like to be on the other side of the review.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need approximately $5,000 to cover the technical costs involved with mounting a show.  Those costs include the registration fee for the Festival, venue rental, hiring a tech person to run the multi-media, hiring a director, advertising costs and living expenses.  Since I live in Montana, I will need to pay for a place to live in Los Angeles for two months to allow for rehearsal, preview and Festival run.Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Perks include shout-outs on Facebook and Twitter and in the Indie Voice Blog, free tickets to the show, dinner and a show package, and an autographed copy of the script.  We may also throw in the chance to meet some of my celebrity friends (subject to availability).

The Impact

I have been supporting the indie music and theater community for many years.  It is my passion to support their art through published reviews, awards ceremonies and showcase opportunities.  If I am successful with this venture, then I will have more to contribute to others since I will truly have "walked a mile in their shoes."

Risks & Challenges

This is not going to be easy.  I am located in Montana and my creative team is in Los Angeles.  We will be doing our planning via Facebook and Skype and will not be able to be in the same room together until just a few weeks before the show goes up.  Despite that, I believe we can pull this off with your help, and bring my story to the Hollywood Fringe.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to contribute?  You can still help me by sharing my tweets and Facebook posts, and letting your friends know all about my project.  Indiegogo, Twitter and Facebook have great share tools, so please spread the word far and wide.

story:
Hello friends!

My name’s Hannah, I’m the Artistic Director of On The Run and I'm here to tell you a bit more about our Crowdfunder campaign and why we need your help.

But first, I want to say thank you for being here and reading our story - it really means a lot!

 

The Company

We’re a Lecoq-trained theatre company who have performed our work since 2014. Our first show, So It Goes, was an autobiographical show about my Dad, who died when I was seventeen. It premiered at the Edinburgh fringe in 2014 where it received wide critical acclaim (including a 5* review from The Times), a sell-out run and went on to tour internationally as part of the British Council Showcase 2015. 

The Show

Our new show ‘The Rebirth of Meadow Rain’ explores theme of emotional abuse and coercive control, something often misunderstood or difficult to define.  As a company, we are passionate about making work that deals with issues in society that are difficult to talk about. Our aim is to create an open and honest dialogue with the audience through comedy and storytelling. Meadow Rain is no different, and we’ve teamed up with UK SAYS NO MORE, a campaign to change the societal narrative towards domestic abuse, in order to help spread the change further.

 

How your money will help

Taking our show to the Edinburgh Fringe is fundamental for our show, firstly to reach new and diverse audiences, but also to reconnect with known audiences and venues across the UK. The Edinburgh Fringe is a rich platform for the future touring around the UK and internationally.  

Not only will your money help the company’s development immensely, but it will also help change the public understanding of domestic abuse to something that encapsulates non-violent abusive acts as a central and fundamental part of an abusive relationship. 

 

What will the money go towards?

The show’s been developing for two years and we’ve managed to cover the cost of making the show so far. We've had the good news (in the last 24 hours!), that we've received Arts Council Funding which will cover a portion of the budget!

Edinburgh is incredibly expensive however, and we still need your help to kickstart the final phase of the show’s development!

Our fundraising campaign today aims to raise £3000 towards the cost of Edinburgh. This money equates to around 1/4 of the full budget and will go towards:

  • marketing and press
  • accommodation
  • venue fees
  • travel expenses
  • Props and set

 

!!PERKS!!

We’ve got some fabulous perks available for you, as a small but heartfelt THANK YOU for your contribution. Some examples of perks below*:

  • A thank you post on social media
  • A personalised video thank you from meadow Rain
  • special content (videos, images, even a trailer…) if we meet targets
  • A free ticket to a preview in London or Edinburgh

Or, you can decide the exact amount you want to give to the company, by using the BACK IT button at the top right hand side of the page.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t worry if you can’t contribute funds today! There are many ways you can support our company and campaign:

  • Post about the campaign on social media and tagging @ontheruntheatre (use the share buttons on this page!)
  • tell a friend / family member / rich beneficiary
  • Tell someone about the show
  • Tell someone about UK SAYS NO MORE 
  • send us good vibes
  • give us hugs

 

Finally, a very big THANK YOU to you all for reading this, watching our video and to those who can contribute towards the fundraising. We really appreciate it and it will honestly help us no end!

Lots of love

Hannah xx

 

* List not exhaustive

story:
Two years ago and after a lot of effort, we managed to create a 'Greek Theatrical Group' of Nottingham. The effort was enormous because our team is mostly formed by amateur actors. However, with the right guidance and passion for the theatre, we succeeded last year in staging Aristophanes'  play ' The Wealth' and this year ' The last Black Cat' by Eugenios Trivizas. The last performance was a bigger success, as we prepared English subtitles (to reach not only a Greek-speaking audience), but have rented a small theatre for two-night shows.

After a lot of discussions, our group decided that some changes have to be done, in order to expand and create even more possibilities for self- development.

Therefore, the biggest change that needs to be done is the new venue for our rehearsals. Up till now, we were meeting once a week in different venues which were not fitting the purpose. Unfortunately, we do not have enough funds to afford  to rent a proper one.

To be able to develop our acting skills, and prepare the new performance we are in great need of a suitable place, where we can practice.

Our new play is going to be staged in June, and it is very important to us.

It touches the delicate nature of modern Greek history after the II WW. It combines the theme of the Civil War, the big wave of immigration from Greece to Germany, the personal feeling of being torn between the two countries/cultures and much more.

We are kindly asking for any donations/ support.

Our aim is to collect 2000£, to be able to pay for our rehearsal venue, and performance.

story:
Ballet for All-GDP (Global Dance Projects) 

www.balletforall-gdp.org

Dance and the Visual Arts fostering a deeper understanding of social issues and an appreciation of events, ideas and cultures.  

Art for art's sake. Art for the sake of us all.

As dance and visual artists we are able to craft and communicate a compelling vision of the world that can inform and transform the way we and others experience the world in ways that the written word often cannot.

Ballet for All-GDP [Global Dance Projects] will promote and present artistic collaborations among emerging and established choreographers, composers, designers, visual artists, and artist activists from around the world to bring global, truly multi-cultural programs and events to the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond. Please support our fundraising campaign on IndiGoGo - we can’t do this without your support. 

The San Francisco Bay Area 2016 debut of Ballet for All-GDP 

With your generous contributions we will be able to establish a presence in the vibrant dance and visual arts community of the San Francisco Bay Area with a broad program that will include educational programs, community outreach, free dance classes for the socioeconomically disadvantaged, dance composition workshops and collaborations among choreographers, teachers, visual artists and artist activists from the San Francisco Bay Area and around the world.

Novus Aurora 

“a new, natural electrical phenomenon”

12 dancers — four choreographers — six visual artists. 

A performance and visual arts event with emotional authenticity that shares  messages of hope with others struggling to find meaning, and the means, to bring our better selves forward to achieve sustainable goals of a peaceful, supportive, loving and compassionate world community.

We need $73,000 to pay 12 professional dancers for their time and commitment to a ten week rehearsal period at the San Francisco Dance Center / LINES.

With your donation you’ll be supporting:

Dancers, Choreographers and Visual Artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. We want our dancers to experience working with dance and visual artists from around the world — an experience almost always reserved for established professional ballet companies like San Francisco Ballet.

There are many ways in which you can help support us and our vision:

•Contribute and receive one of our awesome perks. 

•Put posters up in your community. Download and print our crowdfunding posters, and put them up in your local coffee shops, universities, colleges, schools, and elsewhere! Or we can send you five posters if you contact us at  steffon@balletforall-gdp.org

•Tell at least five of your friends about us and ask them to donate  — if 14,600 people each donate $5.00, we will have reached our $73,000 goal. If 3,650 people each donate $20 we will have reached out $73,000 goal. If one person donates $73,000 we will have reached our goal.

•If you have ideas about how we can reach more people, or have some creative fundraising ideas please share them with me at … steffon@balletforall-gdp.org

Ballet for All-GDP has no history — we are new, and we won’t be awarded a grant until we have found a way to establish a presence in the San Francisco Bay Area and in order to do so we need your help. We are reaching out to you and asking you to reach out to family, friends, dancers, dance makers, art lovers, artists and artist activists across the globe to help generate the $73,000 we desperately need.  There is no amount too small. Every dollar counts. Please spread the word! My sincere thanks, Steffon / Founding Artistic Director / Ballet for All-GDP

http://www.balletforall-gdp.org / / steffon@balletforall-gdp.org

About the Directors:

Steffon Long -  Founding Artistic Director 

I was a junior at the University of Massachusetts, Boston Campus, majoring in Psychology and Theatre Arts, when I saw Karen Kain and Rudolf Nureyev dance Sleeping Beauty with the National Ballet of Canada. I’d seen The Nutcracker several times as a child, but it didn’t affect me the way seeing Sleeping Beauty did. The day after that performance I enrolled in adult ballet classes at Boston Ballet. Three months later my teacher, Bob Steel, then a principal dancer with the company, advised me to quit school, move to NYC to study ballet full-time, and pursue a career as a professional ballet dancer. I followed his advice, and was awarded a full scholarship / Trainee position at the legendary Harkness Ballet House of Ballet Arts, (NYC) with Maria T. Vegh and the late David Howard.

My career as a ballet dancer was not remarkable, except for the fact that I was very fortunate to have had any kind of career at all considering how late I began dancing. I was an ordinary, well-trained, employable ballet dancer. I went on to dance corps de ballet, soloist and principal roles with San Francisco Ballet, Oakland Ballet (Oakland, CA), the National Ballet of Iran (Tehran, Iran), The Marin Ballet Company (San Rafael, CA), Classic Ballet of New Jersey, Irish National Ballet (Ireland), Ballet Classique de Paris (Paris, France) , Schindowski Ballet (Gelsenkirchen, Germany) and Stadtischen Bhunen Ballet (Dortmund, Germany).

Since 1985, when I retired from dancing, I have served as Dance Program Director at Stord Kulturskule and Stord Vidergaande Skule (Stord, Norway), and Artistic Director at Worcester School for the Performing Arts and Worcester Youth Ballet (Worcester, MA.), Redwood Empire Ballet School and Redwood Empire Ballet Company (Santa Rosa, CA), Yuma Ballet Theatre (Yuma, AZ), Pacifica Youth Ballet (Pacifica, CA) and Divertissement Dance Company (San Francisco, CA).

In addition, I have taught and choreographed for …

Ballet California, Maria Vegh Ballet Center, Black Hills Dance Theatre (Rapid City, South Dakota), Ballet Classico de Valencia (Valencia, Spain), Hoefgen Studios of Music and Dance (Dorsten, Germany),  Sanda Dance Company (London, UK), Classic Ballet of New Jersey, FLEX Studios, The Drill Hall, Ealing Dance Studios and Dance Works (London, UK),  Wladimir Studios  (Amsterdam, The Netherlands) and Stord Kulturskule and Stord Vidergaande Skule (Stord, Norway)

I have also been a guest teacher at ….

The Dance Center (Bergen, Norway), Ballet des Brandenburger Theater (Berlin, Germany), Tanztheater am Staatstheater (Cottbus, Germany),  Ballet der Stadtischen Bhunen (Hagen, Germany), The Dance Place  (Basel, Switzerland), and the Tanz Centrum in Amsterdam, The Netherlands.

In 1990 / 1991 I decided to further my dance education by attending Laban Centre for Movement and Dance (now it’s Trinity Laban   www.trinitylaban.ac.uk/ ) where I studied Movement Observation and Analysis and Dance Composition.

Maria Vegh - Artistic Advisor

Maria Vegh's career has been distinguished, long and varied. Initially arriving in New York in the early 50's with a vocal scholarship to Juilliard, she was introduced to ballet and came quickly to embrace it. Beginning at the unusually late age of eighteen, she moved rapidly through her training at the National Academy of Ballet and the Ballet Russe School while studying with such notable teachers as Pamela May, Thalia Mara, Mary Skeaping and Arthur Mahoney. After dancing with the Ballet Repertory Company of New York and, as a principal dancer, with the Royal Ponciana Theatre, she began her teaching career at the National Ballet of New York. Appointed a teacher at the then widely-acclaimed, pioneering New York City Harkness House for Ballet Arts in 1968, she became its co-director, with David Howard, in 1971. Moving to California in 1976 (following the closing of Harkness) to become Artistic Director of Marin Ballet, Ms. Vegh led that institution for more than a decade during its rapid accent to national prominence (detailed in a 1981 Dance Magazine feature article).

In 1993, she left Marin Ballet in order to establish the Maria Vegh Ballet Centre. Not a school in the usual sense (it offered virtually no classes), it provided the setting within which Ms. Vegh essentially worked with a small group of serious, promising intermediate and advanced ballet students who aspired to professional careers: individualized instruction and coaching, the identification and correction of technical issues, the development of strong, precise technique and musicality, and injury prevention.

Ms. Vegh has travelled widely across the U.S. and Peru and Japan as a master teacher and as a leader of teacher-training programs, in which she utilized her own syllabus, To Dance. She has been a guest-teacher at many universities and colleges, and ballet schools and companies; she is a member of Regional Dance America's Advisory Committee; she has recently produced a series of videotapes on the training of ballet students.

Devon Chen - Associate Director

Devon started developing her passion for dance at an early age with her first ballet classes. From there, she went on to study many different dance forms including modern, jazz and hip-hop and fell more in love with all that dance had to offer. She has performed with LV Dance Collective, Loose Change Dance Company, Jenni Bregman and Dancers, Vassar College Repertory Dance Theatre and FlyPeople - of which she was a Co-Founding member of the only student-run dance company at Vassar College. Furthermore, Devon has performed at the International Summer Dance Festival in Burgos, Spain, the San Francisco International Hip Hop Fest, City Dance Live on Stage, HeArt of Market, Bay Area National Dance Week and SAFEhouse Arts' Summer Performance Festival. 

Additionally, Devon received a B. A. in Biopsychology from Vassar College and went on to earn her Master’s and Doctorate in Physical Therapy from the University of California, San Francisco and San Francisco State University. She is also a certified Pilates Instructor and uses Pilates to assist in the rehabilitation of her patients. Currently, she practices physical therapy at the Center for Sports and Dance Medicine at Saint Francis Memorial Hospital in San Francisco, where she is a dance medicine specialist, as well as backstage for the casts and crew of touring Broadway shows such as the Book of Mormon and Porgy and Bess.
story_txt:
Ballet for All-GDP (Global Dance Projects) 
www.balletforall-gdp.org
Dance and the Visual Arts fostering a deeper understanding of social issues and an appreciation of events, ideas and cultures.  
Art for art's sake. Art for the sake of us all.
As dance and visual artists we are able to craft and communicate a compelling vision of the world that can inform and transform the way we and others experience the world in ways that the written word often cannot.Ballet for All-GDP [Global Dance Projects] will promote and present artistic collaborations among emerging and established choreographers, composers, designers, visual artists, and artist activists from around the world to bring global, truly multi-cultural programs and events to the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond. Please support our fundraising campaign on IndiGoGo - we can’t do this without your support. The San Francisco Bay Area 2016 debut of Ballet for All-GDP 


With your generous contributions we will be able to establish a presence in the vibrant dance and visual arts community of the San Francisco Bay Area with a broad program that will include educational programs, community outreach, free dance classes for the socioeconomically disadvantaged, dance composition workshops and collaborations among choreographers, teachers, visual artists and artist activists from the San Francisco Bay Area and around the world.
Novus Aurora 
“a new, natural electrical phenomenon”


12 dancers — four choreographers — six visual artists. 
A performance and visual arts event with emotional authenticity that shares  messages of hope with others struggling to find meaning, and the means, to bring our better selves forward to achieve sustainable goals of a peaceful, supportive, loving and compassionate world community.
We need $73,000 to pay 12 professional dancers for their time and commitment to a ten week rehearsal period at the San Francisco Dance Center / LINES.
With your donation you’ll be supporting:
Dancers, Choreographers and Visual Artists in the San Francisco Bay Area. We want our dancers to experience working with dance and visual artists from around the world — an experience almost always reserved for established professional ballet companies like San Francisco Ballet.
There are many ways in which you can help support us and our vision:
•Contribute and receive one of our awesome perks. 
•Put posters up in your community. Download and print our crowdfunding posters, and put them up in your local coffee shops, universities, colleges, schools, and elsewhere! Or we can send you five posters if you contact us at  steffon@balletforall-gdp.org
•Tell at least five of your friends about us and ask them to donate  — if 14,600 people each donate $5.00, we will have reached our $73,000 goal. If 3,650 people each donate $20 we will have reached out $73,000 goal. If one person donates $73,000 we will have reached our goal.
•If you have ideas about how we can reach more people, or have some creative fundraising ideas please share them with me at … steffon@balletforall-gdp.org
Ballet for All-GDP has no history — we are new, and we won’t be awarded a grant until we have found a way to establish a presence in the San Francisco Bay Area and in order to do so we need your help. We are reaching out to you and asking you to reach out to family, friends, dancers, dance makers, art lovers, artists and artist activists across the globe to help generate the $73,000 we desperately need.  There is no amount too small. Every dollar counts. Please spread the word! My sincere thanks, Steffon / Founding Artistic Director / Ballet for All-GDP
http://www.balletforall-gdp.org / / steffon@balletforall-gdp.orgAbout the Directors:
Steffon Long -  Founding Artistic Director 
I was a junior at the University of Massachusetts, Boston Campus, majoring in Psychology and Theatre Arts, when I saw Karen Kain and Rudolf Nureyev dance Sleeping Beauty with the National Ballet of Canada. I’d seen The Nutcracker several times as a child, but it didn’t affect me the way seeing Sleeping Beauty did. The day after that performance I enrolled in adult ballet classes at Boston Ballet. Three months later my teacher, Bob Steel, then a principal dancer with the company, advised me to quit school, move to NYC to study ballet full-time, and pursue a career as a professional ballet dancer. I followed his advice, and was awarded a full scholarship / Trainee position at the legendary Harkness Ballet House of Ballet Arts, (NYC) with Maria T. Vegh and the late David Howard.
My career as a ballet dancer was not remarkable, except for the fact that I was very fortunate to have had any kind of career at all considering how late I began dancing. I was an ordinary, well-trained, employable ballet dancer. I went on to dance corps de ballet, soloist and principal roles with San Francisco Ballet, Oakland Ballet (Oakland, CA), the National Ballet of Iran (Tehran, Iran), The Marin Ballet Company (San Rafael, CA), Classic Ballet of New Jersey, Irish National Ballet (Ireland), Ballet Classique de Paris (Paris, France) , Schindowski Ballet (Gelsenkirchen, Germany) and Stadtischen Bhunen Ballet (Dortmund, Germany).
Since 1985, when I retired from dancing, I have served as Dance Program Director at Stord Kulturskule and Stord Vidergaande Skule (Stord, Norway), and Artistic Director at Worcester School for the Performing Arts and Worcester Youth Ballet (Worcester, MA.), Redwood Empire Ballet School and Redwood Empire Ballet Company (Santa Rosa, CA), Yuma Ballet Theatre (Yuma, AZ), Pacifica Youth Ballet (Pacifica, CA) and Divertissement Dance Company (San Francisco, CA).
In addition, I have taught and choreographed for …
Ballet California, Maria Vegh Ballet Center, Black Hills Dance Theatre (Rapid City, South Dakota), Ballet Classico de Valencia (Valencia, Spain), Hoefgen Studios of Music and Dance (Dorsten, Germany),  Sanda Dance Company (London, UK), Classic Ballet of New Jersey, FLEX Studios, The Drill Hall, Ealing Dance Studios and Dance Works (London, UK),  Wladimir Studios  (Amsterdam, The Netherlands) and Stord Kulturskule and Stord Vidergaande Skule (Stord, Norway)
I have also been a guest teacher at ….
The Dance Center (Bergen, Norway), Ballet des Brandenburger Theater (Berlin, Germany), Tanztheater am Staatstheater (Cottbus, Germany),  Ballet der Stadtischen Bhunen (Hagen, Germany), The Dance Place  (Basel, Switzerland), and the Tanz Centrum in Amsterdam, The Netherlands.
In 1990 / 1991 I decided to further my dance education by attending Laban Centre for Movement and Dance (now it’s Trinity Laban   www.trinitylaban.ac.uk/ ) where I studied Movement Observation and Analysis and Dance Composition.
Maria Vegh - Artistic Advisor
Maria Vegh's career has been distinguished, long and varied. Initially arriving in New York in the early 50's with a vocal scholarship to Juilliard, she was introduced to ballet and came quickly to embrace it. Beginning at the unusually late age of eighteen, she moved rapidly through her training at the National Academy of Ballet and the Ballet Russe School while studying with such notable teachers as Pamela May, Thalia Mara, Mary Skeaping and Arthur Mahoney. After dancing with the Ballet Repertory Company of New York and, as a principal dancer, with the Royal Ponciana Theatre, she began her teaching career at the National Ballet of New York. Appointed a teacher at the then widely-acclaimed, pioneering New York City Harkness House for Ballet Arts in 1968, she became its co-director, with David Howard, in 1971. Moving to California in 1976 (following the closing of Harkness) to become Artistic Director of Marin Ballet, Ms. Vegh led that institution for more than a decade during its rapid accent to national prominence (detailed in a 1981 Dance Magazine feature article).
In 1993, she left Marin Ballet in order to establish the Maria Vegh Ballet Centre. Not a school in the usual sense (it offered virtually no classes), it provided the setting within which Ms. Vegh essentially worked with a small group of serious, promising intermediate and advanced ballet students who aspired to professional careers: individualized instruction and coaching, the identification and correction of technical issues, the development of strong, precise technique and musicality, and injury prevention.
Ms. Vegh has travelled widely across the U.S. and Peru and Japan as a master teacher and as a leader of teacher-training programs, in which she utilized her own syllabus, To Dance. She has been a guest-teacher at many universities and colleges, and ballet schools and companies; she is a member of Regional Dance America's Advisory Committee; she has recently produced a series of videotapes on the training of ballet students.
Devon Chen - Associate Director

Devon started developing her passion for dance at an early age with her first ballet classes. From there, she went on to study many different dance forms including modern, jazz and hip-hop and fell more in love with all that dance had to offer. She has performed with LV Dance Collective, Loose Change Dance Company, Jenni Bregman and Dancers, Vassar College Repertory Dance Theatre and FlyPeople - of which she was a Co-Founding member of the only student-run dance company at Vassar College. Furthermore, Devon has performed at the International Summer Dance Festival in Burgos, Spain, the San Francisco International Hip Hop Fest, City Dance Live on Stage, HeArt of Market, Bay Area National Dance Week and SAFEhouse Arts' Summer Performance Festival. Additionally, Devon received a B. A. in Biopsychology from Vassar College and went on to earn her Master’s and Doctorate in Physical Therapy from the University of California, San Francisco and San Francisco State University. She is also a certified Pilates Instructor and uses Pilates to assist in the rehabilitation of her patients. Currently, she practices physical therapy at the Center for Sports and Dance Medicine at Saint Francis Memorial Hospital in San Francisco, where she is a dance medicine specialist, as well as backstage for the casts and crew of touring Broadway shows such as the Book of Mormon and Porgy and Bess.

story:
Guy is a fat, gay millennial looking for love…Guy is equal parts brilliant and shy…Guy feels like he doesn’t fit in to the gay community, so immerses himself in his work and the world of gaming.

When a romantic rejection pushes Guy to make terrible life choices, it forces him to confront his inner demons, all the while pushing away everyone close to him. A journey through bingeing, gyming, prejudice, hook-ups, beauty standards, and (spoiler alert) stolen identity, GUY shows you that the only person you can be is yourself.

  

GUY is an unconventional, life-affirming story of modern masculinity told through the lens of the experiences of several complex and flawed gay men. It also shows that dating apps aren't just hot white people having 24-hour sex. Every one of us has a real-life rollercoaster story to tell about apps, like Tinder and Grindr, that spans sexuality, race, body image, and personality type. 

GUY is the story of millennial love that will leave you proud, empowered, and a little bit in love; there's a little bit of GUY in everyone.

GUY runs at the King's Head Theatre for 6 shows from August  28 - September 1
 

 

WHO

  • A dynamite cast, with Brendan Matthew, Adam Braidley, Steve Banks, and Seann Miley Moore.​
  • Written by fast-rising writing duo Stephen Hyde and Leoe Mercer, the team behind The Marriage of Kim K

 

​The Cast: Adam, Brendan, Seann and Steve

GUY | Brendan Matthew

Brendan is not only an actor and singer, but also a director and choreographer. He went to Brit School and studied at the Royal Academy of Music with world-renowned vocal coach Mary Hammond. As an performer, he has been involved in the Olivier Award winning 'La Boheme', and has played Marvin Shellhammer in the No. 1 UK Tour of 'Miracle on 34th Street' and Dr Von Whackoff in the 20th Anniversary Production of 'Saucy Jack and The Space Vixens'. He is also part of the group Gregorian. He says "It's my aim to make everyone identify and fall in love with Guy by the end of the show" - so get ready!

AZIZ | Seann Miley Moore 

Seann was an X-Factor finalist and fan-favourite in 2015. Since then, he's recorded his own stunning EP, toured the UK Pride circuit, walked London Fashion Week and generally being a 'Slayzian Popstar in Platforms'- and now he's returning to his roots in musical theatre (he studied at Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts)!

TYLER | Steve Banks

Steve Banks's theatre background is straight acting (the irony). Having come top of the class in his acting degree, Steve has performed internationally, including at the National Theatre in Croatia. He is a fantastic a vers(atile) character actor, having played roles from Satan to Jesus, with a dash of Prince Charming thrown in. He's also partial to masking, dancing, puppetry and clowning... whether these make it into GUY remains to be seen. 

DOM | Adam Braidley

After graduating from Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts, Adam has had a string of roles in productions around the UK. While a regular actor for short films, and a lead vocalist, musical theatre is his passion. He's also able to tap dance and can auctioneer professionally - not quite the stereotypical gym-shark jock he's playing in GUY. We asked him if he has any awkward online dating experiences, and he said no - so we'll definitely be asking him for some tips!

 

The Writers: leoe&hyde

GUY is our third musical. Our first, Queueue, was about millennial internet addiction. Our second, The Marriage of Kim K, was a multi-historical mash-up of pop and classical culture. GUY is a simple love story. 

Except there's a twist. It touches on lots of important issues of today: body image, life online, race, masculinity, and that there is no one way to be either gay or a man in the 21st century. 

With catchy pop/electronic music, GUY sounds like Sam Smith meets Stranger Things, or Years and Years meets Rent. 

 
 

 

Why are we doing a Kickstarter?

Musicals aren’t cheap

  • Fair Pay for Creatives: We are committed to paying the cast and creatives Equity rates.
  • Venue Hire for performances: We need somewhere to do the show
  • Marketing: We have to let people know about the show somehow
  • Equipment: You can't imagine the number of batteries we go through
  • Props: Our drag queen wig is looking a bit worse for wear
  • Insurance : We have to be responsible adults

We are going into this production assuming it will cost us money, not that we will make money from it, which is a precarious position to be in. For us, it's worth the risk to put on this much-needed show, but we'd rather not live on a knife edge and have to rely on support in-kind. 

Can You Trust Us? 

  • Our first run of GUY has had great reviews and has impacted many people who have seen it, and has just one its first award for 'Best New Writing' at Buxton Fringe Festival and 'Best Show' at Birmingham Fest. 
  • Our first professional show, The Marriage of Kim K, was a huge success, received rave reviews, multiple awards and international attention from the likes of Sky News, USA Today, The Guardian and the Sunday Times. It's currently being prepared for a new production and its Australian premiere in 2019.
  • Our team have the support of the Stage One Bursary for training as a theatre producer.
  • We are working with Equity UK to ensure our team are treated and paid fairly.

For more information about leoe&hyde, you can find us on Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, Soundcloud, or just check out our website.

Risks & Challenges

Check-list:

✓ Write the script. 
✓ Compose the music. 
✓ Build a team. 
✓ Find a cast. 
✓ Book dates. 
✓ Launch websites and social media. 
✘ Raise some money.

Every donations helps us break even and ease financial pressure… but above all, it feels wonderful to have a community of people behind us who believe in what we are doing.

Can You Trust Us? 

Our first run of GUY has had great reviews and has impacted many people who have seen it, and has just one its first award for 'Best New Writing' at Buxton Fringe Festival and 'Best Show' at Birmingham Fest. 
Our first professional show, The Marriage of Kim K, was a huge success, received rave reviews, multiple awards and international attention from the likes of Sky News, USA Today, The Guardian and the Sunday Times. It's currently being prepared for a new production and its Australian premiere in 2019.

Our team have the support of the Stage One Bursary for training as a theatre producer.
We are working with Equity UK to ensure our team are treated and paid fairly.

story:
Funding Breakdown

Raised funds will be used to support:

  • payment for rental of TheaterLab NY - $6,000 for a 3-week run
  • hiring a publicity agent - $2,000

Who We Are: 

Eilin O'Dea founded Fusion Theatre in 2016 with the vision of merging the two foundational spheres of performance art: classical theatre and opera. Fusion Theatre draws on a select, exclusive pool of classically trained actors who are also trained opera singers in their unique and groundbreaking merging of these two great art forms. We believe that the spoken word can always be enhanced by music and offer audiences the very best of both creative traditions in what has been described by critics as "the ultimate theatrical experience".

Critical Acclaim:

In May of 2017, our production of Antigone rose to critical acclaim:

"The staging strips drama to bare truth...eschews theatricality and gives us a direct honesty"--Steve Capra of The New York Theater Blog

"Here’s an amazing experience!"-- Yvonne Korshak of Let's Talk Off Broadway

"The concept is intriguing"--R. Pikser of Theaterscene.com

"Fusion Theatre brings Antigone to life like never before through their unique blend of dialogue and classic opera."--Erin Kahn of Stagebuddy.com

Moving Forward:

Our next project will be the seminal play "No Exit" by Jean Paul Sartre. The dual trained cast will enhance Sartre's brilliant text by adding arias and chorus relevant to specific moments in the play to heighten dramatic tension. 

We Need You! 

At Fusion Theater we believe we offer something that the worlds of neither theater nor opera have ever seen before. With your help, we can bridge the gap between theater and opera. We believe that we make opera more accessible to theater lovers and theater more accessible to opera lovers.
We performed Antigone on a shoestring budget and received universal critical acclaim but we cannot proceed without some financial assistance. We believe in the arts in their purest forms and strive for excellence. We are so thankful for any assistance as well as spreading the word.

​

story:
Short Summary

LE JUICE is funding for its summer tour of our inaugural show, S/he/it Happens. So far we're performing in London, Birmingham and Manchester, with plans to spread our wings in September.   

S/he/it Happens is a one-woman gender-messing clown show exploring the violence of assimilation through slapstick, wit, and some surprising new friends. A curious clown is stuck between the gender binary. Armed with not much more than a pair of boxers, they set out on a violently hilarious attempt to fit, one way or another. Is it really rewriting the rules if you haven't read the rulebook?

We make clowning with bite; politically charged, yet highly personal comedy. We believe in self-love and self-mockery, and want you to come join in. As a brand new, graduate company, we need your help in finding our feet and developing our work for a larger audience. Our plan this summer is to test new material on new audiences, touring smaller fringes as the next step to larger plans. However, we cannot do this on our own; as such a tiny company, micro funding is hard to come by, and as two students, we lack the start up capital.  

Who we are​

Le Juice serves a fresh box of concentrated clowning comedy, sucking up the hard stuff. Artist - Miranda Porter. Producer - Livi Dunlop.

Livi and Miranda met each other in the distant days of 6th form college, down in the depths of Hampshire. 

Miranda is a soon-to-be graduate of European Theatre Arts at Rose Bruford College. She has studied clowning under Gaulier in France, as well as in Spain, Poland, and Finland. This is her first solo project. Full bio and CV - http://www.mirandaporter.co.uk
 

Livi Dunlop is a theatremaker based in Winchester and Oxford. Their work can be found at lividunlop.com.

Graphics by Amber Beardow.

What We Need & What You Get

We feel it is crucial to pay any collaborators for their work - your money will cover our artist's fees for graphics, as well as all our print marketing costs. Additionally, it will cover the company's transport to and from Manchester, all props and costumes, music licensing, insurance, and our festival registration fees, all of which add up, as well as covering our venue hire fees for one city. Any extra we raise above our target will go towards paying for September venues - we've applied to Oxford's Old Fire Station (a wonderful venue which you should check out regardless), which costs three times our Manchester venue per night. We are also including 10% to cover Indiegogo's fees and handling charges.

In return we've set up some fun rewards in the spirit of the occasion, and we are always willing to chat, chuckle, and share our enthusiasm. Plus, y'know, you could always come see the show..

 

The Impact

This is, for both of us, our first independent professional project. It is a chance to start something amazing, and share happiness and mischief across the country, as well as being a first step towards a viable career in the arts. Your support is invaluable, and we are so grateful for any aid you are able to give us towards developing our work and practise.

Risks & Challenges

As with any artistic endeavour, there is always a risk of losing money. Between now and the production our aim is to sell tickets - we've kept our venues small so as to both keep our costs down, and aim for full houses. Livi has worked on touring productions before, with the venues we are travelling to, and with your help, we hope to break even over this summer.

Other Ways You Can Help

As students with student friends, we understand financial help is not possible for everyone. But please, share this fundraiser, follow us on Twitter and Facebook (@lejuicetheatre), and maybe even come see the show if we're near you - it all is valuable. Or if you know anywhere that may want to host us, drop us a message! Livi's email is livimdunlop[at]gmail[dot]com. Thank you xx

Graphics by Amber Beardow.
What We Need & What You Get
We feel it is crucial to pay any collaborators for their work - your money will cover our artist's fees for graphics, as well as all our print marketing costs. Additionally, it will cover the company's transport to and from Manchester, all props and costumes, music licensing, insurance, and our festival registration fees, all of which add up, as well as covering our venue hire fees for one city. Any extra we raise above our target will go towards paying for September venues - we've applied to Oxford's Old Fire Station (a wonderful venue which you should check out regardless), which costs three times our Manchester venue per night. We are also including 10% to cover Indiegogo's fees and handling charges.
In return we've set up some fun rewards in the spirit of the occasion, and we are always willing to chat, chuckle, and share our enthusiasm. Plus, y'know, you could always come see the show..
 

The Impact
This is, for both of us, our first independent professional project. It is a chance to start something amazing, and share happiness and mischief across the country, as well as being a first step towards a viable career in the arts. Your support is invaluable, and we are so grateful for any aid you are able to give us towards developing our work and practise.

Risks & Challenges
As with any artistic endeavour, there is always a risk of losing money. Between now and the production our aim is to sell tickets - we've kept our venues small so as to both keep our costs down, and aim for full houses. Livi has worked on touring productions before, with the venues we are travelling to, and with your help, we hope to break even over this summer.

Other Ways You Can Help
As students with student friends, we understand financial help is not possible for everyone. But please, share this fundraiser, follow us on Twitter and Facebook (@lejuicetheatre), and maybe even come see the show if we're near you - it all is valuable. Or if you know anywhere that may want to host us, drop us a message! Livi's email is livimdunlop[at]gmail[dot]com. Thank you xx

story:
Founded in 2017, FIMIIDO was created as a way to bridge the gap between training and the professional world. FIMIIDO stands for the belief that big things can stem from trying something new, and exploring aspects of theatre that we never knew we could love. 

Based in Montreal, we strive to explore different aspects of theatre. Created entirely by theatre students, the company is dedicated to support emerging artist and give them a platform to express their artistic creativity. FIMIIDO strives to push the boundaries for those just starting out in the professional field, giving people a platform to dive head first into the creative process, both on the acting and the technical side.

Donor support allows our artistic community to thrive. We here at FIMIIDO believe that Theatre is a pivotal part of our community. With your help, we can continue to support emerging artist in both the acting and the technical field. With the funds we would be able to bring this production to the next level. The money will go to props, sets, costumes and transportation.

story:
Short Summary

A Hitchcock/Tarantino-esque comedy with guns, lovers and a Broadway starlet.

It’s not the best birthday for Broadway star Blaze O’Hara. She is the unwitting hypotenuse of a love triangle with her boyfriend, aspiring writer Jimmy Poole and her landlord, Mafia Don Harry Verona. She can keep Harry’s heart and hands at bay until the gun goes off and Harry is shot. With his mother due any minute to meet her, Blaze needs quick thinking and even quicker action.

Being a milestone birthday, Blaze begins to evaluate her life, love and career. Mortal danger will do that to a girl. She quickly realises that men have been forcing their desires and decisions on her for too long and it’s time to take back control. Not just to save her life, but to face her fears, literally, because The Trouble With Harry is that he’s hanging from a Rope by the Rear Window; and his mother’s due any minute for coffee.

What We Need & What You Get

For the West End we need a full blown set - bathroom and living room and a van to get everything to and from the theatre in one day/night.

We need £4,000.

The Impact

While tickets are available to the public, it is an industry showcase for producers who may wish to take the show on for a proper West End and/or Broadway run. We are trying to build sustainable careers for extraordinary actors and this is the second step towards that promise. 

The best chance we have of showcasing their talent is for a first rate West End production on the night. We have the same cast as Edinburgh except for the role of Blaze which is now being played by the supremely talented Rachael Sparkes. 

We also need your laughter so, if you can come, please do and please laugh uproariously - https://lwtheatres.co.uk/whats-on/the-man-from-... 

Risks & Challenges

The show will go on. There is no risk to your investment.

The only challenge is that we don't sell out, don't get the laughs and don't showcase ourselves in the best light.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and encourage your friends and family to come. Your enjoyment at the show is as valuable to us as money. You are worth more than your currency. You are the currency. As ever, thank you again for your support.

story:
Connecting.  Coaching.  Creating.

The Young Choreographers Project is about connecting, coaching, and creating.  Beginning in February 2015, we started this project by connecting young aspiring dancers from the inner-city of Los Angeles with professional dance mentors.  Students worked closely with dance professionals over a 6-week period to create original dance pieces that were showcased on March 22nd, 2015.   What we have found is that this process of creating through the art of choreography provided each student with an incresed sense of confidence and self-esteem, and gave them ability to truly express themselves through movement.   In addition, our students learned how to be leaders and to effectively communicate their thoughts and ideas to their peers.

We have already been able to touch the lives of over 30 students, and we would love to expand this opportunity to more communities in the Los Angeles area.  We need YOUR support to make this happen.

What Your Donation will Provide

  • Mentoring Program (Studio/rehearsal space and supplies):  35%
  • Showcase Expenses (Venue rental, insurance, costumes, etc.): 40%
  • Advertising/Marketing:  10%
  • Contributor Perks:  10%
  • Indiegogo Fees: 5%

The Impact

Students who have participated in this project have said that they walked away from the experience feeling more confident and loved the opportunity to express themselves artistically.  Learning the art of choreography gave them more insight into dance as an art form and provided them with more knowledge to take with them to dance class.

Socialization Benefits:  According to "FamilyTalk Magazine," dance education can help students improve their social and communication skills, learn how to work as part of a team, and develop a greater sense of trust and cooperation and make new friends.


Educational Benefits:  Becoming a skilled dancer requires practice, discipline and focus, skills that can be useful in other areas of a child's life. "FamilyTalk Magazine" estimates that students who have a background in dance tend to achieve significantly higher SAT scores and do better in math and science competitions.

Improved Self-Esteem:  As children adjust to the movements and postures required in dance, they begin to get a better sense of their bodies. As they become more comfortable in their own skin, their confidence and self-esteem also improve. According to EduDance, dance lessons can encourage children to foster a more positive attitude and explore their own self-expression. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but would still like to help out, please let others know about our campaign by telling your friends and getting the word out on social media.  And like us on Facebook!

story:
Who are S+K?

The S+K Project (S+K) is a theatre and performing arts company with the objective to make the arts for everyone. We are Resident Company at Bernie Grant Arts Centre, a community arts centre in Tottenham, North London, and have been Associate Artists with Talawa Theatre Company since January 2018. 

Since we launched in September 2014, we have gone on to write, direct and produce almost a dozen productions, with a focus on pushing the boundaries of the form of theatre as well as producing meaningful participatory projects.

Outside of our theatre and artist development work, we produce talks, networking and performance events, as well as an annual festival which aims to bring together marginalised voices in society, allowing them to express themselves through the vehicle of the arts.

With your help, we can continue to be the link for ambitious people of all backgrounds to develop their interest in the arts and related areas by delivering affordable, interdisciplinary, multifaceted work in professional environments. This is your chance to help make the arts for everyone.

 

Our Needs, Your Gains

For the past 4 years, the S+K Project has existed without any funding from public bodies, trusts or foundations. Instead, we have funded ourselves by delivering talks, workshops and events across London and beyond. The company is now in a crucial stage of development as we look towards long-term, UK-wide support for emerging artists. In order to keep our events affordable for everyone, we need support from you to contribute to the costs of running the organisation.

We are hoping to raise £5,000 in just over three months.

Your money will go towards the fees of core staff who plan and deliver our radical and accessible programme of work, including our innovative artist development programme - Scratch That, our national networking event for artists of colour - Bring Me In, our national networking events for artists of colour, and to manage our ever-growing participatory work with young people from all backgrounds.

To say thanks for your support, we’re throwing a fundraiser like no other. As part of our commitment to showcasing emerging artists from all walks of life, we’ve asked some friends old and new to come through and do their ting! Including live performances from Latir, Chelle OT (+ more TBA), an installation by our very own Rumi Woolf (VOID is touring the UK Autumn 2019), a staged reading of Virtue by stand-up and playwright Stella Ajayi (directed by Robert Awosusi), a DJ set from Hana Raage and so much more, you do not want to miss this end-of-year link up.

Support from you can come in a range of forms with pledge perks ranging from £5 to £1,000. These include tickets to the fundraiser, glasses of champagne, workshops, free tickets, dramaturgical support and lots, lots more. 

 

The Impact

The S+K Project will always be fully committed to developing emerging/early career artists and enabling them to create high quality work through our projects, and your support at this crucial point will allow our work to continue to grow and thrive.

Without you, our outreach and participation work across London – as well as the internships we provide for under 25s that equip young people with the practical and artistic skills to pursue careers in the arts – may not be able to continue due to the increasingly competitive funding environment in the arts. Very few artist collectives and companies operate like we do; we are driven by working with a wide group of thoughtful and enthusiastic people who want to be involved in an aspect of performing arts that they were not necessarily able to access before.

Since our inception, we have partnered with a range of organisations – from youth centres and arts clubs, to theatres like Battersea Arts Centre and internationally operating charities like LIFT – in order to provide opportunities to people who are not well represented in the performing arts industry. With a combined reach of over 7,500 people with all of our work through live events, and hundreds of thousands digitally, individuals we have developed have gone on to work with the likes of the Royal Court, Frantic Assembly, Contact Theatre, Tamasha and The National. 

 

Can’t donate but still want to help?

We get it, cash can be tight sometimes, but there are still lots of ways that you can help us on this journey! Please like, share, retweet, comment, subscribe - any of the above, really - to content on The S+K Project socials. Raise awareness with people you know who you think are interested in supporting us. Every person who spreads the word is helping the cause in a huge way.

story:
Hi! My name is Meg. I'm an artist, drag queen, drag mother, and overall lover of everything glamorous. 

A year ago, I created a show called It's Not Personal, It's Drag as my senior project to close out my theatre degree. The show was a hit, taught tons of people about drag and the gay community, and left everyone feeling fierce. This year, I'm bringing the show back, and better than ever! The only thing is...we need your help. Before, the tech aspects were available to me, but this time, all of it is coming out of my pocket. Any help you can give, even if it's just $1, will mean the world to us and make an impact on the success of the show. My goals for this year?

- Reach out and market to audiences beyond the immediate gay community

- Teach audiences about drag and constructs of gender 

- Inspire audience members to go out and see more local drag

What We Need & What You Get

  • With the registration fee, light rental, sound rental, materials to transform the space we're in, posters/marketing materials and decorations, the costs come to roughly $750. As an individual paying for it solo, I could really use some help so I really can get all of the materials I need and make these queens look and sound stellar. 
  • If you donate $5, you'll get your very own signed poster from all of the queens! 
  • If you donate $10, you'll get a reserved seat in our front row VIP section, a signed poster, and a free Mocktail. 

The Impact

Drag is beautiful, drag is grungy, drag is campy, drag is controversial, but most importantly- drag is powerful. I want to bring that power to the Jersey Fringe, because this world needs drag. It’s Not Personal, It’s Drag will deliver you all of the charisma, uniqueness, nerve and talent that you need for the rest of the year. The goal is to “wear crowns, fuck with gender, bend the rules, don’t surrender” (in the words of Sasha Velour, season nine winner of Rupaul’s Drag Race) and ultimately entice audiences to get out to see and support local drag, because the art form supports us all.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're broke like I am, you can help by sharing this campaign and spreading the word! Also, get your tickets to the festival at https://theeagletheatre.secure.force.com/ticket...

story:
Stressé politiquement? Offre-toi une balle et aide à faire naître la nouvelle création de Nicole!

Nicole démarre sa nouvelle création «File Philomèle»: un cirque-théâtre tragique et multimédia inspiré des Métamorphoses d’Ovide (Fable Prognée et Philomèle) qui traite de la passion destructrice d’un homme puissant, de la perte de liberté et de l'agression d’une femme, de sa reprise de parole. Elle offre à ses donateurs pour les remercier, la chance de déformer la tête de notre voisin orangé à toutes les heures de la journée!

 

THE PROJECT

"File Philomèle" (Title play on words, means both “Dash Philomèle” and “Spins Philomèle”) is the new and second creation of the TON (Theater of the obnubiles of Nicole- ad lib| www.leton.ca), a Montreal multidisciplinary production company founded in 2012 that is particularly interested in what induces people, brings together a people and raises it. Le TON presented its first production, "City" in opening of the season 2014-2015 of the Prospero Theater in Montreal.

"File Philomèle" is a mythological narrative with Greek inspirations, with Roman colors, but with a very contemporary resonance that tells the destructive passion of a powerful man, the loss of freedom of a woman, an infanticide, the anger of a wife and a sister, the resumption of victim's speech.

Timeless, this fable has evolved into a silent tragedy where music, choral effects, dance, circus and theater build sounds and visual atmospheres that contribute to bringing to life the emotions felt by the characters without the speech.

This work leaves plenty of room for interpreters' appropriation work and links Greek mythological culture, the excesses and violence of ancient Rome with the visual, technological and scenic possibilities of contemporary Québec.

1. Give yourself a gift

2. Finance a good show

3. Deform the face of Donald at any time of the day!

 

LE PROJET

«File Philomèle» est la nouvelle et seconde création du TON (Le Théâtre des obnubilés de Nicole| www.leton.ca), une compagnie de productions multidisciplinaires montréalaise fondée en 2013 qui s’intéresse particulièrement à ce qui induit force aux individus, les réunit en un peuple et le soulève. Elle a présenté sa première production, «City» en ouverture de la saison 2014-2015 du Théâtre Prospero à Montréal.

«File Philomèle» est un récit un mythologique aux inspirations grecques, aux couleurs romaines, mais à résonance bien contemporaine qui raconte la passion destructrice d’un homme puissant, de la perte de liberté d’une femme, d’un infanticide, de la colère d’une épouse et d’une sœur, de la reprise de parole de victimes.

Intemporelle, cette fable s’est muée en tragédie muette où la musique, les effets de chœur, la danse, le cirque et le théâtre construisent des ambiances sonores et visuelles concourant à faire vivre aux spectateurs les émotions ressenties par les personnages sans le biais de la parole.

Érigée en tableaux, cette pièce laisse une grande place au travail d’appropriation des interprètes et tente un lien entre la culture mythologique grecque, la démesure et la violence de la Rome antique et les possibilités scéniques, visuelles et technologiques du Québec contemporain.

1. Gâte-toi

2. Finance un bon show                              

3. Déforme la face de Donald à toute heure de la journée!

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

A multimedia circus-theater is very expensive to produce, even more so for a young company! As speechless production, international exporting becomes possible and ensures future profitability and reduces financial risk ... but in the long run, but not in the short term! Either during production and what we need to finance.

To have access to Canadian grants, a cultural organization must have produced two shows. “File Philomèle” being our second creation, we will have access to it from the next! That's why we need your help today. You always dreamed of being a producer? Here's your chance! ;)

The biggest risk being the time to invest by the interpreters and designers, difficult to estimate perfectly, particularly with regard to the following:

- Original Music

- Architectural and solid scenography (interpreters must climb and cling to it)

-Repeat time with performers and choreographers to bring the creation to a quality of presentation (a creative constantly refine, even when it is displayed)

The crowdfunding campaign will allow us to raise the rest of the funds needed for production and distribution, but above all, to start with the interpreters, composers and designers!

LES RISQUES ET DÉFIS   

Un cirque-théâtre multimédia coûte très cher à produire, qui plus est pour une jeune compagnie! Comme il s’agit d’une production sans parole, l’exportation internationale devient possible et assure une rentabilité future et diminue le risque financier… mais à long terme, pas à court terme! Soit lors de la production et ce qu’il nous faut financer.

Pour avoir accès aux subventions canadiennes, un organisme culturel doit avoir produit deux spectacles. File Philomèle étant notre seconde création, nous y aurons accès dès la prochaine! Voilà ce qui explique pourquoi nous avons besoin de ton aide aujourd’hui. Tu as toujours rêvé d’être producteur? Voici ta chance! ;)

Le plus grand risque étant le temps à investir par les interprètes et concepteurs, difficile à estimer à la perfection, particulièrement au niveau des éléments suivants :

-Musique originale

-Scénographie architecturale et solide (les interprètes doivent grimper et s’y attacher)

-Temps de répétition avec les interprètes et chorégraphes pour amener la création à une qualité de présentation (une création se peaufinant constamment, même lorsqu’elle est à l’affiche) 

La campagne de socio-financement nous permettra de lever le reste des fonds nécessaires à la production et à la diffusion, mais surtout, de la débuter avec les interprètes, compositeurs et concepteurs!

 

QUESTIONS

Nicole, TON, wtf? www.leton.ca

Ovid, who’s that guy? Metamorphoses ...

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphoses

(You will find the fable "Prognée and Philomèle" in Book VI!)

Do not hesitate to contact Nicole for any other questions! :)

By commenting on this page, or by writing an email to info@nicolepresente.ca

 

LES QUESTIONS

Nicole, Le TON, de kessé? www.leton.ca

Ovide, c’est qui lui? Les Métamorphoses…

https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Métamorphoses_(Ovide)

(Tu trouveras la fable «Prognée et Philomèle» dans le livre VI!)

N'hésite pas à contacter Nicole pour tout autre question! :) 

En commentant sur cette page ou en écrivant à info@nicolepresente.ca

 

Can not you help us financially? Share the campaign with your family and friends! It helps us just as much, if not more! Nicole thanks you for your support and wishes you welcome to the team!

Tu ne peux pas nous aider financièrement? Partage la campagne avec ta famille et tes amis! Cela nous aide tout autant, sinon plus! Nicole te remercie pour ton soutient et te souhaite bienvenu dans l'équipe!
story_txt: Stressé politiquement? Offre-toi une balle et aide à faire naître la nouvelle création de Nicole!Nicole démarre sa nouvelle création «File Philomèle»: un cirque-théâtre tragique et multimédia inspiré des Métamorphoses d’Ovide (Fable Prognée et Philomèle) qui traite de la passion destructrice d’un homme puissant, de la perte de liberté et de l'agression d’une femme, de sa reprise de parole. Elle offre à ses donateurs pour les remercier, la chance de déformer la tête de notre voisin orangé à toutes les heures de la journée! THE PROJECT"File Philomèle" (Title play on words, means both “Dash Philomèle” and “Spins Philomèle”) is the new and second creation of the TON (Theater of the obnubiles of Nicole- ad lib| www.leton.ca), a Montreal multidisciplinary production company founded in 2012 that is particularly interested in what induces people, brings together a people and raises it. Le TON presented its first production, "City" in opening of the season 2014-2015 of the Prospero Theater in Montreal."File Philomèle" is a mythological narrative with Greek inspirations, with Roman colors, but with a very contemporary resonance that tells the destructive passion of a powerful man, the loss of freedom of a woman, an infanticide, the anger of a wife and a sister, the resumption of victim's speech.Timeless, this fable has evolved into a silent tragedy where music, choral effects, dance, circus and theater build sounds and visual atmospheres that contribute to bringing to life the emotions felt by the characters without the speech.This work leaves plenty of room for interpreters' appropriation work and links Greek mythological culture, the excesses and violence of ancient Rome with the visual, technological and scenic possibilities of contemporary Québec.1. Give yourself a gift2. Finance a good show3. Deform the face of Donald at any time of the day! LE PROJET«File Philomèle» est la nouvelle et seconde création du TON (Le Théâtre des obnubilés de Nicole| www.leton.ca), une compagnie de productions multidisciplinaires montréalaise fondée en 2013 qui s’intéresse particulièrement à ce qui induit force aux individus, les réunit en un peuple et le soulève. Elle a présenté sa première production, «City» en ouverture de la saison 2014-2015 du Théâtre Prospero à Montréal.«File Philomèle» est un récit un mythologique aux inspirations grecques, aux couleurs romaines, mais à résonance bien contemporaine qui raconte la passion destructrice d’un homme puissant, de la perte de liberté d’une femme, d’un infanticide, de la colère d’une épouse et d’une sœur, de la reprise de parole de victimes.Intemporelle, cette fable s’est muée en tragédie muette où la musique, les effets de chœur, la danse, le cirque et le théâtre construisent des ambiances sonores et visuelles concourant à faire vivre aux spectateurs les émotions ressenties par les personnages sans le biais de la parole.Érigée en tableaux, cette pièce laisse une grande place au travail d’appropriation des interprètes et tente un lien entre la culture mythologique grecque, la démesure et la violence de la Rome antique et les possibilités scéniques, visuelles et technologiques du Québec contemporain.1. Gâte-toi2. Finance un bon show                              3. Déforme la face de Donald à toute heure de la journée! RISKS AND CHALLENGESA multimedia circus-theater is very expensive to produce, even more so for a young company! As speechless production, international exporting becomes possible and ensures future profitability and reduces financial risk ... but in the long run, but not in the short term! Either during production and what we need to finance.To have access to Canadian grants, a cultural organization must have produced two shows. “File Philomèle” being our second creation, we will have access to it from the next! That's why we need your help today. You always dreamed of being a producer? Here's your chance! ;)The biggest risk being the time to invest by the interpreters and designers, difficult to estimate perfectly, particularly with regard to the following:- Original Music- Architectural and solid scenography (interpreters must climb and cling to it)-Repeat time with performers and choreographers to bring the creation to a quality of presentation (a creative constantly refine, even when it is displayed)The crowdfunding campaign will allow us to raise the rest of the funds needed for production and distribution, but above all, to start with the interpreters, composers and designers!LES RISQUES ET DÉFIS   Un cirque-théâtre multimédia coûte très cher à produire, qui plus est pour une jeune compagnie! Comme il s’agit d’une production sans parole, l’exportation internationale devient possible et assure une rentabilité future et diminue le risque financier… mais à long terme, pas à court terme! Soit lors de la production et ce qu’il nous faut financer.Pour avoir accès aux subventions canadiennes, un organisme culturel doit avoir produit deux spectacles. File Philomèle étant notre seconde création, nous y aurons accès dès la prochaine! Voilà ce qui explique pourquoi nous avons besoin de ton aide aujourd’hui. Tu as toujours rêvé d’être producteur? Voici ta chance! ;)Le plus grand risque étant le temps à investir par les interprètes et concepteurs, difficile à estimer à la perfection, particulièrement au niveau des éléments suivants :-Musique originale-Scénographie architecturale et solide (les interprètes doivent grimper et s’y attacher)-Temps de répétition avec les interprètes et chorégraphes pour amener la création à une qualité de présentation (une création se peaufinant constamment, même lorsqu’elle est à l’affiche) La campagne de socio-financement nous permettra de lever le reste des fonds nécessaires à la production et à la diffusion, mais surtout, de la débuter avec les interprètes, compositeurs et concepteurs! QUESTIONSNicole, TON, wtf? www.leton.caOvid, who’s that guy? Metamorphoses ...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphoses(You will find the fable "Prognée and Philomèle" in Book VI!)Do not hesitate to contact Nicole for any other questions! :)By commenting on this page, or by writing an email to info@nicolepresente.ca LES QUESTIONSNicole, Le TON, de kessé? www.leton.caOvide, c’est qui lui? Les Métamorphoses…https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Métamorphoses_(Ovide)(Tu trouveras la fable «Prognée et Philomèle» dans le livre VI!)N'hésite pas à contacter Nicole pour tout autre question! :) En commentant sur cette page ou en écrivant à info@nicolepresente.ca Can not you help us financially? Share the campaign with your family and friends! It helps us just as much, if not more! Nicole thanks you for your support and wishes you welcome to the team!Tu ne peux pas nous aider financièrement? Partage la campagne avec ta famille et tes amis! Cela nous aide tout autant, sinon plus! Nicole te remercie pour ton soutient et te souhaite bienvenu dans l'équipe!

story:
Dansazania is a dance studio that makes the joy of dance available to all, including those who cannot afford it, but blossom in life because of it. 
However just a few days ago, on September 14th, the non-profit dance studio was the victim arson. We are all completely devastated for the studio, Cinda - the professional dancer whose tireless efforts had built this to what it was, and especially to all the kids, many of them underprivileged or homeless. 

PLEASE HELP! We need everything possible to rebuild this amazing place of hope, care, love and especially dance. Help to make Dansazania rise from the ashes!

ANY HELP AT ALL IS APPRECIATED. THANK YOU Please call my Sister Cinda 0n 0832392299 and let us know if you can come and take a look. The property is the old tennis Club house corner Ruestenberg Rd and Carlow rd Melville.

story:
Summary:

The Way We Get By is being spearheaded by co-directors Logan Bruner and Michael A. Jorge-Rivera, both students at SUNY Purchase who have been theater nerds for their whole lives. Logan Bruner has directed two other productions for Blackwolves productions, he has been working in the entertainment field for the past 8 years during which time he has joined both SAG and AEA working on shows like "Orange is the New Black" and "Mozart in the Jungle" and plays "Springs Awakening" and "The Beautiful Dark". Michael is a sophomore BA theater performance arts major. This is his fourth production at SUNY Purchase. The money raised here will help create the project they have been envisioning in their heads for some time now. This will all culminate in a three night run of the production.

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised here will help in ALL areas of producing the show. The goal is $1500 which will contribute towards getting the flats for the set, various props that can’t be found at the school, such as a shelving unit, costumes, lights, curtains as well as the perks we would like to give back to any donators! Speaking of perks, they range from signed playbills to VIP seating during our shows! If the goal is not reached, every bit of money will still go towards making this production happen. We would have to economize and wouldn’t be able to get the new materials we would want, but the show must go on! This production is happening even if we have to do it in towels and no set (but hopefully we’ll reach our goal and that won’t happen).

The Impact

You may be wondering why this matters? Why should you trust a bunch of college kids with your hard earned cash? This show isn’t just about two people who had sex. It’s about wanting to ask the person you love the one question you just can’t seem to vocalize. It’s about being held back by invisible, and from the outside, meaningless barriers and in the end overcoming them. This show means so much to everyone working on it and we hope that if you come see it, it will mean that much to you too. Logan and Michael have both successfully put on productions here at Purchase before, so we know it is possible. Not only that, but we know that when this show goes up, it will be great. Simple as that.

Risks

There is the risk that we won’t get all the funding we need. What then? Well, we’d just go on. This is not the first production of any of the cast or crew members. All are passionate about this project and if need be, we are all willing to make sacrifices (be they fiscal or otherwise) to see this show happen. If we don’t get enough money to but the lights, we’ll find another production on campus who is willing to lend them to us. If we can’t afford costumes, we’ll have the actors bring in their own clothes. We will make it work regardless.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can give cash, but that's fine! There are plenty of other ways you can help! Share this on Indiegogo! Spread the word on every social media platform you can! Tell your friends! Tell your family! Tell your dog! Either way, thank you in advance!
