story:
Short Summary

The new play from BAFTA winning writer John Foster (Letters of a killer - Patrick Swayze). The Murder Wife is planned to open in London in October. Starring actress Janine Nerissa Broadhead and actor Joe Riley, the play tells a story of a women who discovers her husband is a serial killer and how she deals with this devastating news.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising 7k to bring this to life, the costs will cover production of the play and all support costs including (composers, rental of Theatre space, lighting, sound )

We offer a unique insight into the making of an independent British production and you will see it evolve and transform from the 1st read to a 90 minute production including sound, scores to a heart felt emotionally intense thriller. The actors have been working a gruelling schedule to prepare for this incredible and moving theatrical production

We are passionate about the arts & keeping Theatre alive.

As an investment incentive you will receive based on:

- £100 investment - Free tickets for a year's Doppelganger productions, Free back stage passes and drinks with the actors

- £50 investment - Free tickets for a year's Doppelganger Productions

- Any contribution whatsoever no matter how small will be gratefully received.

The Impact

We are a non profit organisation and re-invest all funds back into the arts. We work closely with Universities, are very active in all the festivals of learning throughout the countries. We have numerous productions under our belt , these have been very successful and enjoyed by many around the country.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
    • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who We Are and What We Do

Made It Theatre is a blood, sweat and tears organisation.

All of us have jobs and families in the real world, yet all of us have souls that reside in the creative realm. We’ve already spent almost every moment of our spare time since January working towards getting an astounding script out of the drawer and on to the stage. The passion in our souls has seen us through until now, but the time has come when the real world has intervened and is demanding that some readies are laid down.

Powerhouse Town is our second production. Buoyed by the success of the first, our confidence was sent sky high and ideas came thick and fast. There’s a bigger cast, a more complicated set and a bunch of props to pay for, and that’s just for starters.

The Cast (in no particular order)

Marcella Hazell   'Karolina'

Ann Brown   'Eileen'

Trevor Dwyer-Lynch   'John'

Anthony Bessick   'Billy'

Pete Gibson   'Bob The Taxi'

Mark Paterson   'Mark'

 

53Two is charity-run arts venue in Manchester City Centre. It's pretty new but has become an important part of the theatre scene in Manchester. We have secured a prime time-slot in 'The Pod', which is the smaller of the two spaces it offers.

81 Renshaw Street, our venue in Liverpool, is of historical importance musically speaking, and it is now a sought after space for theatre-makers and musicians. We couldn't have a better spot to preview our play.

It’s over a year since the script-in-hand reading of Powerhouse Town at Hope Mill Theatre in Manchester. That’s how long it’s taken for the stars to align and for us all, as a collective, to be in the same position at the same time – ready to go. But now we need a little bit of help.

There are a whole host of imaginative perks to be had for everyone who jumps aboard. Read on dear friends, read on...  

 

What We Need & What You Get

So, cutting to the chase, we need to raise £1500.

The costumes are not extravagant, but there are 6 fully grown actors in this one and they will need to be wearing something.

The set needs to reflect the stylised nature of Powerhouse Town so we need to buy some wood and some paint and then pay someone to build it.

As well as props, costumes and set, we need to pay to hire the venues in Liverpool and Manchester. We have sourced some very reasonably priced rehearsal space and we need pay for posters and flyers.

All but two of our perks include tickets to the show. It's important to us that you see what you've helped to fund. We have a formidable cast which we want to show off, and a darkly comic and touching tale we'd like to tell.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

The fact that you're here means you're only a click or two away from being able to share our appeal with, maybe thousands of people depending on how popular you are!

If your pockets are as shallow as ours are right now, just press that button and send us racing all over the internet. Your share could be the one that sends us flying past the chequered flag in time for curtain up this coming July.

Thank you so much for reading this far.

Please share this campaign with your friends xx

story:
Our mission is to bring magic to the Cuban people.

MagiCuba is a five-day, city-wide magic festival featuring some of the world's greatest magicians — including six shows at the Teatro Nacional de Cuba, eight nightclub shows across Havana, a special performance at the Cuban Circus, five full days of magic at our headquarters venue in Old Havana, and numerous other performances.  In addition, we are hosting a conference for magicians at the famed Hotel Nacional that adds a special Welcome Reception and Welcome Kit, several days of exceptional MagiCuba Sessions (lectures, talks, interviews, etc.), Magic & Mojitos happy hours featuring extraordinary close-up magic, a unique "Magic & Culture" walking tour of "Habana Vieja", a "Magic, Rum & Cigar Dinner" and other surprises.

Approximately 40 Cuban and international magicians have confirmed appearances, including John Archer, Jorge Blass, Mike Caveney, Mac King, Eric Mead, Michael Weber and Asi Wind. (See magicuba.org for full details and follow on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/MagiCuba/). This is a unique magic happening!

However, ticket sales and conference registrations will not cover our costs.  Not by a long shot.  We receive no money from the Cuban government and do not expect the event to generate any revenues. We have to pay all the expenses of bringing performers from around the world and across Cuba to Havana, as well as pay all costs for staff, production, marketing, logistics, etc.  The producers will finance the festival to ensure MagiCuba will take place -- no matter what.  However, we are relying on sponsors and the kindness of supporters such as yourself to help recover some of our costs so that we may consider running MagiCuba as an annual event.  So anything you can contribute will be helpful and much appreciated -- including getting the word out by sharing our campaign with your friends and family.  

Of course, the best way you can help is to join us in Havana (register at www.magicuba.org). But if you can't make it to MagiCuba, please help us to bring magic to the Cuban people by making a donation here.  We'll show our appreciation by sending you some fantastic MagiCuba festival merchandise and your name will appear in the "Thank You" credits of the official MagiCuba documentary, which will be distributed online worldwide!

PLEASE NOTE: MagiCuba is fully authorized by the U.S. Department of the Treasury and OFAC under general license CFR § 515.567, which covers travel-related transactions and other transactions that are directly incident to the organization of, and participation in, “public performances, clinics, workshops, athletic and other competitions, and exhibitions.”

story:
What is Takes Chops Productions?

We pride ourselves in creating opportunities for early-career artists diving into this sea of an industry.  Through development and collaboration we produce published works, new works, and reading workshops.  We understand and encourage artists to develop and explore all facets of the creative process through educational workshops, lectures and mentorships. We are happy to be an artistic sanctuary for these young artists testing their wings.  We dare them to create fiercely, unapologetically, and truthfully.

Board Members

Artistis Director: Flynn Osman

Managing Director: Caroline McQuaig

Director of Development: Tessa Welsch

 

Why For the Love of?

For the Love of (or, the Roller Derby Play) by Gina Femia is a passionate, exhilarating, hilarious and seductive play capped off with an entirely female and non-binary cast!  With its fast paced, raw dialogue this show will take you on a captivating ride.

Synopsis:

When Joy gets on the Brooklyn Scallywags and meets the star, Lizzie Lightning, she and her long term partner Michelle find their lives turned upside down. For The Love Of asks how much you’re willing to sacrifice – or lose – in order to follow your heart.

 

Cast

Joy Ride: Kiara Méndez

Michelle: Kayleigh Shuler

Lizzie Lightening: Angelika Anastasio

Andrea the Vagient: Laura Riveros-Sefair

Hot Flash: Lori Bodinizzo

Anna-Stecia: Disnie Sebastien

Squeaky Mouse: Ashley LaCambria

Diaz de los Muertos: Danielle Baez

Prosecute-Her: Liann Yu

 

Creative Team

Playwright: Gina Femia

Director: Flynn Navin Osman

Lighting Design Mentor: Emma Percy

Lighting Designer: Ariana Finamore

Costume Designer: Jennifer Iris Rivera

Scenic Designer: Nickie Dubick

Dramaturg: Lee Harrison Daniel

Casting Director: Megan Townsend 

Physical Trainer: Nora Walden 

 

Administrative Team

Company Manager: Kelly McGuinness

General Manager: Tessa Welsch

 

Budget Breakdown 

If you choose to give to our campaign, your money will be going towards:

The copyrights to produce eight (8) performances

Rehearsal space to refine our production

Costumes designed by Jennifer Iris Rivera

Lighting Equipment for designers Emma Percy and Ariana Finamore to bring their vision to life

Sets for our scenic designer Nickie Dubick to build our world

Marketing, so as many people as possible can come experience this play we love so much

 

Risks & Challenges

Creating theatre is always a financial risk, but we believe it is a worthwhile one. Theater space, especially in New York City, comes at a price and we cannot cover it alone. We also have big dreams here at TCP and some of the gorgeous costume and set designs we have in mind for this new production are going to require more than what we can source from our own homes. With your funding and our ingenuity and elbow grease, we can make this DIY production look like a Broadway smash. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help us get this project off the ground without a financial contribution! You can support us by sharing this campaign with your friends and on social media and following us on Instagram (@takeschops).

story:
Short Summary

  • I, TRUMP is being brought to you by the team from BreakingBurgh.com and Pittsburgh's Independent Filmmaking Community and theatre-makers across the country.
  • What is beyond belief one moment quickly becomes normality the next. Outrageous theatre is the way to puncture that balloon, and live theatre that people must COME TO is crucial to provoking fresh thinking in an election year.  Plus with your help we'll make the final version of I, TRUMP into a novella and film as well.
  • The sky's the limit with this project in this crazy time.  While we are determined to acheive something (and have a draft script and some excellent resources in hand) we need help to get to the fringe festivals we are targeting, create the filmed elements, and bring this to as many venues as possible across the country (and beyond) in the run-up to November 2020.
  • Interaction is key - while there is a draft script ready this will evolve, both in response to your input, the natural development process as we target bigger and bigger venues, and the shifting sands under our feet that defines the current era.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need funding to pay festival fees, hire rehearsal space, film crucial sequences, develop sets, get great actors and technical staff so it can be as big as it needs to be.  We want to have rolling appearances at fringe festival all over and get it picked up by somewhere even bigger.
  • We got perks! Check 'em out  if only for a laugh.
  • Whatever happens we can guarantee something will happen.  But how big it is and what impact we can have is up to you.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • No matter what you can or cannot give financially, sharing and engaging with the project on Social Media is worth a lot!
story_txt:
Short Summary

I, TRUMP is being brought to you by the team from BreakingBurgh.com and Pittsburgh's Independent Filmmaking Community and theatre-makers across the country.
What is beyond belief one moment quickly becomes normality the next. Outrageous theatre is the way to puncture that balloon, and live theatre that people must COME TO is crucial to provoking fresh thinking in an election year.  Plus with your help we'll make the final version of I, TRUMP into a novella and film as well.
The sky's the limit with this project in this crazy time.  While we are determined to acheive something (and have a draft script and some excellent resources in hand) we need help to get to the fringe festivals we are targeting, create the filmed elements, and bring this to as many venues as possible across the country (and beyond) in the run-up to November 2020.
Interaction is key - while there is a draft script ready this will evolve, both in response to your input, the natural development process as we target bigger and bigger venues, and the shifting sands under our feet that defines the current era.


What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to pay festival fees, hire rehearsal space, film crucial sequences, develop sets, get great actors and technical staff so it can be as big as it needs to be.  We want to have rolling appearances at fringe festival all over and get it picked up by somewhere even bigger.
We got perks! Check 'em out  if only for a laugh.
Whatever happens we can guarantee something will happen.  But how big it is and what impact we can have is up to you.


Other Ways You Can Help
No matter what you can or cannot give financially, sharing and engaging with the project on Social Media is worth a lot!

story:
MI HISTORIA / BACKGROUND

La Fundación Cultural Metáforas es una Entidad sin ánimo de lucro de Bogotá D.C. - Colombia que desarrolla proyectos culturales, de educación informal, desarrollo del talento humano y de favorecimiento a comunidades en situación de vulnerabilidad a través de puestas en escena teatrales, Bibliovacaciones creativas y programas de senbilización artística.

The Metaphors Cultural Foundation is a non-profit organization in Bogota D.C Colombia. It develops cultural projects concerning informal education, talent development, and provides support for communities in vulnerable situation through theater plays, creative library-vacations and art programs.

NUESTRA PRECOCUPACIÓN / OUR CONCERN

En Colombia resulta muy difícil producir espectáculos teatrales auto gestionables y auto sostenibles por diferentes motivos: los artistas no podemos depender económicamente de nuestro arte, hay una subvaloración al oficio del teatro y del actor,  existe una sobre demanda de actores y de montajes teatrales para una escasa oferta que paga precios irrisorios por las funciones y por los honorarios de los artistas, no existen modelos gubernamentales que garanticen la formalización y del desarrollo sostenible de dicha actividad, por todo esto,  en la gran mayoría de los casos nos toca  a los actores, directores y gestores culturales alternar las actividades artísticas con la docencia, los eventos recreativos, labores freelance, prácticas de teatro de calle y en el peor de los casos desempeñar oficios muy alejados de nuestra profesión (ventas, servicio al cliente, atención al público etc.) para poder vivir y solventar los gastos diarios de alimentación, vestuario y vivienda entre otros; situación que no ha facilitado que la Fundación Cultural Metáforas pueda consolidar equipos de trabajo estables para llevar a cabo su objeto social.

Por otra parte, nos enfrentamos a la disyuntiva de encontrar financiamiento para la producción de las obras, lo que nos imposibilita llevar a cabo un proceso de creación sólido y coherente, situación que en muchos casos termina desmotivando a los artistas y fragmentando los procesos de creación.

En este marco contextual se presenta esta campaña de crowdfunding como una alternativa para hallar soluciones a nuestra problemática.

In Colombia it is very difficult to stage theatrical performances which would be self-managed and self-sustaining. And there is a number of reasons for this:

·  Financially the artists can't depend on their occupation due to low salaries ,

·  The art of the theater and of the actor is underestimated

·  There is an over demand of actors and plays for the lack of offers with ridiculously low prices for a show and low actors’ fees

·  There are no models of government, which guarantee formal and sustainable development of this activity.

For all these reasons, in most cases it is up to actors, directors and cultural managers to combine the artistic activity with teaching, recreational events, freelancing, taking part in street theatre and in the worst case, to have occupation which is quite far from our profession (sales, customer service, etc.) to be able to survive and afford daily expenses for food, clothes and dwelling in the society. This is a kind of situation which has not facilitated that the Cultural Foundation “Metáforas” could consolidate stable teams to carry out its corporative aim.

On the other hand, we face the dilemma of finding funding for the production of the works which disables us to carry out a firm and coherent process of creating. In many cases this situation ends up with demotivating artists and fragmenting a creation processes.

In this context crowdfunding is presented as an alternative campaign to find solutions to our issues.

DESCRIPCIÓN DE CAMPAÑA / DESCRIPTION OF THE CAMPAIGN

Estamos en proceso de producción de la obra de teatro: “El niño y el rey” una versión libre del cuento inglés The rock in the road “la roca en el camino”, la puesta en escena que está siendo montada  por un equipo de actores profesionales está pensada para el público infantil/familiar y habla sobre la importancia de la ayuda al prójimo y el servicio a los demás.  La obra cuenta con un elenco de 7 actores, 1 director, 1 diseñador y 1 productor.

We are in the process of producing a stage play called "The Child and the King” a free interpretation of the English story "The Rock in the Road". This play is putting on stage with the support of a team of professional actors. It is intended for children/ family audience and concerns the idea of importance of the neighbor. The work is provided with a cast including 7 actors, 1 director, 1 designer and 1 producer.

QUE NECESITAMOS Y QUÉ OBTIENES /WHAT WE NEED WHAT YOU GET

Buscamos tu apoyo para poder financiar la producción y el estreno del montaje, esta ayuda puede ser en especie o económica. Según tu aporte habrán unos incentivos que puedes ver en las recompensas que ofrecemos en nuestra campaña.

We are looking for financial support for the staging our project keeping in mind the aesthetic parameters that we have determined for it (Scenery, props, costumes, premiere performance, advertising, etc.  Depends of your contribution there will be the rewards listed below.

IMPACTO / IMPACT

Con tu colaboración, habrás aportado tu granito de arena para la dignificación del oficio del teatro en nuestro país y podrás hacer posible que la obra sea visibilizada por patrocinadores, mecenas, entidades gubernamentales, empresarios y/o gente que le interese movilizarla para proyectos sociales y culturales en el ámbito local o nacional.

Por otra parte, habrás ayudado en el mejoramiento y equipamiento de los elementos técnicos necesarios para que la Fundación pueda llevar a cabo su gestión cultural con profesionalismo y calidad técnica.

With your collaboration, you will have contributed your bit for the dignity of the art of the theatre and profession of the actor in our country, and you'll be able to make it possible for the work to be noticeable for sponsors, patrons, government, employers and/or people who  want to mobilize themselves for social and cultural projects on the local or national level.

On the other hand, you will have helped the improvement and equipment of the necessary technical elements for the Foundation to carry out its cultural management with professionalism and technical quality.

story:
Heavy Metal Knitting World Championships were held in Joensuu, Finland for the first time in July 2019. News of the event swept to all corners of the world - in one week videos made of the event had been seen by hundreds of millions of people around the world.

Spend one minute of your life by viewing this video from the event. You won't regret it. Or if you don't like anything creative and crazy then you will. Then you shouldn't be even reading this campaign.

 

The competition was a success, but unfortunately it was organized by a group of heavy metal knitting enthusiast-volunteers and an EU funded program that saw its end in 2020. No more EU monies meant no more Heavy Metal Knitting - unless someone took a risk and did something.

So we did!

We established a company called WTF Productions Ltd. (yeah, you read that right - it's Welcome to Finland Productions), who would take the responsibility of organizing craziest Finnish summer event out there. 

We prepared everything in time and in late December 2019 we launched the application period for the 2020 competition and started eagerly waiting for the applications to roll in.

But little did we know, that there would be a person in China, who would eat a bat and who single-handedly would make the world go bat shit crazy. And cause home quarantines, restrictions on movement and halts on commercial activities on a scale never seen before...

Our team pondered on this just when the application period was about to close in March and made the heavy decision - we had to cancel the 2020 event.

In 2019, the live event had people coming from Japan, UK, USA, Israel, Russia, Denmark, Sweden and Finland. If we were to organize the event during the summer 2020, we would pose a serious threat to the contestants if they were to fly to Finland during the Covid-19 epidemic and meet with people from all around the world.

We can't estimate (and we believe no one can) when the crisis and limitations will be over, so the safest bet to do here is to cancel the whole year 2020 and look forward to 2021.

The main problem in cancelling events is however, that a cancelled event cannot generate any income for the organizer. No income - no stage, no lights, no security, no band, no event and eventually no organizers.

To make ends meet and to actually make the event happen again in 2021, we're asking help from you - the grand people of the Internet.

Help us create the event again and make it even better!

By supporting this project, you will make sure that Heavy Metal Knitting will continue and see the crowning of the Heavy Metal Knitting World Champion 2021 (and beyond).

 

Organizing a Heavy Metal Knitting World Championship event entails on a minimum level

  • Venue & stage (it's an open air event, so we need to rent and build a stage)
  • Audio equipment for the metal band (heavy metal knitting ain't the same in acoustic mode)
  • Heavy metal band (this goes without saying. Without a metal band, heavy metal knitting is just - well - knitting)
  • Sound engineer (to mix those tunes for the people seeing the event live)
  • Licenses (if we play real metal songs from real bands we need to pay for the licenses)
  • Security (we don't know how out of hand the event will get, better get some people securing the artists)
  • Live feed (we do realize that not all people can (or want) to come to the most remote corner of the European Union, so the thing we should do is to bring the action to you when it's happening!)
  • The evening before - the contestants need to get to know each other and relax a bit before their big show. We're planning to host a small get-together for the contestants in a Finnish forest under the midnight sun. 

The event and the list above will cost us approximately 20,666 €. Note that we didn't include any compensation for the team in the estimation. We really want to make this happen so we set the bar on the minimum level and hope we're able to exceed it with our idea. If we get more, we're super happy about it and can make even better of an event! 

    If we don't reach our goal of 20,666 €, we'll try to make the event happen anyway. Cutting corners is not nice nor wanted, but the most important thing is that we guarantee that the event will actually take place. If the campaign falls short of the goal - we'll just have to find another way to fund it.

     


     

    In exchange for your interest and monies we offer something truly great (in our opinion at least).

    • Any perk will grant you a lifetime access to the most exquisite club of all time: The Heavy Metal Knitters of the World (we actually have a Facebook group under that name). That and your name permanently on the Wall of Heavy Metal Knitting Fame that will be on our website www.heavymetalknitting.com. Just how cool is that? YOUR NAME ON THE HEAVY METAL KNITTING WEBSITE!
    • You can purchase the coolest clothes and carry the heavy metal knitting logos on your t-shirt or patch your badge anywhere you like. Be a promoter. Pleeeaaase.
    • You can learn how to do heavy metal knitting yourself! Buy the heavy metal knitting starter pack and play some Purl Jam or SlipKnit. The starter kit contains actual knitting needles, Finnish wool made from real sheep, music recommendations, and of course instructions and a moves list on how to do heavy metal knitting!
    • We'll make a few heavy metal knitting wool sweaters and place them available for purchase only in IndieGoGo! Go get em while they're there! Really unique. These will be knitted while listening to your favourite metal band on repeat.
    • The entrepreneurs and business people will see our limited heavy metal knitting cooperation packages worth of buying. Remember the millions of video views we got? Wouldn't it be great to see your company there too?
    • We also made a limited perk for Elon Musk. Elon alone can make Heavy Metal Knitting happen. At the cost of 20,666€ Elon alone can buy the "This is for you Elon" cooperation package. If Elon buys this perk, we would name the event for 2021 as "Elon Musk Heavy Metal Knitting World Championship" Elon Musk is a great inspiration to all of us at the WTF Productions company, so this would be the greatest thing to happen :D

     

     

    The impact of the campaign is immense. The Internet (especially the Internet of Japan) demands more stuff like this. If the campaign is successful, we're able to safely continue developing the event and start planning it for the years to come (2021, 2022, 2023, 2024...)

    Last year our small team built the event from scratch and on a very low budget still resulting in awesome material. Just think what is possible if there's support from all the corners of the world!

    We're aiming to build a worldwide community of heavy metal knitters with the Heavy Metal World Championship being it's yearly peak event. This campaign is a make or break in this endeavor.

     

     

    The biggest risk one can think of has already realized. The Covid-19 epidemic shut down entire continents and made going to other countries and organizing events impossible. We cannot be certain that the epidemic and governments around the world would allow the participants to arrive to Finland in July 2019, so we did what we could and moved the event forward by one full year.

    Other, not so dire risks relate to funding and marketing.

    The funding part is obvious - to organize the event, we need to put in hundreds of hours of work and pay the professionals who make the show happen in July 2021. We should be able to attract funding worth of 20 666 € from different channels, but if we don't we'll still try to make the event happen.

    We prioritize on securing the funding for the event before anything else.

    The second risk is that we won't get enough participants in the competition. Last year there was 26 applicants our of which 12 got into the live finals. We're obviously expecting more applicants for the 2021 event as the Covid-19 epidemic should be a thing in the past.

     

     

    The best way to help Heavy Metal Knitting happen is of course to purchase a perk or two from this campaign. It will have the largest impact on the project and for that we will be eternally grateful.

    The second best way is to share the campaign in your social media channels or send info about it to friends and acquaintances. We're grateful for any publicity the event can get!

    You can use our handles @heavymetalknitting (and @heavyknitting on Twitter) to tag us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and the hashtag #heavymetalknitting to join the conversation. 

    We're also looking for volunteers who could help us create the memorable event in Joensuu, Finland. If you'd like to work with us in this manner, please send a message to wtf@heavymetalknitting.com

    We're absolutely humbled by the number of individuals who support the building of the event. If we can pull this off, we're absolutely going to make an event to remember!

Spend one minute of your life by viewing this video from the event. You won't regret it. Or if you don't like anything creative and crazy then you will. Then you shouldn't be even reading this campaign.


 

The competition was a success, but unfortunately it was organized by a group of heavy metal knitting enthusiast-volunteers and an EU funded program that saw its end in 2020. No more EU monies meant no more Heavy Metal Knitting - unless someone took a risk and did something.
So we did!
We established a company called WTF Productions Ltd. (yeah, you read that right - it's Welcome to Finland Productions), who would take the responsibility of organizing craziest Finnish summer event out there. 
We prepared everything in time and in late December 2019 we launched the application period for the 2020 competition and started eagerly waiting for the applications to roll in.But little did we know, that there would be a person in China, who would eat a bat and who single-handedly would make the world go bat shit crazy. And cause home quarantines, restrictions on movement and halts on commercial activities on a scale never seen before...
Our team pondered on this just when the application period was about to close in March and made the heavy decision - we had to cancel the 2020 event.
In 2019, the live event had people coming from Japan, UK, USA, Israel, Russia, Denmark, Sweden and Finland. If we were to organize the event during the summer 2020, we would pose a serious threat to the contestants if they were to fly to Finland during the Covid-19 epidemic and meet with people from all around the world.
We can't estimate (and we believe no one can) when the crisis and limitations will be over, so the safest bet to do here is to cancel the whole year 2020 and look forward to 2021.
The main problem in cancelling events is however, that a cancelled event cannot generate any income for the organizer. No income - no stage, no lights, no security, no band, no event and eventually no organizers.
To make ends meet and to actually make the event happen again in 2021, we're asking help from you - the grand people of the Internet.
Help us create the event again and make it even better!
By supporting this project, you will make sure that Heavy Metal Knitting will continue and see the crowning of the Heavy Metal Knitting World Champion 2021 (and beyond).
 


Organizing a Heavy Metal Knitting World Championship event entails on a minimum level

Venue & stage (it's an open air event, so we need to rent and build a stage)
Audio equipment for the metal band (heavy metal knitting ain't the same in acoustic mode)
Heavy metal band (this goes without saying. Without a metal band, heavy metal knitting is just - well - knitting)
Sound engineer (to mix those tunes for the people seeing the event live)
Licenses (if we play real metal songs from real bands we need to pay for the licenses)
Security (we don't know how out of hand the event will get, better get some people securing the artists)
Live feed (we do realize that not all people can (or want) to come to the most remote corner of the European Union, so the thing we should do is to bring the action to you when it's happening!)
The evening before - the contestants need to get to know each other and relax a bit before their big show. We're planning to host a small get-together for the contestants in a Finnish forest under the midnight sun. 

The event and the list above will cost us approximately 20,666 €. Note that we didn't include any compensation for the team in the estimation. We really want to make this happen so we set the bar on the minimum level and hope we're able to exceed it with our idea. If we get more, we're super happy about it and can make even better of an event! 

If we don't reach our goal of 20,666 €, we'll try to make the event happen anyway. Cutting corners is not nice nor wanted, but the most important thing is that we guarantee that the event will actually take place. If the campaign falls short of the goal - we'll just have to find another way to fund it.
 
 
In exchange for your interest and monies we offer something truly great (in our opinion at least).

Any perk will grant you a lifetime access to the most exquisite club of all time: The Heavy Metal Knitters of the World (we actually have a Facebook group under that name). That and your name permanently on the Wall of Heavy Metal Knitting Fame that will be on our website www.heavymetalknitting.com. Just how cool is that? YOUR NAME ON THE HEAVY METAL KNITTING WEBSITE!
You can purchase the coolest clothes and carry the heavy metal knitting logos on your t-shirt or patch your badge anywhere you like. Be a promoter. Pleeeaaase.
You can learn how to do heavy metal knitting yourself! Buy the heavy metal knitting starter pack and play some Purl Jam or SlipKnit. The starter kit contains actual knitting needles, Finnish wool made from real sheep, music recommendations, and of course instructions and a moves list on how to do heavy metal knitting!
We'll make a few heavy metal knitting wool sweaters and place them available for purchase only in IndieGoGo! Go get em while they're there! Really unique. These will be knitted while listening to your favourite metal band on repeat.
The entrepreneurs and business people will see our limited heavy metal knitting cooperation packages worth of buying. Remember the millions of video views we got? Wouldn't it be great to see your company there too?
We also made a limited perk for Elon Musk. Elon alone can make Heavy Metal Knitting happen. At the cost of 20,666€ Elon alone can buy the "This is for you Elon" cooperation package. If Elon buys this perk, we would name the event for 2021 as "Elon Musk Heavy Metal Knitting World Championship" Elon Musk is a great inspiration to all of us at the WTF Productions company, so this would be the greatest thing to happen :D


 
 

The impact of the campaign is immense. The Internet (especially the Internet of Japan) demands more stuff like this. If the campaign is successful, we're able to safely continue developing the event and start planning it for the years to come (2021, 2022, 2023, 2024...)
Last year our small team built the event from scratch and on a very low budget still resulting in awesome material. Just think what is possible if there's support from all the corners of the world!
We're aiming to build a worldwide community of heavy metal knitters with the Heavy Metal World Championship being it's yearly peak event. This campaign is a make or break in this endeavor.
 


 
The biggest risk one can think of has already realized. The Covid-19 epidemic shut down entire continents and made going to other countries and organizing events impossible. We cannot be certain that the epidemic and governments around the world would allow the participants to arrive to Finland in July 2019, so we did what we could and moved the event forward by one full year.
Other, not so dire risks relate to funding and marketing.
The funding part is obvious - to organize the event, we need to put in hundreds of hours of work and pay the professionals who make the show happen in July 2021. We should be able to attract funding worth of 20 666 € from different channels, but if we don't we'll still try to make the event happen.
We prioritize on securing the funding for the event before anything else.
The second risk is that we won't get enough participants in the competition. Last year there was 26 applicants our of which 12 got into the live finals. We're obviously expecting more applicants for the 2021 event as the Covid-19 epidemic should be a thing in the past.
 

 

The best way to help Heavy Metal Knitting happen is of course to purchase a perk or two from this campaign. It will have the largest impact on the project and for that we will be eternally grateful.
The second best way is to share the campaign in your social media channels or send info about it to friends and acquaintances. We're grateful for any publicity the event can get!
You can use our handles @heavymetalknitting (and @heavyknitting on Twitter) to tag us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and the hashtag #heavymetalknitting to join the conversation. 
We're also looking for volunteers who could help us create the memorable event in Joensuu, Finland. If you'd like to work with us in this manner, please send a message to wtf@heavymetalknitting.com
We're absolutely humbled by the number of individuals who support the building of the event. If we can pull this off, we're absolutely going to make an event to remember!

story:
"American dreams can and do come true, it seems."--Anna Pulley, East Bay Express from Pick of the Week” about Piedmont Oakland Repertory Theatre  

To make that dream really come true, we need your help!

With your help we may be able to keep producing plays at 4137 Piedmont Ave

Our goal is to raise $12,986 by March 31 to produce the next play.  

We've need  $8,174 MORE by the Deadline.

If we DON'T raise $12,986--YOU GET A FULL REFUND ON YOUR DONATION.  

If we DO raise it,  there are  GREAT PERKS:

  • EACH $48 donated gets one free ticket for the next play.                              
  • INPUT INTO THE PLAYS you would like to see ($28 or more).
  • $28 gets free concessions when you come to the next play.                            
  • $98 gets 2 tickets to the next play  and 2 admissions to the Special Reception on March 29th (NOTE: date changed from March 15 to March 29)  to eat drink, schmooze, talk about theatre, and see a 15-minute preview of Marty Nemko's new musical "Retard!" about a woman with Asperger's who he helped become a musical theatre perfomer!
But any amount helps: lots of little donations add up to help us reach the goal.
BELOW YOU WILL FIND:
  • "Why raise the $ for only one play?"...our rationale.
  • "Are we worth it?"...quotes from reviews.
  • "Where the money goes (and comes from)"...our budget for full disclosure--and which part you might want to underwrite.
  • "Our list of potential plays for production"...which donors of $25 or more can weigh in on!
  • FAQs
For inquiries: (510) 459-8264 or piedmontoaklandrep@gmail.co
 Donate to the RIGHT by Credit Card (donations are through PayPal--so we can refund your donations easily if we don't make the goal---if you don't have an account, you don't have to register, just do is mark the box "Guest.")
Or SEND CHECKS TO: PORT, Box 20936, Oakland CA 94620

John Hale and Karly Shea in "Other People's Money"  Mar-Apr 2014 at Kehillah

"WHY RAISE MONEY FOR JUST ONE PLAY?"...our rationale

For for all the local enthusiasm, great reviews, and advertising—we haven't been in the same place long enough  to make a splash and bring in the audiences.          For instance: "What I Did Last Summer" (Nov 1 - Dec 13) costs $13,000 to produce...and we grossed only $3, 000 in 17 performances.

We plan on doing three plays this year.  But it is unrealistic to expect to raise enough for all three (about $40K plus) in 40 days, so we are aiming to raise enough for another production while we rally more support and get more audience.                              So, "One play at a time."

"The Dining Room" with John Hale, Karly Shea, Aaron Vanderbeeck, Susannah Wood, Brett Mermer, Jamie Harkin  Nov-Dec 2013 Piedmont Center for the Arts
"ARE WE WORTH IT?"...quotes from reviews 
We have produced 3 plays “The Dining Room,” “Other People’s Money,” and “What I Did Last Summer,” and 3 staged readings “The Vibrator Play,” “Love Letters,” and “Speed-the Plow.” Our plays have received first-class reviews.  Here are the blurbs:

"When I saw their riotous and high-spirited production of "The Dining Room" by A.R.Gurney last holiday season, I thought here is a neighborhood theatre company whose work I do not want to miss. “The Piedmont-Oakland Rep is thoroughly professional.--Jeremy Larner, Screenwriter, Academy Award winner for Original Screenplay in 1973 for "The Candidate" which starred Robert Redford.

 “[The Dining Room] is more than a baby step – it’s a full-fledged accomplishment. Deft orchestrator, the Rep’s artistic director, John McMullen, who has chosen perhaps the perfect play for his company’s debut in town.”--Robert C. Hall, Piedmont Post

“Other People's Money is… an enormously entertaining ride—a not-so-fictional history lesson that rockets viewers right into the present. Piedmont Oakland Rep has done a great job bringing it to life.”---Barry Willis, president, Critics Circle in Piedmont Post

 “Come for the greed and sex, stay for the doughnuts.  [reviewing"Other People's Money"] …exquisite power plays and the compelling-yet-repelling  (John Hale as) Garfield, whose cunning, self-deprecation, dancey rejoinders, and fetish for doughnuts make him…highly watchable.”–Anna Pulley , East Bay Express

.. the distraught mother is a joy to watch…. [Director John] McMullen keeps the action moving at a good clip….Add two teen pals and a bit of sexual tension…[in 'What I Did Last Summer'], you have a coming-of-age drama  with plenty of grit.” – Sally Hogarty, Contra Costa Times & Inside Bay Area News

“Other People's Money is…a neat ensemble for the often quick scenes with sharp dialogue.  It's a fine Fall entertainment—and hopefully PORT has a long run of its own on Piedmont Avenue.” --Ken Bullock, Berkeley Daily Planet


Nathan Zambala, Rosie Fry, Cameron Dodd in "What I Did Last Summer"            Nov-Dec 2014 at 4137 Piedmont Avenue--where we want to stay!
"WHERE THE MONEY GOES"...our budget for full disclosure--and which part you might want to underwrite.

We pay the actors--not much, but we pay. Many non-Equity theatres don’t pay.  Actors have to pay for transportation, a quick snack on the way to rehearsal.            Each actor puts in about 200 hours per play: 15 performances of 3 hours each.  25 rehearsals—5 nights per week from 7 pm to 10 pm--usually after a full day’s work at an office or a restaurant. At least 40 hours to memorize lines.  Talk about dedication!

We spend little on the set--it's theatre of the imagination!--and we borrow most of the costumes. Royalties are $100 PER PERFORMANCE…unless we do Shakespeare, Shaw, or Wilde, etc.…but we mostly want to bring you those plays that perhaps you don’t see elsewhere.

OVERHEAD  TOTALS 
Rent & Utilities  $  4,950.00
Sec Dep  $  400.00
Insurance  $  567.00
Supplies  $  100.00
Fees   $  895.00
Fundraising   $  2,300.00
 SUBTOTAL   $  9,212.00
PRODUCTION COSTS per prod
Actors  $  1,500.00
Director  $  500.00
Lighting/Sound  $  325.00
Royalties  $  1,300.00
Promotion  $  3,600.00
Costumes  $  250.00
Designers  $  150.00
Stage Manager  $  150.00
Rehearsal space  $  500.00
Sets  $  200.00
Props   $  100.00
Concessions  $  130.00
Programs  $  100.00
 SUBTOTAL   $  8,805.00
 TOTAL EXPENSES   $  18,017.00
INCOME
Tickets  $  3,978.00
Concessions  $  468.00
Door donations  $  585.00
Projected income  $  5,031.00
NEED TO RAISE   $  12,986.00

We have about $2,200 left in the bank, and we are using it to run this campaign for ads, mailings, signs, postcards, etc.

"OUR LIST OF POTENTIAL PLAYS FOR PRODUCTION"  If we make the goal, we will query everyone who donates $25 or more to see how they rank the plays.as well as asking you to suggest plays you'd like to see which aren't listed.

Boston Marriage—David Mamet’s only love story, a high comedy about a pair of Lesbian Courtesans Con-Artists in Victorian Times.

Medea--Euripides, adaptation by California poet Robinson Jeffers...                   “HELL HATH NO FURY….She gave him her all.   Stole the treasure, betrayed her father, cut her brother into pieces then threw the pieces out the back of the chariot to slow down her father’s pursuit.  She came with him to his homeland where they treated this princess like an outsider, an alien, a witch. …not that she didn’t have her tricks and potions. Now he is leaving her to marry a younger woman—the king’s daughter—so he can climb the ladder of success. And he plans to take their two boys with him. BUT…Some women you just shouldn’t mess with.”                         Judith Anderson urged her friend Jeffers to adapt the play for her--and she won the Tony for her performance!  "...a very actable version." 

OR,--by  Liz Duffy Adams.  Aphra Behn, the first female playwright of the English Restoration stage (and a spy!), meets up with The Merry Monarch King Charles and Nell Gwynne, the first female actress on the English stage…and hot fireworks follow!  Originally produced by SF’s Magic Theatre.

The Merchant of Venice—by you-know-who.  Italians and Jews speak in accent which lends rhythm to the language, in this controversial and brutal “comedy” about a harsh collecting of a debt and revenge.  But teenage Portia is the smartest girl in Venice who outwits them all (think a young Katharine Hepburn).  The old question remains: “Who is the hero and who the villain?”In two hours with all the boring parts tossed into the bin of dramatic history, and accompanied by lovely traditional Italian music. 

The Actor’s Nightmare & Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All to You—by Christopher Durang.  The bad dream of every actor of showing up in underwear not knowing their lines.  Worse in the cast are historical theatre luminaries Henry Irving, Sarah Siddons, Dame Ellen Terry.  Worse yet, the plays are Hamlet, Private Lives, A Man for All Seasons, and a ersatz Samuel Beckett Play.  The other one is the nun who terrorized every parochial schoolboy’s dreams and made the rest of us laugh hysterically at her educational philosophy.

DOG’S HAMLET and CAHOOT’S MACBETH by Tom Stoppard.  This clever romp is two short plays. In the first, a troupe of English schoolboys (played by adults) speak in a mock language called "Dogg." This hilarious language babbles along until the schoolboys, who are studying Shakespeare's "foreign" language, present an incredibly funny 15 minute version of Hamlet and then encore with a two-minute version!   Then, after the Prague Spring of 1968, theaters were shuttered and state-supported actors lost their jobs.  But you could "rent" an evening of theatre by having 5 actors show up at your door with a suitcase full of props and costumes and put on a play in your living room.  In "Kahoot's Macbeth" the action shifts between the bare stage and a police inquiry. The murder and intrigue of Shakespeare's play are juxtaposed with the Czech political harassment.  "The language and the laughter are contagious...Lewis Carroll would have been at home." - The New York Time. "A blend of comic nonsense and astringent political satire." - Christian Science Monitor

Heidi Wolff and Brett Mermer "In the Next Room: The Vibrator Play"  Sept 2014  at 4137 Piedmont Avenue

FAQs--ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS I’VE BEEN ASKED:

Why such a low estimate on the ticket revenue and attendance? We based it on what we have brought in over the last 3 plays.  We sell some tickets on Goldstar for half price.   We discount a lot to bring people in. Hopefully, more tickets will be sold,

A lot of people have said that they didn’t know about us.  Hopefully, that will change when we have a season and can sell subscriptions and “flexpasses.”

You can help remedy this: tell everyone you know that there is live theatre on Piedmont Avenue!).

How much have we spent so far?

In the last year we have produced 3 plays and 3 staged readings.                             We have spent over $35,000.  The Producer put up his own money to fund the productions.   None of the budget reflects any repayment of that amount.

Why is the rent so low on Piedmont Avenue?

We would be sharing the space with another tenant.  We would have access on Saturday nights and Sundays…which means we have to set up all the sets, lights, etc., then dismantle everything each weekend. 

Thus our schedule of playing 3 performances per week on Saturday evening , Sunday Matinee, and Sunday evening for 5 weeks per production.

It’s too hard to park on Piedmont Avenue

We go to the movies, we go to restaurants, we go to the gyms, we go shopping, we go to the beauty parlor, and always find a place to park.                               HOWEVER, Wells Fargo has generously offered their 20 space parking lot to us after their 6 pm closing.                                                                                                         We will offer this as a perk to the first 20 who contribute $100 for the Reception, and to our first subscribers (when we get a full season and can sell subscriptions).

How do we select the plays?

As is usual, the artistic director decides the season.  This year, we are inviting our audience to weigh in on which plays they prefer from a list.

John McMullen says, "Here is what I think about when selecting a play: does it touch me emotionally and tickle my brain?  Do I have the actors to play the roles? Will it make my audience want to come and see it? We have a “company” of actors who we tend to consider when choosing plays.

Why not apply for grants?

 It seems that you have to be in business for about three years before they take you seriously.   Lots of the money for arts grants has shrunk, but we will be applying soon. 

Can I deduct this?

If we raise the $13K, yes, you will be able to deduct it from this year’s taxes.

We are awaiting our 501c3 nonprofit status, but it is a sure thing and retroactive to when we incorporated.

If we don’t raise it, you get your money back.

Who is behind all this?

Producer John McMullen has an MFA in directing from Carnegie Mellon, and lots of experience acting, directing, and teaching at Carnegie Mellon, City College of San Francisco, and Los Medanos College.

For the last 4 years, he has been the theatre critic for the Berkeley Daily Planet—but his theatre friends tease him that, “He has come back from the dark side.”

If you don't have much, but love theatre:

  • Enough $10 contributions add up
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

Here’s hoping!

John McMullen

DONATE at the TOP RIGHT 

or send your check to:  PORT, Box 20936, Oakland CA 94620 (please mail checks by March 28 so we can receive and process it before the deadline).

Lesbian Courtesans Con-Artists in Victorian Times.
Medea--Euripides, adaptation by California poet Robinson Jeffers...                   “HELL HATH NO FURY….She gave him her all.   Stole
the treasure, betrayed her father, cut her brother into pieces then threw the
pieces out the back of the chariot to slow down her father’s pursuit.  She came with him to his homeland where they
treated this princess like an outsider, an alien, a witch. …not that she didn’t
have her tricks and potions. Now he is leaving her to marry a younger woman—the
king’s daughter—so he can climb the ladder of success. And he plans to take
their two boys with him. BUT…Some women you just shouldn’t mess with.”                         Judith Anderson urged her friend Jeffers to adapt the play for her--and she won the Tony for her performance!  "...a very actable version." 
OR,--by 
Liz Duffy Adams.  Aphra Behn, the
first female playwright of the English Restoration stage (and a spy!), meets up
with The Merry Monarch King Charles and Nell Gwynne, the first female actress
on the English stage…and hot fireworks follow! 
Originally produced by SF’s Magic Theatre.
The Merchant of Venice—by
you-know-who.  Italians and Jews speak
in accent which lends rhythm to the language, in this controversial and brutal
“comedy” about a harsh collecting of a debt and revenge.  But teenage Portia is the smartest girl in
Venice who outwits them all (think a young Katharine Hepburn).  The old question remains: “Who is the hero
and who the villain?”In two hours
with all the boring parts tossed into the bin of dramatic history, and
accompanied by lovely traditional Italian music.  
The Actor’s
Nightmare & Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All to You—by Christopher Durang.  The bad dream of every actor of showing up
in underwear not knowing their lines.  Worse
in the cast are historical theatre luminaries Henry Irving, Sarah Siddons, Dame
Ellen Terry.  Worse yet, the plays are Hamlet, Private Lives, A Man for All
Seasons, and a ersatz Samuel Beckett Play. 
The other one is the nun who terrorized every parochial schoolboy’s
dreams and made the rest of us laugh hysterically at her educational
philosophy. 
DOG’S HAMLET and CAHOOT’S MACBETH by Tom Stoppard.  This clever romp is two short plays. In the
first, a troupe of English schoolboys (played by adults) speak in a mock
language called "Dogg." This hilarious language babbles along until
the schoolboys, who are studying Shakespeare's "foreign" language,
present an incredibly funny 15 minute version of Hamlet and then encore with a
two-minute version!   Then, after the Prague Spring of 1968, theaters were shuttered and state-supported actors lost their jobs.  But you could "rent" an evening of theatre by having 5 actors show up at your door with a suitcase full of props and costumes and put on a play in your living room.  In "Kahoot's Macbeth" the action shifts between the bare stage and a police inquiry. The murder and intrigue of Shakespeare's play are juxtaposed with the Czech political harassment.  "The language and the laughter are contagious...Lewis
Carroll would have been at home." - The New York Time. "A blend of comic nonsense and astringent political
satire." - Christian Science Monitor



Heidi Wolff and Brett Mermer "In the Next Room: The Vibrator Play"  Sept 2014  at 4137 Piedmont Avenue
FAQs--ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
I’VE BEEN ASKED:
Why such a low
estimate on the ticket revenue and attendance? We based it on what we have brought in over the last 3 plays.  We sell some tickets on Goldstar for half price.   We discount a lot to bring people in. Hopefully, more tickets will be sold,
A lot of people have said that they didn’t know about us.  Hopefully, that will change when we have a season and can
sell subscriptions and “flexpasses.”
You can help remedy this: tell everyone you know that there
is live theatre on Piedmont Avenue!).
How much have we spent so far?
In the last year we have produced 3 plays and 3 staged
readings.                             We have spent over $35,000.  The Producer put up his own money to fund the productions.   None of the budget reflects any repayment of that amount.
Why is the rent so
low on Piedmont Avenue?
We would be sharing the space with another tenant.  We would have access on Saturday nights and
Sundays…which means we have to set up all the sets, lights, etc., then
dismantle everything each weekend.  
Thus our schedule of playing 3 performances per week on
Saturday evening , Sunday Matinee, and Sunday evening for 5 weeks per
production.
It’s too hard to park
on Piedmont Avenue
We go to the movies, we go to restaurants, we go to the
gyms, we go shopping, we go to the beauty parlor, and always find a place to park.                               HOWEVER, Wells Fargo has generously offered their 20 space
parking lot to us after their 6 pm closing.                                                                                                         We will offer this as a perk to the first 20 who contribute
$100 for the Reception, and to our first subscribers (when we get a full season and can sell subscriptions).
How do we select the plays?
As is usual, the artistic director
decides the season.  This year, we are
inviting our audience to weigh in on which plays they prefer from a list. 
John McMullen says, "Here is what I think about when selecting a
play: does it touch me emotionally and tickle my brain?  Do I have the actors to
play the roles? Will it make my audience want to come and see it? We have a
“company” of actors who we tend to consider when choosing plays. 
Why not apply for grants?
 It seems that you have to be in business for about three years before they take you seriously.   Lots of the money for arts grants has shrunk, but we will be applying soon. 
Can I deduct this?
If we raise the $13K, yes, you will
be able to deduct it from this year’s taxes.
We are awaiting our 501c3 nonprofit
status, but it is a sure thing and retroactive to when we incorporated.
If we don’t raise it, you get your
money back.
Who is behind all this?
Producer John McMullen has an MFA in
directing from Carnegie Mellon, and lots of experience acting, directing, and
teaching at Carnegie Mellon, City College of San Francisco, and Los Medanos
College.
For the last 4 years, he has been the
theatre critic for the Berkeley Daily Planet—but his theatre friends tease him
that, “He has come back from the dark side.”
If you don't have much, but love theatre:

Enough $10 contributions add up
Ask folks to get the word out and make some
     noise about this campaign.

Here’s hoping!
John McMullen
DONATE at the TOP RIGHT 
or
send your check to:  PORT, Box 20936, Oakland CA
94620 (please mail checks by March 28 so we can receive and process it before the deadline).

story:
Who are we?

We are a student led society ran by two second year drama students - Yasmine-Nadia Sebbah (President) and Chris Birks (Vice President). Our aim is to bring together the musical theatre fans of Edge Hill University and give them a chance to perform. EHU Musical Theatre Society is a new society for 2014, created with the intention of producing quality productions for the university students, staff, and local residents to enjoy. With over 160 people signing up at the univerity freshers' fair, 64 people auditioning, and 32 final cast members, our society has accomplished so much in such a short space of time.

What have we done?

As we are a new society we have currently only produced one production - Broadway, Here I Come, a musical theatre showcase featuring a variety of songs from many shows including Avenue Q, 9 to 5, Spring Awakening, Once, Rent, Matilda and many more. See the project video for a look at our production and see our hugely talented cast in action! BHIC started rehearsals in September and the show was performed on 13th December. This production was put together to get us started as a society and also our first fund raiser for this production of Rent.

What are we wanting to do?

To put it plain and simply - we want to produce a production of Rent the musical.

What is Rent?

Rent is a multi award-winning musical with book and lyrics by Jonathan Larson, loosely based on the opera La Boheme. Set in New York, Rent explores the lives of 8 people, focusing on themes such as HIV/AIDS, drug abuse, homosexuality, and poverty. Rent has won multiple awards including Tony Award for Best Musical, Drama Desk Awards, Pullitzer Prize for Drama, and Theatre World Awards.

Why Rent?

Rent was chosen for two reasons. First of all it's a hugely popular musical with an amazing score. Secondly, universities are a place where sex is extremely common and drugs can be easily accessible. The themes of AIDS and drug abuse in Rent can be used to spread awareness of the dangers of unprotected sex and drug use.

Why do we need the money?

As a university society we have no source of income. Anyone in the amateur theatre business knows that putting on a musical can be expensive.This is why we need your help to help fund our production. The costs of theatre hire, microphone hire, band hire, set hire, costumes, props, promotion materials and more all adds up very quickly. We are doing everything we can to fund raise and make this show unforgettable.

Why should I donate to this cause?

Our society is a place where any and all students of the university, no matter what course they are on, can come to perform and have fun. University can be a stressful place and our members come to us to unload their stress, forget about their problems, and spend one evening a week doing what they love. We give everyone the opportunity to shine, no matter what their performance background is. Supporting our Kickstarter campaign is giving a chance to let the students of EHU release their creative talents and escape the stress of university. Please, give anything you can to help a group of students do what they love.

story:
Who We Are

With a new year comes a brand new focus, the Limelight Theatre Company, bringing new works, new voices, and heartfelt stories to light centerstage. The Limelight Theatre Company was founded in response to the necessity for the continuation of the arts and uplifting the voices of our local artists and creators during a time of great challenge and change. The Limelight Theatre Company introduces its name with pride, as we emerge from a period of darkness with hopes to pave the way to more accessible, affordable, and enlightening dramatic art.

Join us and support us as we work to educate and enlighten our communities through the arts and place professional artists and creators in the limelight. The Limelight Theatre Company plans to provide an array of events in the future, including mainstage productions, staged readings, and concerts. Please support our mission by donating to our campaign. Your contribution will directly support the necessary funding to put artists and creators centerstage. We thank you and we welcome you to the Limelight Theatre Company.  ​

 

What We Need

Our fundraising goal is $11,000. All funds raised will go directly towards:

  • Production expenses for upcoming productions, staged readings and concerts
  • Licensing rights for theatrical works and concert materials 
  • Hiring of performers, musicians and creative designers
  • Operational expenses

 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a tremendous impact on the arts community. With many theaters shut down and permanently closed, artists and designers are out of work and the continuation of the arts is in jeopardy. This campaign will directly support the Limelight Theatre Company’s mission  by providing much-needed opportunities for professional artists and providing accessible and affordable arts experiences for communities in the Westchester, Putnam and the greater NY area. 
 

A Clear Road Ahead

Our mission at the Limelight Theatre Company is to stimulate, promote, teach and develop interest in the dramatic arts; to enlighten and educate the general public in the dramatic arts; to advance the general level of culture in the field of dramatic arts by the establishment and maintenance of a theater community for the production of plays, musicals, readings, dramas, comedies, shows, concerts, and dramatic arts in all forms and of the highest standards; and to bring all aspects of the dramatic arts to areas and centers not adequately served at the present time. Furthermore, the Limelight Theatre Company works to share and raise the voices and inclusivity of all artists, cultures, and backgrounds in our performing arts community.

Led by founder Stephanie Scuderi, the Limelight Theatre Company was created with this determined mission and will stop at nothing to fulfill it! Stephanie Scuderi is also the Executive Director of Spotlight Arts, Inc., a nationally recognized and award-winning youth theatre company where Stephanie directs many of their mainstage productions, and single-handedly led the company through the global pandemic over the past year with new and innovative ways to safely continue to bring theatre to its audiences and artists. Stephanie is also on faculty at Temple University where she teaches voice to their B.F.A. Musical Theatre students. Stephanie's most recent and notable experiences in New York as a performer were her leading roles as Alice in Frank Wildhorn’s revised version of WONDERLAND at the Frederick Loewe Theater in New York, NY directed by Tony Nominee and award-winning director Gabriel Barre and the role of Gabby in CITY OF ANGELS at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in New York, NY directed by David Alpert and music direction by Ana Flavia Zuim. Stephanie is thrilled to bring her expertise both onstage and behind the scenes to the Limelight Theatre Company to further their mission in the arts community. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some may not be able to contribute at this time. Will you help us by sharing this campaign link on social media or even just with two other people? Thank you for spreading the word and supporting our arts community!

Follow us on Twitter and Instagram to keep up with our latest projects and news! 
Visit our website for social links and more information: www.limelighttheatrecompany.com

story:
What is this "punk theatre" you refer to?

Diagnostic Theatre Company is seeking funding for its inaugural season of punk theatre. "Punk theatre", as we call it, are performances that are work-shopped and produced under a strict adherence to a set of DIY ethics:

  • DTC is a non-profit 501-c3 who donates its proceeds to charities and organizations that share our goals (i.e. Southern Poverty Law Center, Anti-Defamation League, Black Lives Matter, ACLU, Planned Parenthood, Hand in Hand for Syria).
  • Diagnostic believes that theatre, and "high art" in general, suffer from the haughty airs that surround it by excluding the wide swath of audience members who might be interested in attending, if only they could afford it. DTC believes you shouldn't need a disposable income to enjoy art and culture. There is no dress code, if you're a little late, you're fine.
  • Diagnostic Theatre Company will never have any corporate sponsorship. Ever. Funding is provided in part by grants and primarily through donations from supporters like you.
  • Admission to any and all DTC productions are pay-what-you-can in the form of donations to that show's selected charity and/or beneficiary.
  • DTC is committed to diversity and inclusion when it comes to casting, representation onstage, and the formation of original characters in new works. We firmly believe this is the way theatre, art, and America should be by default, so you will never see us making a hashtag out of it or exploiting it in any kind of marketing tactic to draw either crowds or funding.
  • DTC will prioritize the production of original works but will also produce new visions of classics, and productions of lesser-known modern works.
  • Street theatre workshopping of new works, house shows where available.
  • Hand-crafted/re-purposed/upcycled minimalist crowd-sourced sets, props, and costumes.
  • Original music by unsigned, DIY artists or Diagnostic artists only. Potential short musical sets by local punk bands before top of show and during intermissions.
  • Diagnostic believes in a power determined by the people, in an art that cannot be compromised. We believe, we will endure, and we will overcome.
  • Diagnostic is vehemently anti-fascist.

Quite transparently, Diagnostic is a leftist company. We make no effort to hide that and will understand if you decide this is a deal-breaker.

What We Need & What You Get

In short, Diagnostic needs the start-up capital to:

  • Pay artists and technicians a decent day rate
  • Rent rehearsal and performance spaces
  • Pay festival registration fees
  • Equipment cost and rental
  • Costumes and props
  • Royalties

The Impact

Contributions to Diagnostic Theatre's campaign will benefit the public by:

  • Providing live theatre for and inspired by the proletariat
  • Helping to sustain a culture of constructive resistance against the current administration
  • Peacefully protest the establishment through art and performance, rather than violence

Risks & Challenges

Obviously these are divisive times, and this is a potentially divisive stance for a non-profit to take. But Diagnostic is not intimidated by this culture of monologue, rather, we look forward to helping us all move towards a culture of dialogue. We are confident we can overcome these obstacles by:

  • Remaining steadfast in the belief in love and cooperation
  • Celebrating each other

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially to the campaign, please consider:

  • Coming to our shows
  • Express interest in helping out
  • Engaging your friends in conversations about the idea of a punk theatre
  • Follow, like, and share us on social media

Thank you for your time and consideration.

story:
Celebrating Diversity...

The Boulder Dance Coalition - the group that runs the Avalon Ballroom - knows that dance is not only good for our well-being but can also be a powerful bridge to better human understanding. Our mission is to promote public participation in dance and music which is realized through the annual Boulder International Festival. Communities can pass laws intended to curb xenophobic attitudes. Groups can have candlelight vigils, stand in solidarity at protests, and write editorials. But when people hold hands and dance with one another, attitudes can change within individuals.

Each year, we depend on donations from festival goers and various grants to help offset the cost of the festival that has become a Boulder tradition since the original Folkfest in 1981. (click here for more history) As a 501(c)3 non-profit, our budget has limitations and so we are reaching out to the public in hopes of raising funds to help sustain and grow the Boulder International Festival.

At the Boulder International Festival you’ll find some of the best talent in the state representing many flavors of dance and music, with performances, dance teaching and an emphasis on participation. The festival also hosts a world market featuring local artists and fair-trade art, jewelry, and handmade goods from around the world.

This year's festival is June 14-16, 2019. See the list of 2019 performers and vendors​!

 

But we can't do it without you...

The Boulder International Festival is a 3-day event, free and open to the public and all ages. Each half hour features a different dance performance, some with live music, ranging from cultural traditions of "village" life around the world to tango, waltz and Zumba demonstrations.

The festival kicks off with a public Salsa dance on Friday night followed by participatory international folk dancing with music by Barbelfish Balkan Band on Saturday evening with a variety of dance lessons and demonstrations from performers throughout the weekend.

To put this all together requires a budget of just over $10,000. We are hoping to raise $2,000 through crowdfunding to:

  • Provide the flexibility we need to focus our efforts on expanding the festival to include new audiences.
  • Ensure that we can continue to produce the festival.
  • Allow us to keep the festival FREE!

Here is a breakdown of the festival budget:

  • Location – space rental, electricity, restroom cleaning, permits $250.00
  • Advertising – flyer/poster design and editing, event promotion efforts $700.00
  • Printing – flyers, site maps, signage $650.00
  • Supplies – print/copy materials, postage, food $750.00
  • Staff – manager, staff, crew $3,500.00
  • Rentals – tent and chairs $1,650.00
  • Audio – systems, technicians, Saturday night band $1,800.00
  • Security – 2 security personnel for 2 nights $960.00

Each year local business and organizations help support the festival. The Boulder Dance Coalition thanks those who have already pledged to support the 2019 Boulder International Festival:

  • Boulder Body Wear
  • Boulder County
  • Boulder Daily Camera
  • City of Boulder
  • City of Boulder Human Relations Commission
  • Downtown Boulder
  • KGNU 88.5FM
  • Eldorado Natural Spring Water

 

 

Perks

BDC Friend – Everyone who contributes to the campaign will have their name added to the thank you display at the festival.

 

The Impact...

The Boulder International Festival promotes openness, diversity, inclusivity, and exploration - things that are good for our psyches and our communities, just as dancing is good for the body. Communities around the world are in need of unity, even in Boulder which has an educated, world-traveled, left-leaning population. There have been threats called in to the Jewish Community Center and racist tagging around town among other overt expressions of prejudice. Many of these intolerant opinions stem from lack of opportunity to get to know people from other cultures, and therefore we feel the festival is more important than ever.

We believe that if people hold hands and dance; actually experience the energy generated by participating in the brief experience of being inside the culture the change of attitude will happen from within the individual.

 

Other Ways You Can Help...

Even if you can't donate, please help us spread the word! Share this link and let people know about the Boulder International Festival and be sure to come to the Pearl Street Mall June 14-16 and dance!
