Groups can have candlelight vigils, stand in solidarity at protests, and write editorials. But when people hold hands and dance with one another, attitudes can change within individuals.
Each year, we depend on donations from festival goers and various grants to help offset the cost of the festival that has become a Boulder tradition since the original Folkfest in 1981. (click here for more history) As a 501(c)3 non-profit, our budget has limitations and so we are reaching out to the public in hopes of raising funds to help sustain and grow the Boulder International Festival.
At the Boulder International Festival you’ll find some of the best talent in the state representing many flavors of dance and music, with performances, dance teaching and an emphasis on participation. The festival also hosts a world market featuring local artists and fair-trade art, jewelry, and handmade goods from around the world.
This year's festival is June 14-16, 2019. See the list of 2019 performers and vendors​! But we can't do it without you...
The Boulder International Festival is a 3-day event, free and open to the public and all ages. Each half hour features a different dance performance, some with live music, ranging from cultural traditions of "village" life around the world to tango, waltz and Zumba demonstrations.
The festival kicks off with a public Salsa dance on Friday night followed by participatory international folk dancing with music by Barbelfish Balkan Band on Saturday evening with a variety of dance lessons and demonstrations from performers throughout the weekend.
To put this all together requires a budget of just over $10,000. We are hoping to raise $2,000 through crowdfunding to:

Provide the flexibility we need to focus our efforts on expanding the festival to include new audiences.
Ensure that we can continue to produce the festival.
Allow us to keep the festival FREE!

Here is a breakdown of the festival budget:

Location – space rental, electricity, restroom cleaning, permits $250.00
Advertising – flyer/poster design and editing, event promotion efforts $700.00
Printing – flyers, site maps, signage $650.00
Supplies – print/copy materials, postage, food $750.00
Staff – manager, staff, crew $3,500.00
Rentals – tent and chairs $1,650.00
Audio – systems, technicians, Saturday night band $1,800.00
Security – 2 security personnel for 2 nights $960.00

Each year local business and organizations help support the festival. The Boulder Dance Coalition thanks those who have already pledged to support the 2019 Boulder International Festival:

Boulder Body Wear
Boulder County
Boulder Daily Camera
City of Boulder
City of Boulder Human Relations Commission
Downtown Boulder
KGNU 88.5FM
Eldorado Natural Spring Water

 

 
Perks
BDC Friend – Everyone who contributes to the campaign will have their name added to the thank you display at the festival. The Impact...
The Boulder International Festival promotes openness, diversity, inclusivity, and exploration - things that are good for our psyches and our communities, just as dancing is good for the body. Communities around the world are in need of unity, even in Boulder which has an educated, world-traveled, left-leaning population. There have been threats called in to the Jewish Community Center and racist tagging around town among other overt expressions of prejudice. Many of these intolerant opinions stem from lack of opportunity to get to know people from other cultures, and therefore we feel the festival is more important than ever.
We believe that if people hold hands and dance; actually experience the energy generated by participating in the brief experience of being inside the culture the change of attitude will happen from within the individual. Other Ways You Can Help...
Even if you can't donate, please help us spread the word! Share this link and let people know about the Boulder International Festival and be sure to come to the Pearl Street Mall June 14-16 and dance!

story:
In a community dominated by Mexican agricultural workers, it can be hard to feel as if you have a future outside field work. When I was little I didn’t think I would have anything to offer or if there was even a reason to offer any special skills since I was just going to end up working in the fields like the rest of my family. My parents though decided that I should sign up for clubs or sports so that I could get out and talk to people. So in the second grade they signed me up for a folklorico group, Juventud Latina Genesis, and I fell in love. This will be my eleventh year in the group and I can honestly say that it has changed my life. The chaos and time that comes with dancing taught me how to balance my time so that I could do my school-work, volunteer, and participate in other events. I also learned to not get nervous in front of crowds, a skill that is necessary when in school and planning to give many class presentations. Had I not signed up for dancing, I might not have grown up to try new things, like learning five languages, being a part of school plays, volunteering at camps and churches, and many different clubs in our school.

Knowing how dance affected me, I wanted to provide that same experience for other families who could not afford to pay for the type of classes I took and am still currently taking. There is a real need for children to fill their days with some sort of activity, to make good habits, to keep them off the streets and away from gangs, I joined a team of people who wanted to give a free dancing experience too and we started a dance group in a church, Our Lady Help of Christians. We gained a lot of support for creating it at a church because a majority of the families are also Catholic because not only would their love of dancing grow, so would their faith in God.

I have created this campaign so that we might buy our students dresses and shoes for future showcases because I believe that no money should have to come from the parent’s pocket. We would appreciate any kind of pledge you are able to make and we will always remember that you helped children’s futures glow brighter.

story:
Who we are and what we do:

We are Joe, Poppy and Molly, the core team behind The Cardboard Rocketship, a brand new theatre company based in Manchester, producing exciting and relevant work by young people. We set up at the start of lockdown to give young creatives a way to stay creative and collaborative, and create relevant and immediate theatre from young peoples' perspective. We are raising money to help get us off the ground, and what we raise will first and foremost go towards setting ourselves up as a community interest company and producing our second project, a piece which heavily relies on a printed element. The piece will be a celebration and exploration of young people's relationship to protest. All profits made from  it will go towards charities supporting and championing equality and intersectionality in the UK. Anything left over from fundraising will be put into delivering further projects, events and engagement activities such as workshops. Our main aim as a company is to give young people the space and opportunity to make work that is relevant and exciting to them.

What we are fundraising for:

We are trying to raise £500. This will be more than enough to cover the printing costs for our second project, set ourselves up as a community interest company and begin to deliver an exciting, diverse and inclusive programme of online (for now) events and opportunities for young theatre makers and creatives. This is an extremely tough time for theatre, and it is more than likely that one of the aspects of theatre's that could suffer the most is their youth programmes, which are extremely important to thousands of young theatre makers, performers and writers across the country, including us. In an uncertain time, we are aiming to provide a space for these young people to thrive, allowing them to keep creative, develop their skills and make work that is relevant and vital to them.

The reason we’re fundraising:

Up until now, we have been self-financing the company and it's activities ourselves. This is something we are more than happy to do, but as young people this takes up a sizeable proportion of our income. As we want to reach out to more and more young people to get involved, and produce our work in various formats, it is becoming increasingly unviable to finance this ourselves. Any support you can provide would be invaluable and vital.

Other ways you can help:

 If you can't donate, but still want to help out, there are a number of ways you can:

- Give us advice! If you are a theatre professional or have any knowledge of running a small (or any other sized) arts organisation, any advice and expertise you could lend us would be extremely helpful. We are young creatives, and certainly not business people or managing directors. Chat to us on twitter @TCRocketship or via email at contact@thecardboardrocketship.co.uk

- Share the word! However you can, tell your friends and family, share us on social media. We want both people who want to get involved and people who want to support us to hear about us. As many as possible!

- Volunteer with us! We are currently looking for a company manager/producer, if you think you'd enjoy and suit this role, please get in touch with a CV at contact@thecardboardrocketship.co.uk with the subject header 'Company Manager Role'. If you’ve got any other skills, be that creative or in business, and would like the volunteer - please also let us know! 

Social investor:

If you're considering donating £40 or more, you can choose to request a private Zoom meeting with one of our core team to talk about The Cardboard Rocketship, our vision for it and how your money will be spent in as much detail as you'd like. Email us at contact@thecardboardrocketship.co.uk to book. Requesting or having a meeting does not mean you are obliged to donate the specified amount.

Any further questions:

If you have any questions about donating and what the money will be used for, or anything else, please get in touch! contact@thecardboardrocketship.co.uk

story:
Monuments Community Tour 2018: LEAR  

Hi there!
My name is Adam Boyle, and I am the Artistic Director of Bears & Vagabonds Productions. We at Bears & Vagabonds are dedicated to championing important social and ethical causes through theatre and community. 

We are currently gearing up for our next community Shakespeare tour. This year our production will be Shakespeare's King Lear, which we will be bringing to community venues throughout Greater London, East Anglia & Kent.


The production will be offered to communities on a 'pay what you feel' basis to help encourage engagement through  the arts from more non-traditional theatre goers - so, basically, people can come for free!

Lear will be an up-to-date production of William Shakespeare’s ‘King Lear’, exploring themes of home, homeless and the refugee crisis.
The production will follow the story of a female Lear, who divides her land between her three daughters tracking the breakdown of her relationships with these daughters and other friends, and the loss of her home, largely due to her own battle with mental health, whilst also exploring the effect that this has on those around them.  

We are targeting our production for community audiences, and want to make it as accessible as possible.   It will be a playful, ensemble piece, including folk singing, puppetry and physical theatre, whilst bringing out the comedy of the piece.

A percentage of the donated box office will be donated to our chosen charity for this production, Emmaus. Emmaus is a fantastic homeless charity, which gives an opportunity for people to work their way out of homelessness, providing meaningful work as well as a stable home for as long as someone needs it.  You can learn more about Emmaus here: https://www.emmaus.org.uk/

We ran a successful small-scale tour early this year of two Shakespeare plays-in-rep (The Winter’s Tale and Richard II), raising £300 for The Mental Health Foundation. This time we want to up our game. We have more community venues lined up, we will be engaging with more people, offering free educational workshops alongside the performances, and hope to raise even more money for our chosen charities.

Please do take a look at our incentives and do what you can to support our project. Every little really does help. Please do also check us out on social media on the links below, and come check out one of our performances.

Thanks!

Bears & Vagabonds Productions

www.bearsandvagabonds.wix.com/2017
Facebook /Bearsandvagabonds
Instagram @bears_and_vagabonds
Twitter @Bears_Vagabonds

story:
Short Summary

We are a playwright/director/producer team presenting the reading of a new play in NYC. "Addison & the Black Hole" is the story of Travis Tannehill, a rattled, eight-year veteran of the war in Afghanistan who returns home to family in crisis. "Addison" explores family, duty, love, war, and the darkest corners of the human heart. This powerful new work is presented in partnership with Lincoln Center Education and The Society for Artistic Veterans.

We have the space. We have the actors. We believe the play has an audience. All we need is your help to make this reading a success. You'll be supporting new theatre at the ground level, getting "Addison" in front of producers, investors, and other backers who want to produce bold new plays.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need $1000 to pay our actors, director, producer, and playwright.
  • We need $400 to pay for audition, rehearsal, and reading space.
  • We need $200 for script and marketing material printing (postcards).
  • We need $400 to fly the playwright from Tulsa to NYC for rehearsals and the reading.

The Impact

  • One of our major visions for future productions of "Addison" is civilian-veteran artistic collaborations. We also believe in bringing awareness to mental health for veterans suffering from PTSD and other post-war trauma.
  • This reading has the potential to spark interest among theatre producers and investors looking to produce plays about the veteran experience. You're also employing quality theatre artists to bring the play to life for veteran and civilian audiences. 
  • By donating, you are personally investing in the life of a new play. Imagine seeing a future production of "Addison" and knowing that you were vital in making that happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute financially, you can help us by SHARING THIS CAMPAIGN with those who also want to be a part of making new theatre possible!
  • And you can help us GET THE WORD OUT about the reading on May 25th at Lincoln Center in NYC!

story:
Short Summary

We are Georgia Goodman and Lance C. Fuller and together founded the Eagle & Beaver Ensemble, a London based theatre company seeking to bring North America closer to Europe.

We are both actors as well as producers, individually, before finding each other and deciding to unite!  Georgia succesfully produced a short run of Fat Girl by Neil LaBute a couple of years ago, and currently has several film scripts in various stages of production.  Lance has also successfully produced many shows, including some with his improv group.

We decided to create the Eagle & Beaver Ensemble as a way to highlight all the North American talent in London as well as Europe.  The thirst for American-centric shows keeps growing and we felt that the real North American talent here should be given a platform.  We also wanted to give a platform for emerging playwrights in the United States and Canada, and the opportunity to have a show staged at a London theatre.

Our first production, Tiny Shorts, is based around the themes of "independence" and "freedom" to coincide with Canada Day (July 1st) and United Stated Independence Day (July 4th).  All the plays were commissioned around these themes.

Our production will be the official launch of our company and there is no better place than the award winning theatre, The Union Theatre to house us.  We envisage this production to be the start of similar productions in the future, based around typical North American key themes from holidays (have you heard of Peanut Butter & Jelly Day?) to weird customs.  You might even see the odd Mountie.

As producers, we are keen to give our cast members a great experience, and your wonderful contribution can help us achieve this, along with the initial seed money donated by the American Actors UK organisation (AAUK).  Requests could be anything from:

-  giving them a safe rehearsal place where they can explore the plays and their characters, and relieve the stress of trying to find rehearsal space. Most rehearsal space in London will go between £15 to £30 an hour.  As we'll have 8 plays and a cast of almost 20, that's a lot of hours!
- any props/costumes needed for their chosen play
- clearance on any music we might need to play on the night
- a technician for light and sound
- any insurance needed

And probably countless other issues that will no doubt arise.  This contingency pot will put everyone's minds at ease, and the directors and actors can focus on what they do best: giving us the best performance possible.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise £500 or anything close to that amount.  This would go towards:

- hiring audition and rehearsal space for the directors and cast

- technical and art department requirements

We have amazing perks that we hope will excite you as well.  Especially Lance's headshot session - a must for any actor in London!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution doesn't have to be monetary.  We would be incredibly grateful if you would spread the word and share to link to this fundraising page to as many people as you can! 

Yes, your grandmother too, and that aunt you haven't called in a while!

Every pound counts.

story:
Amennyiben az elkövetkező két hónapban Magyarországon 

az aktív kereső korban lévők közül 

minden huszadik ember utal egyetlen dollárt, 

azaz kevesebb, mint 300 forintot, akkor jelen kampány célösszege össze fog gyűlni.


275.000 magyar embert keresünk



Amennyiben az elkövetkező két hónapban Magyarországon 

az aktív kereső korban lévők közül 

minden kétszázadik ember utal 10 dollárt, 

akkor jelen kampány célösszege össze fog gyűlni.




27.500 magyar embert keresünk,

akinek van 10 dollárja - egy átlagos éttermi ebéd ára arra -, hogy a szívére hallgasson.

És aki hallgat a szívére, annak mi adunk valami mást is, amit hallgathat: készítettünk néhány hangoskönyvet.


Az összegyűlt pénzzel a Magyarországra menekült rászorulókon segítünk.



Adj, hogy üdvözülj!

Ez a karma törvényének alkalmazása.

A középkorban az emberek olyannyira hittek benne, hogy búcsúcédulákat vásároltak az Egyháztól. Pénzt adtak az Egyháznak azért, hogy az, mint egy "cég" megszabadítsa őket bűneiktől isten színe előtt.

Az már mindegy, hogy HOGYAN adsz. Természetben vagy pénzben. Ahogy neked kényelmesebb.
Ha neked az kényelmesebb, hogy személyesen viszel ételt, italt, jó szót a menekülteknek, akkor tedd ezt.
Ha te erre nem érsz rá, és egyébként is, inkább fizetsz profi segítőcsapatnak, akkor utalj pénzt. Mi nem csinálunk mást, mint összegyűjtjük és professzionális segítőket bízunk meg a feladattal.

Mi is gyűjtünk, mások is gyűjtenek. Mi ezt az üzenetet fűzzük a gyűjtési akciónkhoz és azoknak az adományait várjuk, akiket személyesen megérintett az üzenetünk.
Az emberek abban nem tévedtek, hogy fizettek az Egyháznak. Abban tévedtek, hogy kecskére bízták a káposztát.

Nem bújhatsz ki ez alól.
Jó tett helyébe jót várj! Isten nem ver bottal. E két alternatívát kínálja az élet.
Adj, hogy üdvözülj!

































Nem adsz?

De akkor ne csodálkozz, hogy nincs szerencséd...
story_txt:
Amennyiben az elkövetkező két hónapban Magyarországon az aktív kereső korban lévők közül minden huszadik ember utal egyetlen dollárt, azaz kevesebb, mint 300 forintot, akkor jelen kampány célösszege össze fog gyűlni. 

275.000 magyar embert keresünk



Amennyiben az elkövetkező két hónapban Magyarországon 
az aktív kereső korban lévők közül 
minden kétszázadik ember utal 10 dollárt, 
akkor jelen kampány célösszege össze fog gyűlni.




27.500
magyar embert keresünk, 

akinek
van 10 dollárja - egy átlagos éttermi ebéd ára arra -, hogy a
szívére hallgasson.

És
aki hallgat a szívére, annak mi adunk valami mást is, amit
hallgathat: készítettünk néhány hangoskönyvet.

Az
összegyűlt pénzzel a Magyarországra menekült rászorulókon
segítünk.


Adj, hogy üdvözülj!

Ez a karma törvényének alkalmazása.

A középkorban az emberek olyannyira hittek benne, hogy búcsúcédulákat vásároltak az Egyháztól. Pénzt adtak az Egyháznak azért, hogy az, mint egy "cég" megszabadítsa őket bűneiktől isten színe előtt.

Az már mindegy, hogy HOGYAN adsz. Természetben vagy pénzben. Ahogy neked kényelmesebb.Ha neked az kényelmesebb, hogy személyesen viszel ételt, italt, jó szót a menekülteknek, akkor tedd ezt.Ha te erre nem érsz rá, és egyébként is, inkább fizetsz profi segítőcsapatnak, akkor utalj pénzt. Mi nem csinálunk mást, mint összegyűjtjük és professzionális segítőket bízunk meg a feladattal.

Mi is gyűjtünk, mások is gyűjtenek. Mi ezt az üzenetet fűzzük a gyűjtési akciónkhoz és azoknak az adományait várjuk, akiket személyesen megérintett az üzenetünk.Az emberek abban nem tévedtek, hogy fizettek az Egyháznak. Abban tévedtek, hogy kecskére bízták a káposztát.

Nem bújhatsz ki ez alól.Jó tett helyébe jót várj! Isten nem ver bottal. E két alternatívát kínálja az élet.Adj, hogy üdvözülj!

































Nem adsz?
De akkor ne csodálkozz, hogy nincs szerencséd...

story:
The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

This project will successfully bridge the boarders of performing arts and education in unusual way, in our workshops young people will get to physically experience the power of theatre through classes in their schools, in a way which has inspired many a student in the UK as a result of a Joint Stock theatre, Frantic Assembly or Rambert workshop. The second key part of this project is working with teachers in Kunungu, in partnership with Limited Resource Teacher Training (LRTT)to build their confidence as educational drama specialists allowing teachers to further increase the tools in their toolbox to deliver inclusive and engaging education across the curriculum.

The final, but imperative aspect is a performance of a well known play which will go through a new treatment in rehearsal, where the actors and director will explore the boundaries of their skills and knowledge as African theatre and European theatre techniques merge.

Who:

Lucinda Bray is a UK based theatre director, facilitator and teacher who has worked in regional theatre in the UK for over 10 years. She has produced and directed a broad range of productions working with actors with a variety of training and experience.  She is specialises in devising.

 As an educator she has been working in formal and informal education settings since 2006, often using drama as a teaching tool, particularly for language teaching, or the exploration of issues such as relationships and bullying. 

Benjamin Egesa Osipo is the other half of the production team and is based in Kampala UGANDA.

He is a radio journalist and a sports commentator with Uganda Broadcasting Corporation 's Sports Channel Magic 100fm. 

As a performing artist, he was trained and performed with the world renowned Ndere Troupe and as such bares an acute understanding of the African traditions, culture and performing arts.

An extremely versatile performer with a gift for words, this will be his return to the performing arts after a seven year sabbatical and will in essence be tasked with linking the unique dramatic techniques brought forth by Lucinda to the cultural context within the script and reproduce a masterpiece.

Product:

Written in the 1970’s Betrayal in the City sensitively draws out the challenges of creating a Nation; new culture, new societal hierarchies, who are the friends and who are the foe? How do you respect the past whilst moving forward?  

The cast will be entirely Ugandan with a British director, this cross cultural collaboration will allow for a new interpretation of a text which may be well known to the audience. It will also allow for experimentation with dramatic technique. Utilising the skills and experience of the cast and merging this with European approaches to theatre.

Process

The theatrical styles of Britain and Uganda and the rehearsal processes can be quite different, the collaboration between cast and director offers the chance to explore these differences and take risks in rehearsal to create a production of the play that offers something new to both sides and the audience, however well they know the play.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a budget of £3000 to cover costs of the project which include:

  • Fees for our hardworking actors and equally important stage team.
  • Equipment hire
  • The creation of our simple but fabulous set.
  • Logistics including transport to rural and inner city schools, accommodation during teacher training workshops.

If we do not meet our goal the funds will still be used to carry out the project, but it will be much harder to create our vision.

Your financial support for the project will yield a variety of rewards including producer credits and video footage from rehearsal and interviews or couching from the director.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

There are a number of challenges of this project the major one is the director being so far away until the last minute, it creates additional issues with casting and the usual challenges of producing  a play are heightened by this. The timescale of delivery is very tight, all parties will be working together very closely to ensure that the project is a success.

Fortunately the challenges are the sort the team are used to working with; small budgets, a lack of time and a great deal of unknowns. Lucinda is particularly adept at working with a lack of resources, having produced plays in a week before, including the renovation of non-theatre spaces into a comfortable performance venue. She has experience working abroad most recently working for Limited Resource Teacher Training in Guyana during 2016.

Benjemin has a track record of bringing together excellent creative teams in Kampala as well as excellent contacts within the creative industries there.

At the heart of our work is a sense of collaboration which cannot fail to yield results.

Other Ways You Can Help

Or come and see Here We Are at the Maddermarket Theatre dramatized and directed by Lucinda Bray to raise money for the project. If you can’t donate but believe in our project do not despair, you can still help us out there and share this page with your friends through Facebook and Twitter. Follow Betrayal in the City page on Facebook to keep up with our activities and keep liking and sharing what you see!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! 

My name is Emelia Koberg and I am in love with dance. I have been since I was a child but I allowed myself to get pulled in other directions, other people's ideas of what and who I should become. I didn't listen to the voice inside that wanted to express through movement my thoughts and feelings especially about injustice in the world, the contradictions of pain and pleasure, of desires and of love. 

Last year I finally realized I could no longer ignore this voice and went to study dance and Somatics in Finland despite the empty bank account and threw myself whole heartedly into the passion of moving, finding new limits and new abilities. In March I attended a life-changing 2 week dance training called Depth Movement with Edivaldo Ernesto that pushed my physical, emotional and psychological limits. We danced 4 hours straight everyday without a break, finding more and more power from a deep source within; a desire to express, to play, to feel, to be fully alive.  In June, I attended another training with the maestro of floorwork, David Zambrano and again I was challenged to new lengths, finding ways to gather and send energy, to feel stress and joy at the same time, to connect deeply to myself while connecting to the whole group. This training is about new ways of being and relating to ourselves and to each other in the world. 

I came to Greece to train with fellow dancer and teacher to train and begin collaborating with Vicky Angelidou. I had of course heard about Exin, a 1 month long training with David Zambrano assisted by Edivaldo Ernesto and Milan Herich that she and many others I know are attending. I had not applied because I didn't have the money or the belief I would be really ready. A week after arriving and training with Vicky, I was encouraged by a fellow dancer from the Barcelona training to write to them because he heard of a cancellation. I didn't think I would get in with the course starting September 1st since other people are on the waiting list but low and behold I was. 

You can read more about it here:

https://www.exindance.com/page2

The Impact

I am turning 30 September 23rd, an important marker in life. There is no better present I could imagine than dancing for 7 hours everyday with inspiring teachers and other dancers from all over the world. With this training, I know I will emerge as a new person and dancer and performer. This leads me to the second part of the dream: to start an intercultural dance project creating performances and teaching youth from different backgrounds, cultures and  experiences. I plan to start this in Sweden first and expand to other places. 

What I Need & What You Get

The training has naturally some costs: it is €2400 which includes accommodation, food and of course the teaching. Maybe that seems like a lot of money but it is basically a condensed study year but more powerful because of its immersive nature and working so closely with the teachers and other students. I assure you I will dance my ass off for every cent I receive. 

I am also applying for a travel grant from the Swedish Arts Council, however, it takes 6-8 weeks to process and I have no guarantee if I will receive it. If I do, I will ask you how you would like the money to be used, for example, I could use it to to offer more classes and workshops and make videos of performances/research. 

In return, I will offer dance classes and workshops that you can either attend or provide a scholarship to someone who would not otherwise be able to attend. 

If you are more interested in acroyoga, yoga or meditation, I will offer some classes that you can attend in person or as a video recording. 

 

EVen MORE about me

ÉMÉ LÍA KOBERG (Sweden/Canada) is a dancer and performer, yoga and acroyoga teacher moving and working internationally. Her work is inspired by play, connection, pleasure and pain. With a background in teaching movement and languages, she is moved to create experiences that invite new pathways to self-awareness, communication and authenticity. Her performative practice engages with public and unseen places through authentic movement, improvisation, storytelling, acrobatics and touch. Navigating between “professional” and activist worlds in international development, gender and sexuality and education; she is interested in personal and social exploration of belonging, power structures, gender and sexuality and nature and construction of truth.

story:
Welcome to The Box Theatre Company of Oconomowoc!

Managing Artistic Directors Allison Chicorel and Timothy J. Barnes are thrilled to announce the premiere of "The Wind in the Willows". The adventures of Rat, Mole, and Mr. Toad will be told through spectacular song and dance.  

The Box Theatre Company targets people of all ages and seeks to cast youth actors and provide them a space to learn all aspects of the theatrical arts while providing a safe and encouraging environment.  

The cast of Wind in the Willows features two adult actors, Timothy J. Barnes and Connor O'Hara and 25 youth actors.  This challenging show will begin rehearsals January 21st with opening weekend on March 1st!

Campaign contributions for this show will be used for the following: paid musicians, scenery, costumes, professional lighting design, and will cover the increasing cost of the production rights. 

Every individual or business who donates to this campaign will be mentioned in our Playbill.  The show runs the entire month of March with 15 performances scheduled.  

Thank you for your continued support of local theatre and our emerging junior talent!

 

Allison Chicorel and Timothy J. Barnes

story:
He started the Sexual Revolution and believed he discovered the energy of life itself…

In the end, he was hounded and imprisoned, and became the only citizen and scientist in American history to have his work burned by both the Nazis and the U.S. government…

The Last of Wilhelm Reich brings to life the dramatic saga of a visionary, tormented genius who wanted to change the world, but was met with ridicule and persecution.

In this stirring new play, Wilhelm Reich, controversial proponent of orgone energy, enlists the audience in a quest for the truth. “The whole world,” Reich declares, “may call you mad, but it is only true if you are wrong!”

What if that truth is not acknowledged or understood for centuries? For Reich, it meant facing ostracism and arrest to pursue his vision of a better world. 

In The Last of Wilhelm Reich, he relives the chronicle of his life and loves – the traumatic suicide of his mother; the fears of abandonment that begin in childhood and haunt him through adulthood; the tempestuous, conflicted relationships he has with his father, brother, wives, and children; the initial triumphs of his scientific and socio-political achievements, including Character Analysis and the Sexual Revolution; and the repression of his theory of orgone energy, leading to persecution, imprisonment, and the actual burning of his life’s work.

The Last of Wilhelm Reich has a cinematic, stream-of-conscious structure, as Reich communicates directly with audience members and guides them through scenes of his life history. His guidance, however, is challenged by a Lear-like struggle to hold on in the face of personal and political torment.

Reich’s tragic life ends with death in prison – but his passionate refusal to cower or abandon his beliefs remains courageous and inspiring. 

What Is Needed

After a year of workshop development, your help is needed to bring this play to life – first Off-Broadway, and then on tour around the world.

This is a "Fixed Funding" campaign, and there are 60 days to reach the funding goal. If the initial funding goal is not reached, all contributions will be returned to you by Indiegogo. Once the funding goal is reached, the campaign will attain "In Demand" status after 60 days, so Stretch Goals can continue to be funded.

The starting budget of $125,000 will fund a limited run at an Off-Broadway theater.

Stretch goals will finance the hiring of an illustrious cast and production team, a special effects budget, and an expanded advertising campaign.

“Dream” casting for Wilhelm Reich includes:

Brian Dennehy 

Stellan Skarsgard


Christopher Plummer

Michael Gambon

Nick Nolte

Anthony Hopkins

About the Author

Drew Denbaum has been an award-winning writer, director, and actor in theater, film, and television for over forty years. His complete bios can be read on Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drew_Denbaum) and The Dramatists Guild (http://www.dramatistsguild.com/memberdirectory/getmembership.aspx?cid=40614).

Budget Breakdown

A Last Word about Reich...

Reich’s tragedy is that his genius was traumatized by internal as well as external torments. Nonetheless, he was visionary, big-hearted, and courageously productive. Reich’s character analysis is still practiced by therapists around the world – as is orgone therapy – and, as his daughter Eva says near the end of the play, “new research is validating much of his work [and] illuminating the way to the future…In the end, he could still be right!” 

With your help, Reich may yet get the recognition he deserves.

Risks & Challenges

All of the workshop productions of The Last of Wilhelm Reich have met with audience acclaim, but there is no guarantee of critical success. While the script calls for a simple setting augmented by dynamic lighting and sound design, it can also be produced with a more complex, multi-level set and the use of projections and special effects throughout the play. The funding of Stretch Goals will help to ensure that audiences throughout the country and around the world have a chance to attend The Last of Wilhelm Reich and appreciate the life of this remarkable man. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word about this campaign. Thank you!

story:
Who are we?

Combining the artistic visions of Manchester based visual artist, Howl Creative, and Leeds based companies, LSMarley and Brink Dance Company, “Howl” is a collaborative project that aims to create engaging, socially conscious and communicative art that represents modern day youth culture and speaks for the young people of today. More information can be found on each of the organisations here:

 

https://www.facebook.com/howlcreative.uk/

https://www.facebook.com/Brinkdanceco/

https://www.facebook.com/LSMarley1/

 

Through a continuous creative relationship Brink Dance Company and Howl Creative have investigated the collaboration between visual and performance art inspired by personal interests in rave and youth subcultures. After successfully applying to the SHINE Emerging Artists programme and receiving a small cash bursary, the collaborators were provided the opportunity to exhibit at Light Night Leeds and Lightwaves Festival, Manchester.

 

Meeting at the company’s research and development residential, LSMarley and his unique compositional soundscapes became the third artistic voice of Howl, providing an otherworldly and experimental depth to the work, whilst capturing the music trends of youth culture today.

 

We are launching a crowdfunding campaign to ensure the highest quality of work can be produced, therefore we are in need of specialist equipment to achieve this aim. Contributors donations will enable us to create this thrilling, engaging and powerful experience for our audiences.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

As stated above, the main reason we are crowdfunding is so we can purchase specialised equipment for the installation. This equipment is as follows:

 

High quality PA system for LSMarley’s music that can handle heavy bass.

Mesh screen that allows the animation to be projected onto but also allows the dancers to be seen behind.

High quality projector for the animation.

 

Fortunately, we have been supported through the SHINE bursary, so our fundraising target is £750 (although, if we do raise more than this, this means we’ll be able to invest in other things such as costumes, which currently the dancers are sourcing themselves).

 

However, we don’t want to just take your money and not give you anything in return! Below is our list of perks for when you donate a certain amount:

 

£5 – You get a personalised thank you across Brink Dance Company’s social media

£15 – You receive a signed photo of the artists involved

£30 – You receive a copy of rehearsal footage taken from our residency at the HopBarn in Newark.

 

The Impact

 

Without people’s contributions, the art will not reach its fullest potential in creating the best and most enriching experiences for its audiences. The equipment we need to make this possible is essential to the final outcome of our work and we know any contributions will greatly support the integrity and quality of the piece.

 

We want to ensure the work speaks true for the younger generations whilst bringing people together through an intimate and exciting experience. Through our chosen mediums, we hope to encourage more people to engage with contemporary art and use our artistic vision to celebrate young people and human experiences. It is very rare that art takes into full consideration the reality of young people, and this is a real opportunity to develop a new generation of interest in socially conscious, high quality art. If the experience is not as good as we hope it to be, we risk missing out on this audience and fully communicating our message as creatives.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We appreciate that not everyone has money to spare. While we value donations of any amount, we would also massively appreciate it if you shared this campaign across your own networks on our behalf.

 

Also, as part of this campaign we will be running a number of fundraising activities, so if you feel you’d rather not just donate, but want an experience to go along with it, then please check out our events! To find out more about these we will be shouting about them here:

 

@howl_creative

@brinkdancecompany

 

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and thank you in advance for any support you can give us.

 

The “Howl” Creative team

story:
Poetinis žygis pėsčiomis per Lietuvą prasidės gegužės 8 d. Klaipėdoje ir baigsis gegužės 27d Vilniuje. Aplankysim: Priekulę, Saugas, Šilutę, Katyčius, Pagėgius, Vilkyškius, Smalininkus, Jurbarką, Gelgaudiškį, Veliuoną, Vilkiją, Raudondvarį, Kauną, Karmėlavą, Jonavą, Ruklą, Čiobiškį, Kernavę. Kiekviename mieste ar miestelyje bus nemokamai rodomi poetiniai, muzikiniai, improvizaciniai vakarai: ,,vakaras P" ir ,,vakaras O" , kurių pagrindą sudaro lietuvių poetų: G. Grajausko, V. Stankaus, S. Gedos, D. Kajoko, D. Grajausko, J. Meko, V. Braziūno, R. Stankevičiaus ir M. Nastaravičiaus kūryba, bei Balio ir Artūro muzika ir istorijos. Bus parodyta 15 ,,vakarų P" ir 4 ,,vakarų O" ir nueita 400km.

 

Keliaus trys žmonės:

Balys Ivanauskas - profesionalus aktorius dirbantis įvairiuose Lietuvos teatruose (LNDT, ,,Pojūčių teatras", ,,Utopia", Kauno miesto kamerinis teatras), bei nepriklausomuose teatriniuose projektuose.

Artūras Dubaka - profesionalus aktorius, bei muzikantas, S. Mykolaičio premijos laureatas, dirbantis įvairiuose teatruose (VMT, Juozo Miltinio dramos teatras), bei įvairiuose kūrybiniuose projektuose. Taip pat dirba klounu organizacijoje ,,Raudonos nosys - Gydytojai klounai".

Edvinas Bandorius - operatorius.

story:
Short Summary

We're producing a short film featuring some great, esteemed dancers and some original music that is set in New Orleans, LA. The film will utilize creative collaboration to increase the exposure of, and to attract a new donor base to, the arts and music foundation that we are working on behalf of so they can better fulfill their objective: giving funding and resources to school music and art programs across the country.

While the foundation we are working with is funding the production of this film the best they can, the funds they extended do not cover some of the essentials needed for producing this piece. Namely, travel and food for all of the cast and crew that we are asking to contribute their time and resources.

What We Need & What You Get

It's simple, really. We need just $2000 in order to get this film created.

In return, we'll add your name as a special thanks to the credits of this film, plus our many thanks and gratitude for making such an impact.

story:
Summary

DAPA Performing Arts is one of Perth's premier performing arts schools. This year our kids will be putting on a show at Alexandra Theatre in Victoria Park.

Performing Arts has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic but we want to make sure we keep our kids developing their talents, singing and dancing and achieving the extraordinary. In times like these we need to ensure as a community that we support and empower the arts.

The David Academy of Performing Arts has strived over the years to deliver to students the highest quality of performing arts education available. DAPA’s director, Andre David has been directing and producing critically acclaimed shows, concerts, musical theatre productions, festivals and other performing arts events for nearly 20 years. Our amazing and talented students and team are proud to perform for their audience every chance they get. Learning through DAPA’s drama classes, singing lessons, voice training workshops and performance arts masterclasses, all our talented students are ready to step out on stage to show you the stars they have become!

"A Riot of Rhythm" is the 2021 annual showcase concert to give kids a platform to showcase their talents and skills developed, perform the repertoire learned and gain performing experience and exposure in the discipline of performing arts. The show will feature a review-style theatrical performance of a variety of pop hits and musical theatre excerpts including phenomenal solo performances, engaging duets and ensembles and exciting, choreographed group numbers performed show-choir style. 

For more information visit https://dapaaustralia.com/concert-events/.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our estimated budget including production fees, marketing costs and artist fees (band etc.) works out to approximately $34,000. Of this amount we expect to raise around $18,000 from our internal fund raising activities, sponsorships and student fees. This leave a shortfall of about $16,500 which needs to be raised to ensure that ongoing performances are sustainable.

A detailed budget it available - email admissions@dapaaustralia.com to request the budget PDF should you wish to peruse it.

Your contribution will help us ensure the show goes on even in these hard times, enabling our children to keep shining their star!

  • Contributions of $30 or more will enable you to access a 10% discount on all tickets purchased
  • Contributions of $50 or more will enable you to access a 20% discount on all tickets purchased
  • Contributions of $100 or more will enable you to access a 20% discount on tickets purchased plus priority seating
  • The highest contributor (above $100) will receive 4 complimentary tickets and VIP seating.

 

The Impact

Supporting the performing arts and ongoing creative development for our kids is supporting their future and giving them a platform to realise their fullest potential, shoot for the stars and achieve their dreams. Performing arts develops confidence and community, providing a safe and fun avenue for kids to explore their creative capacity.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate funds, there are other ways you can support the cause:

  • Spread the word to help stimulate ticket sales!
  • Share this campaign on social media
  • Like and follow our facebook page
  • Share our social media posts about the show and invite people to the facebook event page

From the DAPA Team, a heartfelt thank you for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hello, my name is Juan Carlos Arroyave, I'm from Medellin, Colombia. We have been working in a contemporary dance performance called "Entre Mujeres" ("Among Women"). Please allow me to tell you what this is about.

"Entre Mujeres", is a tribute to the women movement. We start from the stereotypes associated at the female gender to invite the spectator to transcend their look and realize that the female language is common to all the human being.

"Entre Mujeres" is almost a reality, almost. We still need $20.000 dollars to show 5 more performances in the Medellín's neighborhoods and communes. After those performances, we reflexionate with the audience about the topics that our work treats.

We count on your support, thank you and our best regards from Colombia.

story:
What would happen if your ex moved in next door?

We'll show you!


The Girl Next Door is an intimate, LGBTQIA+ inclusive play that features over 20 original songs in the pop-rock style. With a script by Sara Mayfield and music by Sara Mayfield & Ava Maria Safai, this new Canadian musical follows a girl caught between her present relationship with the man of her dreams and her fiery first love; a musician named Jade.

 

The creators helming this project: 

+

Sara Mayfield is a queer french Canadian director, actress, writer and theatre technician. She is a graduate of Capilano University’s Musical Theatre program, where she got experience writing and directing several scenes. In the summer of 2018, Sara was a contracted actor in Skis and Skates, an original musical about the first women's hockey tournament in Canada. She originated a role in the show, as well as helped create songs for the show playing both the guitar and French Canadian spoons. Her experience working on this new show has given her insight into the play development process, which is essential to this project. After this show, Sara was cast in Shakespeare Canada’s touring production of The Tempest, playing Antonia, Ferdinand, and Stephano. In addition to these professional acting contracts, Sara has been present in many community theatre productions since her debut in 2013, most recently appearing in Mamma Mia at the Abbotsford Arts Center. She is currently part of the main cast for Tabletop Tiddies, a queer and feminist Dungeons and Dragons podcast streamed live on Twitch Tuesday nights at 7pm and available on all podcasting mediums. She is a producer as well as cast on this show, organising advertising, podcast cross promotion, and acting as the show’s publicist.

Prior to going to school for musical theatre, Sara made it a priority to learn the technical elements of theatre. She was the props manager and special effect coordinator for Carrie: The Musical and stage managed Virgins: A Musical Threesome with Fighting Chance Productions. She has also worked in various roles for Theatre under the Stars (two seasons working front of house) and Awkward Stage Productions (assistant stage manager, runner, follow spot operator). These experiences, in addition to a production and technical theatre class at Capilano University, will help ensure that The Girl Next Door is a success! Check out her other work at SaraMayfield.wixsite.com/mysite

 

Ava Maria Safai is a Middle Eastern actress, director, singer-songwriter, and musician based in North Vancouver and holds her BFA in Theatre - Acting from the University of British Columbia. Select Credits include Woman in Revolt, She Said. Revolt Again. (UBC), Lady Barbara/Eve/Horse in Timothy Findley's "The Wars" (UBC), Iris in The New Margo (Seeing Things Collective),  and Alice/François in Marcel (The Smith Foundation for the Arts). When Ava Maria is not acting, she is hard at work in the studio creating original music. Following the placement of her first single "Finding Hope" on Lifetime's Dance Moms, Ava Maria released her debut album We've Got Issues, her EP The Butterfly Acoustic and her merchandise line at her concert on the Red Gate Revue Stage in 2018. She has garnered over one million views on YouTube, been featured in Maclean's magazine, and was selected as The North Shore News' "Favourite Local Celebrity" (2018). She also collaborates with her father to compose scores and soundtracks for feature films and television series. In 2019, she completed and published her second record He Loves Me (Not), as well her first holiday single In The Snow. In October 2020, Ava Maria released her third album Goodbye, Dalloway to fans across the globe via an online release concert. Ava Maria is also an experienced director, choreographer, music producer, composer and writer. She is known for bringing many of her talents on to every project she does and is excited to do the same on The Girl Next Door. Further information about Ava is available at www.AvaMariaSafai.com

 

 

The Plot:

This show follows our protagonist, Violet, as she wrestles with two romantic relationships; the first, her current relationship with her boyfriend Greyson, and the other, a past relationship with her university flame Jade. Our story is launched when Violet and Greyson move into a new apartment, only to realize that their next-door-neighbour is none other than Jade. These inciting circumstances awaken once-dormant emotions and memories inside our protagonist, allowing the audience to experience the highs and lows of each relationship through flashbacks as well as events in the present time. These high stakes propel the characters to express their feelings in a memorable pop/rock score, which draws from the likes of Pasek & Paul (“Dear Evan Hansen,” “Dogfight”), Jeff Richmond (“Mean Girls”) and Brian Yorkey & Tom Kit (“Next to Normal,” “If/Then,” “Freaky Friday,” “High Fidelity”)

 

 

The Perks:

Fernie : $10   This tier named after a symbolic fern in our show gets your named featured in our program and website!

Stationary : $20   This tier named after a song from our show gets your name featured in our program and website as well as a personalised E-card thank you!

You Care : $35   This tier named after a song from our show gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, and a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show!

Out Of Your Mind : $50   This tier named after our finale number gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, and early access to the digital album!

Moving Up : $75    This tier named after our opening number gets your name featured in our program and website, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, early access to the digital album, and a thank you package! (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!)

Star-Crossed Lover : $100    This Tier named after our love ballad gets your name featured in our program and website, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, early access to the digital album, a thank you package (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!) and 1 VIP ticket to the shows premier!

The Girl Next Door Fan : $150    You're a real fan! This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  early access to the digital album, a The Girl Next Door Merch Pack, and a personalised 30s song! Please let us know your name (or the person the song's about name) and 3 things about them (i.e. occupation, hobbies, pets, favorite food...) and we will write you a 30s song!

Violet's Care Package : $250    This is an extra special package from Violet to you! With this tier you get your name featured in our program and website, A  1 VIP ticket to the show, and a care package from Violet (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, a Letter from Violet, The Girl Next Door Bath Bomb, a travel mug, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!)

Greyson's Picnic : $500    Score a picnic date with at least one member of The Girl Next Door's creative team, courtesy of Greyson! (If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship the picnic to you & meet via Zoom.)  This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  Greyson's Picnic Experience, and 1 VIP ticket to the show!

Violet's Ice Cream and Vodka : $500    Let's satisfy your sweet tooth! Meet at least one creative from The Girl Next Door and enjoy an evening filled with ice cream, vodka, bourbon, chocolate, henny, sundaes, sprinkles, and cherries, courtesy of Violet. (Alcohol for 19+ only. If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship you materials to decorate your sundae & meet via Zoom. ) This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  Violet's Ice Cream and Vodka Experience, and 1 VIP ticket to the show!

Perfect : $750    Attend one of our technical rehearsals, where you will meet the cast & crew and get one-on-one time with the team to ask any of your burning questions. Our writers will also treat you to dinner at one of our favourite restaurants in Vancouver. (If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship the dinner to you & meet via Zoom.) This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  Cast/Crew meet and greet, dinner with the writers and 1 VIP ticket to the show!

In Too Deep : $1000    This one is for the die-hard The Girl Next Door fan! Experience either Violet's Ice Cream & Vodka or Greyson's Picnic, enjoy a dinner with the writers AND meet the cast/crew of our show in a technical rehearsal. (If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship the products to you & meet via Zoom.) This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, a The Girl Next Door Merch Pack, Cast/Crew meet and greet, dinner with the writers, One character experience (Greyson's Picnic or Violets Ice Cream and Vodka) and 1 VIP ticket to the show!

The Girl Next Door : $1500    This is for the one who wants it all! This perk gets you every perk we got as well as 4 VIP Opening night tickets, a producer credit, and a cast/crew Autographed program! 

 

 

Thank you!

Your contribution will support the premiere of our show. Money earned through this campaign will support everything from the construction of the set, costumes, venue rentals and artist compensation. We thank you for your generosity.
story_txt:
What would happen if your ex moved in next door?We'll show you!The Girl Next Door is an intimate, LGBTQIA+ inclusive play that features over 20 original songs in the pop-rock style. With a script by Sara Mayfield and music by Sara Mayfield & Ava Maria Safai, this new Canadian musical follows a girl caught between her present relationship with the man of her dreams and her fiery first love; a musician named Jade. The creators helming this project: 
+
Sara Mayfield is a queer french Canadian director, actress, writer and theatre technician. She is a graduate of Capilano University’s Musical Theatre program, where she got experience writing and directing several scenes. In the summer of 2018, Sara was a contracted actor in Skis and Skates, an original musical about the first women's hockey tournament in Canada. She originated a role in the show, as well as helped create songs for the show playing both the guitar and French Canadian spoons. Her experience working on this new show has given her insight into the play development process, which is essential to this project. After this show, Sara was cast in Shakespeare Canada’s touring production of The Tempest, playing Antonia, Ferdinand, and Stephano. In addition to these professional acting contracts, Sara has been present in many community theatre productions since her debut in 2013, most recently appearing in Mamma Mia at the Abbotsford Arts Center. She is currently part of the main cast for Tabletop Tiddies, a queer and feminist Dungeons and Dragons podcast streamed live on Twitch Tuesday nights at 7pm and available on all podcasting mediums. She is a producer as well as cast on this show, organising advertising, podcast cross promotion, and acting as the show’s publicist.Prior to going to school for musical theatre, Sara made it a priority to learn the technical elements of theatre. She was the props manager and special effect coordinator for Carrie: The Musical and stage managed Virgins: A Musical Threesome with Fighting Chance Productions. She has also worked in various roles for Theatre under the Stars (two seasons working front of house) and Awkward Stage Productions (assistant stage manager, runner, follow spot operator). These experiences, in addition to a production and technical theatre class at Capilano University, will help ensure that The Girl Next Door is a success! Check out her other work at SaraMayfield.wixsite.com/mysite Ava Maria Safai is a Middle Eastern actress, director, singer-songwriter, and musician based in North Vancouver and holds her BFA in Theatre - Acting from the University of British Columbia. Select Credits include Woman in Revolt, She Said. Revolt Again. (UBC), Lady Barbara/Eve/Horse in Timothy Findley's "The Wars" (UBC), Iris in The New Margo (Seeing Things Collective),  and Alice/François in Marcel (The Smith Foundation for the Arts). When Ava Maria is not acting, she is hard at work in the studio creating original music. Following the placement of her first single "Finding Hope" on Lifetime's Dance Moms, Ava Maria released her debut album We've Got Issues, her EP The Butterfly Acoustic and her merchandise line at her concert on the Red Gate Revue Stage in 2018. She has garnered over one million views on YouTube, been featured in Maclean's magazine, and was selected as The North Shore News' "Favourite Local Celebrity" (2018). She also collaborates with her father to compose scores and soundtracks for feature films and television series. In 2019, she completed and published her second record He Loves Me (Not), as well her first holiday single In The Snow. In October 2020, Ava Maria released her third album Goodbye, Dalloway to fans across the globe via an online release concert. Ava Maria is also an experienced director, choreographer, music producer, composer and writer. She is known for bringing many of her talents on to every project she does and is excited to do the same on The Girl Next Door. Further information about Ava is available at www.AvaMariaSafai.com  The Plot:This show follows our protagonist, Violet, as she wrestles with two romantic relationships; the first, her current relationship with her boyfriend Greyson, and the other, a past relationship with her university flame Jade. Our story is launched when Violet and Greyson move into a new apartment, only to realize that their next-door-neighbour is none other than Jade. These inciting circumstances awaken once-dormant emotions and memories inside our protagonist, allowing the audience to experience the highs and lows of each relationship through flashbacks as well as events in the present time. These high stakes propel the characters to express their feelings in a memorable pop/rock score, which draws from the likes of Pasek & Paul (“Dear Evan Hansen,” “Dogfight”), Jeff Richmond (“Mean Girls”) and Brian Yorkey & Tom Kit (“Next to Normal,” “If/Then,” “Freaky Friday,” “High Fidelity”)  The Perks:Fernie : $10   This tier named after a symbolic fern in our show gets your named featured in our program and website!Stationary : $20   This tier named after a song from our show gets your name featured in our program and website as well as a personalised E-card thank you!You Care : $35   This tier named after a song from our show gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, and a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show!Out Of Your Mind : $50   This tier named after our finale number gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, and early access to the digital album!Moving Up : $75    This tier named after our opening number gets your name featured in our program and website, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, early access to the digital album, and a thank you package! (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!)Star-Crossed Lover : $100    This Tier named after our love ballad gets your name featured in our program and website, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show, early access to the digital album, a thank you package (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!) and 1 VIP ticket to the shows premier!The Girl Next Door Fan : $150    You're a real fan! This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a personalised E-card thank you, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  early access to the digital album, a The Girl Next Door Merch Pack, and a personalised 30s song! Please let us know your name (or the person the song's about name) and 3 things about them (i.e. occupation, hobbies, pets, favorite food...) and we will write you a 30s song!Violet's Care Package : $250    This is an extra special package from Violet to you! With this tier you get your name featured in our program and website, A  1 VIP ticket to the show, and a care package from Violet (including Violet's Candies and Stickers, a hand-written thank you letter, a Letter from Violet, The Girl Next Door Bath Bomb, a travel mug, and a special edition Violet Patch from the show!)Greyson's Picnic : $500    Score a picnic date with at least one member of The Girl Next Door's creative team, courtesy of Greyson! (If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship the picnic to you & meet via Zoom.)  This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  Greyson's Picnic Experience, and 1 VIP ticket to the show!Violet's Ice Cream and Vodka : $500    Let's satisfy your sweet tooth! Our writers will also treat you to dinner at one of our favourite restaurants in Vancouver. (If based outside of the Vancouver area, we will ship the dinner to you & meet via Zoom.) This tier gets your name featured in our program and website, a handwritten thank you letter, a secret song sample with demos of three songs from our show,  Cast/Crew meet and greet, dinner with the writers and 1 VIP ticket to the show!In Too Deep : $1000    This one is for the die-hard The Girl Next Door fan! story:
Jez Dolan and Joshua Val Martin are making a new performance

Jez and Joshua are making a new show 'Double-Ender'. #DoubleEnder

Double-Ender tells our story. How we are affected by the gentrification and homogenisation of our city, its changing attitudes to LGBTQ people, the language we use, and how easy it is to forget our own history.

Double-Ender is a new collaboration between visual artist Jez Dolan and playwright Joshual Val Martin that uses storytelling to explore the cultural capital of queerness.

Taking as its starting point the psycho-geography of the city and Polari - the lost language of gay men, hear the story of how Joshua took fetish clubs on historical walking tours of Manchester, and how cottaging can lead to long-term love. Discover how language can both reveal queer identity and obscure its content to the uninitiated, see how cities can grow and change, both for the better and for the worse, shaping attitudes towards queer people.

Dolan and Martin bring together their work for the first time to create a fast-paced show that both informs and entertains.

We can only make this show with your support.  Your contribution will help pay for the basic costs of rehearsing and mounting the show and lead to presentations in Manchester, Bury and Oldham.  If these work, we'll aim to send Double-Ender out on an extensive tour of England and beyond in 2021.

DUE TO COVID-19 OUR PERFORMANCES HAVE BEEN KNOCKED BACK TO LATER IN THE YEAR - HOWEVER WE ARE STILL MAKING THE SHOW!

 

Any contribution you can  make will be really helpful.

story:
We are taking the Dying Swan on Tour - first Toronto, then the World!

We are a community based, small, passionate, highly motivated group of Carnival lovers and we are on a mission!

The Dying Swan represents the epitome of Mas and Caribbean Theatre and we want the world to see what Trinidad and Tobago has done. We would like to bring this mas to Toronto this summer for guest appearances.

We need your help!

We need to raise $20,000USD to cover all expenses for the team of six people to travel up from Port of Spain, Trinidad. We are asking for you kind donations to help us make this happen. The funds will be used to cover: Transportation (flights, in-city transportation), food, lodging (for 6 people for about 10 days), equipment rental and storage space.

We will also be approaching potential sponsors to help us cover these costs.

  

We are approaching large venues to host the Costume: Harbourfront, the CNE, Ontario Place, Ontario Science Centre, The Royal Ontario Museum. If you are able to connect us with other suitable venues, please contact us at: TheDyingSwan@Outlook.com

We hope the Toronto Carnival, King and Queen Competition and Pan Alive will host the Dying Swan!


Who are we?

Our team is Nathalie Taghaboni, Oswald McLean, Austin Fido and Ian Royer and we believe the world needs to see this live!


Why are we doing this?

Anyone who caught even a glimpse of this 2016 Costume knows that it is unlike anything we have seen in a very long time. It has taken the spirit of original, traditional Mas and served it up fresh and new. Designed by Peter Minshall and portrayed by Jha-whan Thomas, The Dying Swan. Ras Nijinsky in Drag as Pavlova was unexpected as it arrived on stage at the Trinidad and Tobago Carnival King and Queen Competition in February 2016. It silenced the crowd with its simplicity and rewrote Mas history.

 


Other Ways You Can Help.

Every little bit will help and we know the passion is shared not just in the Caribbean Community but in all areas of the Arts, Music and Theatre.

If you know of venues we should include in our requests, let us know!

If you know of sponsors who would be able to help us reach our goal, let us know!

if you can connect us with lodgings, space for rehearsals and storage, let us know!

Help us make The Dying Swan  welcome in Toronto!

Once we're done, we'd love to hear from our US, UK friends!

story:
Tired of the same endless loop of Shakespeare and Oscar Wilde in small theaters? The days when stageplays were moneymakers is long gone, unless you're in the business of doing Broadway-level work. Everyone else is working with a tight budget, and often cannot afford to pay royalties for plays that are in copyright. 

This website will contain a curated collection of plays that are public domain or which have been released by their authors for performance without further royalty payments. The site will be free to use, and will operate as a not for profit project.

Funds will be used to pay for website essentials such as domain name, hosting, and design services.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Ely Sonny Orquiza and I am directing the American Premiere of TRADE by renowned Irish playwright Mark O'Halloran for the longest running queer theatre in the world, Theatre Rhinoceros in San Francisco.

Back in 2015 when I studied abroad to examine Irish Theatre in Dublin and Galway, Ireland, I was introduced to the queer political performance landscape brewing underneath the religious fabric of Ireland's Republic. Queer Theatre in Ireland is rich, potent, and unapologetic. 

I was introduced to TRADE by Professor Jody Allen Randolph as part of the course curriculum. TRADE deeply touched me. The play challenged my perspectives: it was thought-provoking, fresh, and invigorating. I want to stage this dynamic play to San Francisco where it will hopefully find its way to the hearts of our audiences, like it did mine.

By helping us reach our fundraising goals, you are helping us bring and share this complex yet profound story to our San Francisco theatre audiences in the Spring.

What We Need 

As an artist in the Bay Area, I want to make sure this process is as equitable to everyone involved. I have a desire to compensate all the artists for contributing their time, effort, and expertise to fully realizing the mounting of this truly unique and genuine production. Our three-person production needs:

  • Artists (to: John Trantichella and Mikee Loria) stipend 
  • Consumable Props (non-alcoholic beer)
  • Director (Ely Sonny Orquiza) stipend
  • Dialect Coach stipend
  • Graphic Designer
  • Marketing stipend
  • Modest costume budget
  • Printing Programs 
  • Printing Flyers (re: Marketing)
  • Small stipend for Tech Week Snacks

The Impact

To reach our fundraising goals, we need your support. You will be helping us build the world of this play and making it possible to create an independent, artist-led, equitable Pop-Up Theatre, an initiative new to Theatre Rhinoceros' season in partnership with Spark Arts Gallery in San Francisco's Castro Neighborhood. We want the community to rally behind this production, either by word of mouth, sharing the fundraising platform, or donating to meet our goals. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that finances are a big concern for everyone. If you are unable to help donate at this time, it would be wonderful if you can spread the word and share this IndieGoGo crowdfunding platform to your family, friends, and colleagues. We appreciate all forms of support that we get. It takes a village to create a performance production!

Thank you so much!

All my best,

Ely Sonny Orquiza

(Trade, Director)

story:
Our Story

Charity Clark-Anderson and Angela G. King first met as members of the all-female cast whose rendition of venerated author and playwright Pearl Cleage's A Song for Coretta was voted "Best Play of the Season" by the subscribers to the Detroit Repertory Theatre. From then on, they would often bring up the possibility of starting a group to help nurture other aspiring local playwrights like themselves whenever they would run into each other at various theater events. Leah Smith, marketing and development director for the Rep, eventually overheard just such a conversation and piped up, "You can meet here!" From that extraordinary proposition emerged The Detroit Playwrights' Lab ("The Lab").

More than 20 individuals came out to Detroit's oldest professional producing theater on July 25, 2016, for the first-ever meeting of The Lab. Individuals who included nationally renowned local playwright and retired Wayne State University English professor, Bill Harris. And, by Skype from Los Angeles, Dominique Morisseau, the Tony-nominated playwright who also hails from Detroit. 

Meeting typically every other Monday at the Rep since then, The Lab now counts the likes of Clark-Anderson, a two-time Audience Favorite winner of the annual BoxFest Detroit festival for women directors at Plant Ant Theatre, among its ranks. As well as 2018 Kresge Artist fellow, Emilio Rodriguez. And such increasing regulars on the theater festival circuit as King, Collette Cullen, Jennifier Ellis and Emily Fishman.

Fueled by steady inroads in the Detroit theater community, The Lab endures as a forum for playwrights of varying levels to come together and hear their works read and critiqued. We also offer writing exercises, group theater outings and other related undertakings to help cultivate the full creative development of our members' unique individual voices.  And we culminate each season with a staged summer showcase of 10-minute plays and excerpts from plays written by our members. Plays and excerpts that are helmed and brought to life on the stage of the Detroit Rep by some of the most promising theater directors and actors in Metro Detroit. Most recently we were granted another honor by Meadow Brook Theatre: the opportunity to launch a series of readings of one- and two-act plays by our members at this venerable institution.

Even though we present all of our productions to the public free of charge -- courtesy of a lot of volunteer effort that we would some day like to compensate --these events are not without cost to bring to fruition. Which is why we ask you to partner with us financially in ensuring the continued viability of the Detroit Playwrights' Lab.

Thank you in advance for your support!
