story:
Our Story

In early May of 2020, after two months of quarantine and the announcement of the indefinite closure of New York City's Broadway theatres, video essayist Kyle Kallgren decided that he had had enough.

Honestly, he'd missed participating in theatre for a long while, but this assault on one of his (and the world's) most beloved institutions was a breaking point. He reached out to see who among his friends would be interested in joining an endeavor to start making theatre in the present, the "new normal," where traditional physical theatre wasn't coming back for a while. Standouts among his enthusiastic and capable respondents were David Kowarsky and Ilana Greenberg-Sud, who signed on as producers for the first project.

Inspired by the rise of authoritarian leaders at home and abroad, the initial plan was to produce a version of Alfred Jarry's proto-absurdist King Ubu, as a re-affirmation of the necessary role of theatre as social commentary. Then, after the death of George Floyd on May 25th, the world grew a little darker and less stable. Protests, and the reactions thereto, began to escalate in intensity and dominate the news that was not about COVID-19. We realized that we needed to emphasize different goals of theatre -- we needed to bring people together, and drive us towards a better world. 

We pivoted to produce Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, on Midsummer, something a bit more uplifting and accessible, and we decided to organize the performance as a fundraiser for bail and mutual aid funds. 

With just a few weeks of lead time, we peaked at over 300 simultaneous viewers. The stream has since garnered over 7000 views (at the time of writing this), and our viewers donated over $5,000 to the cause.

We want to bring actors, writers, directors, and other artists together to continue to our work in preserving and innovating the institution of theatre. We want to make social justice part of our mission as a theatre company. We want to keep learning and growing.

And we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise a total of $9,500. This is the amount that we've identified that will provide us with:

  • Initial Startup Costs
    • Legal fees, government filing fees, initial web design costs
  • 1 Year of Maintenance expenses for the organization
    • Bank Fees, Hosting and software tools (mailing list, social media management)
    • Marketing/Advertising
  • 80% of projected operational expenses for Year 1.
    • Rights, costumes and props, artist and staff stipends for two major productions, several minor ones
  • Fundraising Fees and Perk expenses

Worlds Elsewhere Theatre company believes first and foremost in the value of art of all kinds, especially theatre. While we are largely charity-driven and nonprofit in nature, we want to be able to support artists. This may involve licensing newer works not in the public domain, by spending on technology, costumes, and props for our performers, or compensating our performers and administrative staff for productions that are not directly associated with a charitable event. 

Eventually, we hope to be putting out enough content and building a strong enough community such that we can be funded largely through some combination of recurring donations and occasional pay-per-view content, but there's a lot of startup cost. 

As a new organization, we'll need to retain the services of lawyers to help us get set up as an LLC, then to establish and maintain our status as a 501(c)(3) organization so we can directly handle funds for our charitable efforts, rather than simply directing people to an outside site to donate. A lot of the feedback we got after Midsummer was that people wanted it to be easier to donate, and it's a lot easier to make that happen when you can accept donations directly, as well as offer tax deductibility.

Furthermore, we need all of the things online organizations do: mailing lists, social media management software, web hosting and design.

And we'd like to do something for our backers. We're looking forward to having fun with our T-shirt designs, and our repertory company is already a small but supportive community on Discord. If you join us, that'll be a place where you can be the first to know about our new projects, be invited to exclusive events like readings, talkbacks, and classes, and just hang with some absolutely wonderful artists. 

The Impact

Worlds Elsewhere plans to "stage"

  • At least 2 major productions each year, on the scale of Midsummer or Lysistrata
  • At least one charity focused production per year.
  • Many other smaller events, such as the Winter Cabaret on December 19th, informal readings on our Discord, or theatre "jams" where our company will be part of creating wholly new work. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Creative endeavors are, in part because of the difficulties of ensuring financial support, often a dicey prospect. People who are primarily motivated by passion can often find their passions sapped in times of economic or other more foundational uncertainties. 

However, our team is highly qualified and experienced with maintaining organizational discipline for the long haul.

Kyle Kallgren has been producing video essays regularly on YouTube, both independently and as part of larger creative collaborative groups for over 10 years.  His channel has over 70,000 subscribers. 

David Kowarsky was the first non-founder employee of Grovo Learning Inc., an online learning startup in the corporate training space. He established, maintained, and evolved the video production quality standards for which Grovo's content team became widely known. After 8 years of operation, Grovo was acquired by market leader Cornerstone OnDemand in 2018. The content team became the center of Cornerstone's Studios division, which continues to produce world-class learning content.

Ilana Greenberg-Sud is a veteran of theatre, with experience in front-of-house operations, backstage coordination, and everywhere in between. She's especially passionate about the intersection of theatre and charitable work, remembering fondly her work as director and producer of The Vagina Monologues at UMD for three years. Additionally she has over a decade of leadership and online community management experience for many organizations and events including DragonCon, Fandom Grammar, and J/D Ficathon.

If we can firmly establish our organization with this initial investment, and offer some compensation to our artists and administrators doing the work of the company, we hope to achieve self-sustainability through regular contributions of patrons, and perhaps occasional pay-per-view events, (though we hope to remain accessible as possible).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you, like many people, are not in a position to offer your financial support at the moment. This is a difficult time. If that is the case and you would still like to support our mission, any of the following steps would be very welcome assistance. 

  • Subscribe to the Worlds Elsewhere YouTube Channel!
  • Like our Facebook Page!
  • Sign up for our Newsletter!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share links to the campaign.
story_txt:
Our Story
In early May of 2020, after two months of quarantine and the announcement of the indefinite closure of New York City's Broadway theatres, video essayist Kyle Kallgren decided that he had had enough.
Honestly, he'd missed participating in theatre for a long while, but this assault on one of his (and the world's) most beloved institutions was a breaking point. He reached out to see who among his friends would be interested in joining an endeavor to start making theatre in the present, the "new normal," where traditional physical theatre wasn't coming back for a while. Standouts among his enthusiastic and capable respondents were David Kowarsky and Ilana Greenberg-Sud, who signed on as producers for the first project.
Inspired by the rise of authoritarian leaders at home and abroad, the initial plan was to produce a version of Alfred Jarry's proto-absurdist King Ubu, as a re-affirmation of the necessary role of theatre as social commentary. Then, after the death of George Floyd on May 25th, the world grew a little darker and less stable. Protests, and the reactions thereto, began to escalate in intensity and dominate the news that was not about COVID-19. We realized that we needed to emphasize different goals of theatre -- we needed to bring people together, and drive us towards a better world. 
We pivoted to produce Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, on Midsummer, something a bit more uplifting and accessible, and we decided to organize the performance as a fundraiser for bail and mutual aid funds. 
With just a few weeks of lead time, we peaked at over 300 simultaneous viewers. The stream has since garnered over 7000 views (at the time of writing this), and our viewers donated over $5,000 to the cause.
We want to bring actors, writers, directors, and other artists together to continue to our work in preserving and innovating the institution of theatre. We want to make social justice part of our mission as a theatre company. We want to keep learning and growing.
And we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get
Our goal is to raise a total of $9,500. This is the amount that we've identified that will provide us with:

Initial Startup CostsLegal fees, government filing fees, initial web design costs

1 Year of Maintenance expenses for the organization
Bank Fees, Hosting and software tools (mailing list, social media management)
Marketing/Advertising


80% of projected operational expenses for Year 1.Rights, costumes and props, artist and staff stipends for two major productions, several minor ones

Fundraising Fees and Perk expenses

Worlds Elsewhere Theatre company believes first and foremost in the value of art of all kinds, especially theatre. While we are largely charity-driven and nonprofit in nature, we want to be able to support artists. This may involve licensing newer works not in the public domain, by spending on technology, costumes, and props for our performers, or compensating our performers and administrative staff for productions that are not directly associated with a charitable event. 
Eventually, we hope to be putting out enough content and building a strong enough community such that we can be funded largely through some combination of recurring donations and occasional pay-per-view content, but there's a lot of startup cost. 
As a new organization, we'll need to retain the services of lawyers to help us get set up as an LLC, then to establish and maintain our status as a 501(c)(3) organization so we can directly handle funds for our charitable efforts, rather than simply directing people to an outside site to donate. A lot of the feedback we got after Midsummer was that people wanted it to be easier to donate, and it's a lot easier to make that happen when you can accept donations directly, as well as offer tax deductibility.
Furthermore, we need all of the things online organizations do: mailing lists, social media management software, web hosting and design.
And we'd like to do something for our backers. We're looking forward to having fun with our T-shirt designs, and our repertory company is already a small but supportive community on Discord. If you join us, that'll be a place where you can be the first to know about our new projects, be invited to exclusive events like readings, talkbacks, and classes, and just hang with some absolutely wonderful artists. 

The Impact
Worlds Elsewhere plans to "stage"

At least 2 major productions each year, on the scale of Midsummer or Lysistrata

At least one charity focused production per year.
Many other smaller events, such as the Winter Cabaret on December 19th, informal readings on our Discord, or theatre "jams" where our company will be part of creating wholly new work. 

 

Risks & Challenges
Creative endeavors are, in part because of the difficulties of ensuring financial support, often a dicey prospect. People who are primarily motivated by passion can often find their passions sapped in times of economic or other more foundational uncertainties. 
However, our team is highly qualified and experienced with maintaining organizational discipline for the long haul.
Kyle Kallgren has been producing video essays regularly on YouTube, both independently and as part of larger creative collaborative groups for over 10 years.  His channel has over 70,000 subscribers. 
David Kowarsky was the first non-founder employee of Grovo Learning Inc., an online learning startup in the corporate training space. He established, maintained, and evolved the video production quality standards for which Grovo's content team became widely known. After 8 years of operation, Grovo was acquired by market leader Cornerstone OnDemand in 2018. The content team became the center of Cornerstone's Studios division, which continues to produce world-class learning content.
Ilana Greenberg-Sud is a veteran of theatre, with experience in front-of-house operations, backstage coordination, and everywhere in between. She's especially passionate about the intersection of theatre and charitable work, remembering fondly her work as director and producer of The Vagina Monologues at UMD for three years. Additionally she has over a decade of leadership and online community management experience for many organizations and events including DragonCon, Fandom Grammar, and J/D Ficathon.
If we can firmly establish our organization with this initial investment, and offer some compensation to our artists and administrators doing the work of the company, we hope to achieve self-sustainability through regular contributions of patrons, and perhaps occasional pay-per-view events, (though we hope to remain accessible as possible).
 

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand if you, like many people, are not in a position to offer your financial support at the moment. This is a difficult time. If that is the case and you would still like to support our mission, any of the following steps would be very welcome assistance. 

Subscribe to the Worlds Elsewhere YouTube Channel!

Like our Facebook Page!

Sign up for our Newsletter!
Use the Indiegogo share tools to share links to the campaign.

story:
What Is Safe Hands?

Safe Hands is an original folk-rock inspired ensemble musical about five women united by the secret of “Frankie’s House”, a covert abortion clinic on the edge of town. The show explores the hidden lives of women in the 1950s as they struggle with the restraints of domesticity, toxic relationships, and the reality of being a woman in the workplace.

Although Safe Hands has received glowing audience reviews when it was featured at Vassar College (live concert, 2019), Purchase College (virtual reading, 2020), and the Twenty By Twenty Fringe Festival (virtual production, 2021, multi-nominee), due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the musical has not yet gotten the opportunity to be produced in full. Until now!

 

Okay, So What's The Deal? 

We are developing a virtual production of the show set to premiere this fall. Directed by Jen Jacobs with cinematography and video production by Bethany Ostrander, the show will combine elements of film and theatre to deliver a multimedia experience in a collaborative effort of over 20 artists. The piece consists of professional demos with full arrangements combined with live performance; a filming process that unites remote recording with in-person filming, culminating in a true music/film/theatre hybrid experience. The piece is currently in production and plans to be released later this year. 

But we could use your help! Between travel costs, equipment expenses, and making sure our actors get the pay they deserve, your contribution would help produce this effort and give you a ticket to see the production.

 

 

What Do We Need? 

For this show to be a success, we will need some support. 

With over twenty young artists involved in this ensemble show, the piece serves as a love letter to collaboration. Artists deserve fair pay, and so a portion of our budget is dedicated to paying the incredible 20+ actors, musicians, and young artists on our team. As creators, we are not taking anything. If this project exceeds its asking budget, all additional earnings will go towards increasing the stipend for our performers. 

 

The rest of our budget is allocated towards providing the tools to successfully execute this endeavor. Some of our largest expenses include travel (21%) for providing transportation for the actors and crew to and from our physical shoots, and the needs for production days (24%), including filmmaking equipment such as lights and recording devices to ensure the highest quality product possible in addition to safety precautions to ensure the entire company remains in Safe Hands. To advertise the musical, we require funds to run ads and make sure the show reaches a wide audience. 

Not only is your generosity helping to fund this project, but it serves as an investment in the future of the show, as we hope to use these demos and footage to help secure us further development and production opportunities.

 

In exchange for your generous support, we're offering a tiered special rewards system! For each donation benchmark hit by an individual donation, you will receive all of the perks at that tier, plus all of those in the tiers below. 

 

$5 - Ticket To Show

$25 - Personalized Thank You Note & Thank You by Name in the Playbill and Website

$50 - Early Access to A Musical Number 

$100 - Access to the Full Safe Hands Soundtrack (not available to the general public) & Signed Poster from Our Cast

$250 - Personalized Thank You Video & Personalized Limerick

 

We are also offering limited quantities of an exclusive Limerick Perk ($36), where our writers will pen you a poem of your very own!

 

Media

Early Demo for "Stay For The Ride" featuring iraya

 
Early Demo for "Out With The Wash" featuring Lucy Hall, Elena Rey
 

Don't take our word for it! 

 

 

Creative Team

 

The Current Crisis

29 U.S. states are considered "hostile" to abortion rights (2019). 58% of American women  of reproductive age (nearly 40 million) live in these states. 

Internationally, laws fall along a continuum from outright prohibition to allowing abortion without restriction as to reason. As of 2017, 42% of women of reproductive age live in the 125 countries where abortion is highly restricted (prohibited altogether, or allowed only to save a woman’s life or protect her health).

Abortions occur as frequently in the two most-restrictive categories of countries (banned outright or allowed only to save the woman’s life) as in the least-restrictive category (allowed without restriction as to reason)—37 and 34 per 1,000 women, respectively.

If this project speaks to you or if you are passionate about protecting every woman's right to safe healthcare, please consider donating to one of the following resources.

 

Ipas: Providing access to safe abortion and contraception for women and girls around the world.

Planned Parenthood: Planned Parenthood delivers vital reproductive health care, sex education, and information to millions of people worldwide. 

International Women's Health Coalition: Advocacy, policy-making, and education worldwide in the name of women's health.

The National Domestic Abuse Hotline : Supporting current and previous victims of domestic violence with 24/7 live chat, safety planning, abuse identifying resources, connection to local domestic abuse recovery organizations, and more. 

 

Stay Up To Date With Safe Hands 

Instagram: @magritteandrosen

magritteandrosen.com

If you want to help but can not afford to donate, we encourage you to repost this campaign to your network and help us boost these important stories!

 

Art by Maddy Obry
